40951695.review: Renowned Explorers is an excellent game.  The basic gameplay of jumping from node to node and having events at each one is pretty good, and there is such a vast amount of content that it takes a very, very long time to experience everything that every expedition has to offer.  It does have  a non-trivial amout of repeated content because each node is a story, and certain common nodes will come up every time you attempt an expedition, but 1) the fast skip of text is on point and 2) the "combat" is nuanced enough with the 3 damage types and associated moods and things that it just doesn't get old.  Additionally, even though I suck hard at video games, new content unlocks after every game (at least for the first many (20+?) expeditions, even with a small RNG associated with the unlocks), which keeps things new and fresh with interesting campfire tales.  Highly recommended.

40300244.review:
世界の秘密を探索していく冒険ゲーム。似たようなゲームにCurious Expeditionがあるが、あちらがヘックスのマップを開いていくストラテジー的探索ゲームだとすると、こちらは文章と選択肢とダイスロールで道を切り開いていくゲームブック的探索ゲームと言えるだろう。

最初に１人のリーダーと２人の仲間を選び、ゲーム開始。謎の眠る土地へと趣く。マップ上では自分の周囲と目的地のみが見えていて、自マスから伸びる道の先のマスを選んで、目的地を目指して移動していく。移動の度に食料を消費する。食料がゼロになってもゲームオーバーではないが、ステータスが激しく下がるので、食料の管理も重要な要素になってくる。

各マスにはイベントが設定してあり、移動するたびに何かが起きる。戦闘やチャレンジなどマスでどのようなことが起きるのか、何が入手できるのかは、移動前にマスの上のアイコンでなんとなくわかる。

マスではイベントが発生し、文章と絵でストーリーが展開される。時に選択肢が表示され、選ぶ選択肢によって状況や報酬が変わっていく。
またイベントではこの選択肢による分岐の他に、状況をクリアできるかどうかを判定するためにチャレンジと呼ばれるダイスロールが行われることがある。ダイスロールでは各キャラクターが持っているチャレンジに対応したスキルによって成功率が上昇する。例えば罠に対してはQuick Tinker（軽業師）、古代遺跡に対してはArchaeologist（考古学者）など。それぞれのスキルジャンルには複数のスキルがあり、会得しているスキル数が多ければさらに成功率が上昇する。
各マスには、どのカテゴリのチャレンジが起きるのかがアイコンで表示されているので、苦手なチャレンジを避けていくこともできる。
各スキルは、装備品、レベルアップ、専門家の雇用、研究などによって会得することができる。どのスキルを誰に会得させるか、という戦略も必要になる。

マスで敵対する人間や生物と出会うと戦闘に突入することがある。戦闘はヘックスを移動してのターン制バトル。ここで特徴的なのは、戦いの目的は敵の体力を奪うのではなく、戦意を削ぐということ。攻撃方法には通常の物理攻撃の他に、会話による侮辱と褒め殺しがあり、どの方法をとっても敵の戦意を削いでいく。キャラクターによって、また敵の種類によって、物理攻撃と会話攻撃に対する得手不得手があり、またどの攻撃方法を多く選んだかによって戦闘報酬も変わってくるので、状況によって攻撃方法を上手に選択することが重要になる。

日本語対応していない上に、文章メインのゲームなので英語を読んでいく必要があるが、わりと平易な文法で書かれているようで、他のゲームに比べて文章は読みやすいと思う。それでも、文章が主体のゲームなので、どうにか日本語化して欲しい。

40071062.review:
The are so many great ideas behind this game that it really pains me to have to not recommend it. But, at the end of the day, the game just isn't actually very fun to play, and that's the most important thing about games, right?

So let's talk a little about it.

It's got a really neat system whereby your explorers have traits. Things like Diplomat or Quick Thinking or Naturalist or Survivalist. These traits have sub-traits, things like Nimble and Reflexes for Quick Thinking or Customs and Language for Diplomat. You can gain multiple sub-traits, even for traits your explorers don't normally have, a variety of ways and trying to get a team with the right mix of sub-traits (and therefore the right mix of traits) seems initially like a fun puzzle.

The unfun here comes from the fact that there are SO many traits (not to even mention sub traits) that you either make a team that can do a little bit of everything (and therefore can do nothing at all well, which is the surest route to disaster ever) or you make a super specalized team and 25% of the time you automatically succeed at whatever you're doing and 75% of the time you automatically fail.

Combat is also another area that seems neat at first but quickly becomes unfun. See, tactics and proper managing of the mood system and what not just isn't enough. In fact, it's almost irrelevant (with some exceptions for when a boss becomes basically impossible to kill if you're in the wrong mood). Gear is really all that matters. Do you have amazing gear? Combat's a cake walk. With even slight attention paid to mood, you'll likely be able to do just about any combat without taking any significant losses. Do you have medicore gear (not bad, just mediocre)? You're gana get 1-2 shot and take 2-3 shots to kill the lowiest mook.

Party composition is another huge issue. It seems like there's tons of options, tons of ways to make a valid party. There isn't. You HAVE to have a real healer, someone with a special ability to that heals for >100% of speech score. That means that one of your three slots is more or less required to be one of about 5 characters. Also, not only do you have to balance your crew around having the right mood composition, but you have to balance around your captian's ability as well. In other words, if you pick a Captain who isn't a healer, you have to pick a healer that matches that Captain. Since there's only about 5 choices for healer, and since not all healers are good with all Captains, you're likely picking from 1-2 of the 5. Then you're last slot has to match both your Captain and your Healer, maximizing your chosen win goal (which has to be picked at party select effectively AND stuck to all game come hell or high water), but one that also compliments them in combat AND fills in any combat weak points you may have. It effectively stops being about choosing a fun party and quickly becomes "well, I get to choose a Captian and after that my choices are pretty much made for me if I don't want my party to suck."

There are lots of other issues along these lines as well. Things that seem fun at first but which just aren't. You'll spend FAR more time with this game angry at your crew for not having the skills you need/failing to succeed when you needed them too, and far more time pulling your hair out in combat because you didn't gold focus harder than you will actually enjoying the fun stories, characters, locations, and adventures.

And that's a shame too, cause the game has so much going for it. Great music, great stories, lots of interesting (if ultimately unfun) systems, cool characters, great art, etc, etc, etc. But at the end of the day, you'll be more angry or frusterated than delighted and satisfied with this purchase. So either wait for a REALLY good sale or just don't get it at all.

39566552.review:
After having spent over 60 hours on this game, I feel quite comfortable to recommend it to anybody who is willing to invest the time required to learn its unique systems. It does take some effort, but given how unique the whole experience is, it is time well spent.

You start by assembling a crew, and that in itself is quite an unique experience. At first you have 4 captains, but as you play with other characters, they are also unlocked for that role. Each character brings an unique benefit from being captain, ranging from very useful to fairly situational. There are three very viable paths to build you crew around, with them being Friendly, Devious and Aggressive. It might seem strange to be able to fight the same battles with a friendly alignment as you would with an aggressive one, but this is exactly the charm of the game. The textual outcome of encounters describes how the enemy reacted to your attitude, giving  a sense of cohesion to the plot.

There are many systems and subsystems happening in parallel, but they all pretty much feed into each other. So for example, the diverse skill pool of your characters gets supplemented by treasures found on the map, training they may receive in towns, and research that can be done inbetween missions, and vice-versa.

The game is quite replayable, as each crew will face the same challenges in a different way. It is perfectly possible to come back to a scene you've been to before and find a completely different outcome due to having another set of skills and personalities at hand.

The game also offers two very distinct modes, Discovery and Adventure. I spent almost all of my time on Discovery, which allows you to save at any time and peruse options at your own pace, also being able to negate a very unlucky skill roll, because those will happen... you have a 97% chance to accomplish a task and it fails. You just reload. That is not an option in Adventure mode, which is the original mode and the hardcore option, I guess. Back when I had infinite time for games that might have been an option, but I'm perfectly happy with Discovery.

It is charming, it is unique, and it is a good investment of your money. Recommended!

39265512.review:
Well the game has nice sides, the system is very original with its friendly/devious/aggressive style. It has a nice rogue lite feeling with captains to unlock. You have a good variety of explorers to choose from to create your crew of 3 explorers.

The game is also very unbalanced, building defense is pretty useless as you will use all your ressources to build a "tank" that will be easily destroyed anyway. To give an exemple, someone with 100 in resistance (which is huge) on the last map will be hit for about 15, when someone with 0 will be hit for about 25. This is totally useless to invest in it, since with 100 offensive power you will oneshot pretty much anything. And even if you want to get a tank to soak all that damage, it's useless because ennemy characters will focus the lighter ones, totally ignoring your tank, and you can't do much about since all good characters can attack through you anyway.

The downside of the game is that despite the variety, it's very quickly repetitive. Your characters have very few skills to use (only 3, a bit more with leveling) but most of the time you can only use 1 or 2 because of the context (malus, resistances, immunities of ennemies), not many choices... You keep these 3 characters for the whole run, so fights are really repetitive.

The city system between explorations is boring, then you get thousands of bonuses, of "get more status per encounter, get more status per campaign, get more science per... There are so many bonuses in the end that you can't plan anything, you just try to focus on one thing and there's no real strategy.

And the worst is that the last map is always the same, same 3 palaces to get the same 3 keys, same final boss that is insanely difficult compared to the difficulty of the last map.

I had planned to do lots of different things on this game as I do with most rogue lites, but after 2 runs I'm already bored.
39265512.developer_response:
Hey there! Sorry that we ended up boring you. Besides the expansions (adds another 3, 4 and 5 expedition), there is not much I think I can do to help you improve your experience. The overworld can indeed be overwhelming and hard to plan on, although I do believe it offers a lot of strategy. (take a look in the community challenges or discord to see some examples) I admit that the battles aren't always that interesting too. Certainly a place where the game could do better.

However, the thing about tanks strikes me as weird. The formula for defense is that damage is halved with each 50 points of defense. So 25 damage on a 0 armor character does about 25 damage, but 25 on a 100 armor character does about 6. A tank would survive 4 times more hits like that. If you hover over the armor, you'll see it's current damage reduction in %. (should be 75% for 100) Are you positive that you were looking at the correct damage type? Else it might have been a bug.

Again, sorry to have bored you, but thank you for trying Renowned Explorers!

39238818.review:
I've sunk more than a few hours into Renowned Explorers, so I fugured it's time to give it a review.
I recently got The Curious Expedition, which is a fairly similar game both in premise and in gameplay, and even though TCE is good, I'd say Renowned Explorers is the better one. Even though the rogue-like mechanics are fairly simple and after a while you start seeing the repetitive formulas in every map, event and quest, Renowned Explorers has just enough flavor and charm to convince you into at least pretending every character on your team is truly unique, every map is a different exotic location and every treasure is a one-of-a-kind priceless artifact, even if you've already seen them all before. TCE doesn't really have that sense of wonder, and after you've figured out the clockwork behind it everything starts to blend together a bit.

The game mechanics in RE have a good balance of complex and simple. 

Characters offer plenty of variety in skills, though over repeated playthroughs you'll probably have developed a set of favorites. Unlocking characters as expedition captains (which grants them an unique bonus) requires beating a few missions with them as regular team members, so it's an incentive to keep trying new combinations in your team in order to get those captain boosts that best fit your play style.

Combat is a straightforward rock-paper-scissors system of punches, insults and compliments, but there's a lot of combinations, buffs (and debuffs) and consequences (both within and outside combat itself) from taking one approach over the other, so a good deal of strategy is needed on the higher difficulty settings.

Exploration is a risk-and-reward guessing game with some fairly basic resource management, but some characters, perks and equipment can tip the balance in your favor. Although each map is more-or-less unique in setting, treasures and plot, the layout itself is randomly generated. Since you can only cover part of the map on each expedition, this means there's always the potential of a secret treasure or challenge you might have missed.

All in all, RE is a pretty great fit for exploration-themed roguelikes. If you enjoy discovering new things, Renowned Explorers should give you plenty of hours of fun for its price tag.

39168285.review:
A charming game full of flavor that also has a surprising amount of depth.

While the core mechanics of the game are relatively simple, the way each part interacts with other parts allows for many different options and strategies. Beyond the three basic styles of combat to focus on (Friendly, Devious, and Aggressive), you have three resources to balance (Gold, Status, Research), and three different ways of obtaining those resources (Challenges, Encounters, and Insight). Finally, you have a whole slew of Equipment, Entourage, and Research to help you improve at doing each of the above.

Initially, the game can be quite challenging. However, once you learn the basic synergies and strategies, you'll find yourself replaying the game to try out different combinations and strategies. With 18 characters (with DLCs) to choose from, there are dozens of different party compositions along with a multitude of paths to advance in the game.

38755648.review:
In the realm of tactical RPGs, RE:I is in a unique place. Aesthetically this is not your typical high fantasy game, but instead you pick a team of 3 individuals to 'explore' various locations, meeting various people and creatures you have to defeat. Second, a full game will last around 3 hours depending on difficulty, and there isn't an emphasis on story like you might see in a game like Banner Saga or Jeanne d'Arc. But it does have its own charm; you can choose between 20 different character with their own personalities and back stories, however superfiscial. There are at times even interactions between different combination of characters. 

Battles themselves are also unique. Every character has 3 different attacks: Physical, Demoralizing, or 'Convincing' for lack of a better term. Either beat them into submission, talk them into submission, or convince them you are agents of good. It doesn't matter in the end; each of these 'attacks' will drain a standard health bar on a given creature, your goal of which is to reduce to zero. How hitting someone on the head with a shovel, and then telling them how awesome they are 'defeats' them is anyone's guess. But it doesn't really matter. The important part is [b]tactically[/b] there are big consequences to choosing one attack over another, even if they all work on the same health (the game calls it 'spirit') bar. In addition to 3 primary attacks, each character will gain 2 special attacks that run the gammut of your typical RPG abilities: Stun, AoE spells, group heals, debuffs, etc. While there is a rock paper scissors mechanic to battles, it can get deeper when you are offered a greater reward for demoralizing them instead of befriending them. Or maybe the enemy is weak against demoralizing, but none of your characters have strong demoralizing attacks.

While most of your gameplay will be ensuring you survive battles, there are 2 other gameplay areas: The Adventure Map, and the Global Map that exists between adventures. On the Adventure Map, your crew moves from point to point trying to gain as much treasure, knowledge, or status as possible. Each time you move to a node you use up food, and as you are limited in the amount of foood you have, it's impossible to cover everything. Each Adventure Map ends in a boss battle before you are sent to the Global Map to reap your rewards.
The Global Map is where you choose how to spend your spoils. Money buys equipment, knowledge unlocks various buffs, and status recruits 'helpers' that buff your party in various ways. While there are 3 different resources, there doesn't feel like there's enough difference between them. 

Renowned Explorers: International Society is good enough. It's probably worth it on sale. It has a lot of charm and interesting enough gameplay for at least a few runs through. With multiple difficulties, Iron Man mode, achievements, and 20 different characters to choose there's a lot of game time to be had; don't let the 3 hour play time mislead you.

38388892.review:
Despite being a big fan of turn-based strategy, I resisted buying this game for a while. Little did I know that I was depriving myself of one of the more fun, clever, and unique titles in the genre. The two misconceptions I had initially were...

1) That the game boiled down to rock, paper, scissors. While this mechanic is present (it works similar to how the Fire Emblem weapon triangle does), it's just one of a whole slew of things going on during the game's many encounters.  There are resistances, weaknesses, buffs and debuffs, character and enemy statuses, various rewards for handling encounters in different ways, and on and on. Once you get your footing and start understanding the game's many systems, combat becomes a real delight: a strategic (and sometimes literal) dance that requires balancing a dozen or more factors to reach a desired outcome.

2) That everything seemed a bit simplistic. Don't let the cartoonish look fool you, Renowned Explorers features great depth on both the strategic and tactical layers. I've played for over 30 hours and only just feel like I'm getting a real strong grasp on advanced gameplay and how to maximize my score. While the fact that a single game only lasts maybe 3-4 hours was initially a disappointment, so much of the joy from the game is playing around with different crew combinations and taking on different challenges that I've come to appreciate that games can be completed briskly. This also makes it palatable to play 'Adventure Mode', which features auto-saving and permadeath.

Generally, I'd recommend ignoring the "Discovery Mode" that allows for save-scumming and lower difficulties and just diving in to Adventure Mode on Classic difficulty, the game's recommended setting. While you'll take your lumps early on, the failures will be quick and you'll get to experiment with a variety of teams. Plus, the first time you succeed will really feel like an accomplishment. And I say this as someone who is generally too much of a wimp to play Ironman in games like XCOM and the like.


Overall, I heartily recommend this for anyone who enjoys turn-based strategy!

38291664.review: Great game, lots of different combinations for your party, the new expansion has a lot of replay value.  Highly reccomended for turn based lovers.

38259983.review:
When was the last time you insulted a sheep into submission? Or complimented a mummy on his wrappings? Or engaged in a battle of charms with a vampire? Unless you’re leading a way more interesting life than the rest of us, or have already played Renowned Explorers, the answer should be never. And that should also be the big reason you ought to play Renowned Explorers, because the battles are nothing like you’ve ever experienced. They’re far more than battles of wits, far more than rock-paper-scissors strategy, and support a game far more charming and entertaining than most adventure jaunts you’ll find.

The Renowned Explorers are a club of intrepid adventurers brought together by a common love of antiquities, danger, and glory. They hold annual competitions to see who can amass the most prestige for themselves, and you just happen to want a piece of that. Assembling a crew with two other like-minded explorers, you embark on a series of five expeditions around the globe to uncover treasures and secrets for the world. If you play your cards right and use every tool at your disposal, you can claim the title of Most Renowned. Otherwise, you’ll leave behind little more than rumors of your last great journey.

At the heart of this title is something of a text adventure. Each of your expeditions sees you leading your crew around to points of interest in whatever region you’ve jaunted off to. At each point you’re given a description of what’s happening, and a load of choices in response. Depending on your decisions you might end up finding a hidden treasure, scoring some gold or research, battling bandits or natives, or pulling yourself out of some other dire predicament. These story snippets are the gears that power everything else in the game, and considering how many systems that covers it can be daunting to figure out how best to approach a simple text prompt.

Your options at each stop are usually presented with a percentage of how likely you are to succeed, which is heavily dependent on your crew, their skills, and other decisions up to that point. Characters are loaded with six different stats, a list of skills across multiple disciplines to learn, and slots for different pieces of equipment. Challenges may call for specific skills, completion of previous encounters, or sometimes just the luck of the draw. Success means scoring tokens which are converted to currencies used to gear up between expeditions, while failure can cost you stat penalties, supplies which are used to traverse the map, or resolve which works as your extra lives in combat. While the text portion of the game generally won’t end a run on its own, it can tee up a defeat in combat with mounting penalties.

Combat isn’t the main focus of the game, but it’s perhaps the most unique element. Encounters play out on familiar hex(ish) maps where you and your foes take turns moving around and using skills. The difference here is that instead of different weapons or attacks, you have three schools of abilities with wildly different effects. Aggressive actions are attacks, devious actions have negative emotional impacts, and friendly actions have positive ones. All of these when used on enemies deplete their spirit, and reducing it to zero defeats the unit. But everyone also has an emotion meter that tracks whether they’re happy or sad, and what specific emotion that puts them in. Furthermore, there’s an overall mood determined by the predominant actions on both sides which can incur huge (like 50% huge) bonuses and penalties depending on how the two teams are feeling.

The interplay between these different approaches affords a wealth of tactical options. Each mood affects attack and speech stats, so a clever player will make their enemy enraged before hitting them to lower their armor, or sadden an enemy that’s about to attack to lower their speech. Items can play a part in this as well, boosting key stats or even giving bonuses when attacking enemies with certain emotions. Really you have enormous control over the approaches your team can take, but to succeed in more difficult areas you have to focus on one or two and stack up your bonuses for it.

The same is true for the resource game, as winning the game requires you to accrue enough renown to beat out the other explorers. Renown is earned from most things you do but there’s a ton of ways to boost your earnings, and ways to focus on a few resources to really pump your results. Gold is used to buy items, status lets you recruit an entourage that provides further bonuses from tokens earned, and research lets you unlock studies that produce all kinds of powerful effects. Choosing how to spend these currencies to build your renown machine is the real meat of the game, and mathematically-minded players may find plenty to chew on here.

With a design this tight there’s not much to critique, aside from seeing the same encounters over and over as you sink more and more time into the game. The variety comes from the different crews you can assemble, and the different choices you make in building them up, but you’ll still end up reading the same passages again and again. It’s an issue the developers seem keenly aware of if the different expansion DLCs are any indication, and there are so many treasures to find and unlock anyway that it shouldn’t be too much of an issue. Wrapped up in such a charming presentation, it’s doubtful you’ll have any bones to pick until at least a dozen or two hours in. The unique strategy and combat may take some getting used to, but once it clicks you’ll have a hard time stopping yourself from launching just one more expedition.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11322459/]curation page[/url]!

38126250.review:
當你想要花少少的時間打一局遊戲，但是卻又想要具備挑戰性、多變性、重玩價值高的要素時，
Renowned Explorers絕對是你的首選！

本遊戲正如其名，玩家的目的就是成為最有聲望的探險家，
探險冒險的遊戲在Steam上並非冷門，那這款遊戲為什麼如此吸引人呢？

[b]A. 遊戲簡介：[/b]
首先，Renowned Explorers是一款回合制，具有可愛風格，探險尋寶架構下的策略遊戲，
玩家的目的就是操作探險家前往世界各地尋寶，並且成為探險家中的佼佼者。
想當然，從「選擇探險家」的介面就讓人頭痛，
所有探險家都有不同的能力：工程師、考古學家、盜賊等，各種職業都會對你的探險帶來不少幫助！
利用選擇的探險家進行總共5輪的探索，每一輪探索都前往不同的地區，有點類似某些桌遊，
而相同的地區的路線完全隨機，並沒有所謂「最速解」，耐玩性也大幅增加。
除此之外還有一些遊戲內的特殊機制，讓我在B部分再做說明！

[b]B. 遊戲特色、機制[/b]
如同前言，遊戲是藉由5輪的探索決定探險家們的成敗，
首先，遊戲內最重要的是探險家的「職業」與「合適情緒」，
職業，遊戲的職業在探索不同地區時，會遭遇「隨機事件」，
每一個事件都有特定數個職業影響解決事件的能力，可能會上升或是下降。想當然，事件圓滿落幕可以獲得更多獎勵，
職業的取捨會讓你的隊伍變化多端，也能在面對各種難題時迎刃而解。

「合適情緒」則是適合戰鬥的模式，遊戲的戰鬥並不複雜，回合制的戰鬥架構下，利用不同情緒的搭配造成對手無力還擊，以獲得勝利。
複雜的是：「情緒」是什麼？
簡單來說，就是隊伍的攻擊模式，分別有「友善」、「侵略」與「迂迴狡詐」，可以先想像成剪刀石頭布就好xD
而在遊戲的戰鬥模式下，你的隊伍主要「情緒」跟對方主要「情緒」會讓戰鬥模式產生「場地魔法」(你以為你在遊戲王喔)
場地魔法會對雙方造成不同的BUFF/DEBUFF，善用情緒可以讓戰鬥更加簡單。
另外，情緒攻擊也會對每個角色造成影響：開心的狀態；難過害怕的狀態......都會讓你的攻擊力/命中率等等有所改變，
要小心注意每個人的狀態！

好，假設各位都順利的通關一個地區，你就會獲得獎勵，獎勵不只是得到名望而已！
這邊先不透露太多，只要知道你的獎勵類似不同的Token，可以幫助你升級科技、購買道具、還有各種研究助手以提升每一輪獎勵，善用他們讓隊伍效益最大化。
你還可以派遣手中的探險家進行各種演講賺取這些Token，就像是個巡迴世界的教授(x

評論處先省略掉許多遊戲內的隨機機制，我認為自己去探索會比較具有樂趣！(不是我懶惰XDDD)

[b]C. DLC?[/b]
目前Renowned Explorers有兩款DLC：More to Explore與The Emperor's challenge
More to Explore應該很好理解：也就是更多的地圖與寶藏更供您探索。
The Emporer's Challenge是較為困難的探險模式，皇帝會給你一些困難[strike]機車[/strike]的任務讓你每輪都要達成，
還會有很多限制，像是不能去某些地區探索！[spoiler]皇帝的要求真的很煩躁[/spoiler]
如果想要挑戰自己、增加遊戲耐玩程度的玩家，非常建議兩者都購買。

[b]D. 小小心得[/b]
其實寫到這邊我發現還有超多超多的要素可以說明：營火模式、探險的注意事項我都沒有特別提及。
或許留下一些空間給各位去發掘可能比我說明更加迅速吧！
這款遊戲的一輪時間很短，但是重玩價值超級高，即使你可能要打完3-5場才會知道這個遊戲的運作模式，
但是下一輪你的隊伍特性又不同了，所以相同的策略不能場場沿用。
遊戲也有部分成就是建立在「無悔模式」，就算是SL大法也幫不上你XD，
好處是，這款遊戲對新手非常友善，遊戲內的教學也很完整，我想是不必害怕面對困難重重的挫折感。
如果你每天下班後都想要來一場遊戲內容、隊伍都不同的嶄新冒險，
Renowned Explorers絕對具有看過但是不能錯過的價值！

[b]E. 評分[/b]
畫面：9/10(可愛的畫風，男女老少絕對OK!)
音樂：8/10
遊戲性：9/10(好上手，困難模式成就感十足)
耐玩性：9.5/10(如果太狂熱的話也會跟很多精神時光屋一樣造成睡眠障礙)

小小的Murmur：我好希望有多人模式，這樣就能去挖朋友的大祕寶了(?)

37864074.review:
A very charming rogue-like that melds the push-your-luck gameplay with an original turn based combat system that uses "emotions" as abilities, where moods dictate the flow of the battle. All encompassed under the umbrella of a fantastic exploration theme.
Different party configurations lead to different "story" moments within the expedition and the colorful cast of characters, their personalities and abilities, add to the replay value of the game. No two expeditions are the same. And while they are indeed perilous, the difficulty can be tweaked to your liking:
The Adventure Mode is the recommended way to play the game. Fail an expedition and you are done! The game saves at specific points and when you quit.
There is also a Discovery Mode that pretty much removes the rogue-like aspects. You are able to save whenever you want and are free to retry any failed expeditions and battles lost. This is useful if you just want to learn the stories behind the characters and wish to avoid wasted time if something goes bust. Do note that luck and percentages play a part in the outcomes so be wary! If randomness irks you in videogames, this mode might ease the pain.
In addition, both modes include four difficulty settings that affect turn-based battles and the skill checks of the challenges/trials that you face. They range from Easy to Impossible.
With or without the DLCs (though I recommend both of them), the game encourages multiple runs. Kudos to Abbey Games for constantly adding content patches that enrich this little gem. Highly recommended!

37851134.review: I was honestly suprised at this game. I had never played a choice driven exploration game proir to this and I have to say I found this to be really enjoyable. This game has alot of replay value as you can select many talents between playthroughs based on who your group of explorers are. You can be agressive, devious, or friendly to make your way as an explorer. Each method can be the best or the worst based on the group you have and where you are. There is never a right or a wrong way to explore, only a successful or unsuccessful adventure. I would recommend this game to anyone looking for some light hearted choice driven adventures. Good game for kids in my opinion as well 7+ish years old

I strongly recommend this game.

It's a party-based exploration game with a very unique feel. From the art design to the way your team deals with groups of natives to the vast array of character skills and development paths, this game has a lot going for it. Challenging enough for adults but accessible and appropriate for kids, this game is a great addition to any library.

Whether you're resolveng encounters through a rock-paper-scissors approach which emphasizes non-violent conflict resolution or choosing what skills your characters develop while knowing that each choice can open up some new discoveries and make others all but impossible, this game has a lot of elements that keep you coming back for one expedition after another.

The game isn't bad and certainly entertaining, but it's a bit disappointing.

The combat mechanic is definitely interesting and adds an interesting spin to standard turn based tactics.

There's a good amount of variety for characters you can pick but other than that the replayability is a bit lacking.

If you're into roguelikes and you set it to the hardest difficulty you may be able to get more enjoyment out of it but if you play on the more casual of the two types, and play on normal difficulty instead of hard the game is pretty easy. 

In general the procedule aspect of it seems a bit lacking, either that or I just had two similar seeds back to back.  From what  I can tell there are only a few islands/locations you can travel to as part of your exploration. Once you're there the different zones are a little randomized in terms of which nodes are connected. But overall the type of mobs your fighting seem to be the same. I went to one of the islands in both my playthroughs and in both cases they had bandits and monkeys you would fight on the island. And in the middle of the island was the same giant gorilla "mini-boss" 

I got around 6 hours out of it for $10 which isn't the worst, I may play it one or two more times but overall it doesn't seem like there's enough of a randomness between playthroughs.

Renowned Explorers: International Society is a fun game of pulp adventure that has light strategy and rouge-like elements to it. It's easy to learn, and accessable at all difficulty levels. The characters and environments are highly stylized and very esthetically pleasing. Each of the MANY characters has their own unique personality that matched their disign and creatues unique and meaningful playstyles, allowing for ridiculous amounts or replayability. All in all, there are good times to be had in this game.

36873064.review: When I play Renowned Explorers, I tend to get into obsessive sessions with it, especially when attempting the weekly challenges (another great way to enjoy the game if you go on the discussions page). I've played for so long, and yet I also feel like I've just barely scratched the surface. You can play just to enjoy the exploration, the feeling of going on a new expedition and the wonder and surprise when you see something new, or you can go the competitive route and try going for a high score, testing out all of the different strategies to do so. I've enjoyed the game in both respects, and the devs have done great work at patching the game to better both types of players' experience. There are two DLCs that add a lot to the game for a great price, but aren't at all required, and if you're like me, you can milk the game for a lot of hours at a fairly low price, and I'm still not done.

36849232.review:
You would be hard pressed to find a game that has more love put into it than this. Renowned Explorers is a Rogue-Like placed in the 19 century where you explore distant lands to explore and gather treasures from. Not only does it manage to be a fantastic Rogue-Like, but it also has great character personalitys and humor within it.

You will start out wondering what to do and how everything works, but it won't ward you off with anything that's too hard to gain a grasp of. No matter your skill level, everyone can enjoy this game in equal measure. You'll gain a sense of pride as you see your end-game score getting higher and higher as you continue to improve, learn, and make your own strategies.

As I said earlier, the characters within the game are the delicious side to this savory steak. All character have unique personalitys (including backstorys on the title screen) that you will grow fond. No 2 characters are alike here in this wacky but lovable group of Renowned Explorers. They are even given unique voices and animations for their attacks that just adds even more likeability. Even the side-characters and areas you explore are easy to adore.

This is one of the greatest games of all time in my opinion, and to top it all off, the community is incredibly welcoming and kind. If you are atall interested in this game, I implore you to take a chance on it and fall in love with the craft and detail of it all.

36787164.review:
Nach über 200 Stunden Spielzeit kann ich dieses Spiel nur wärmstens empfehlen.
Das Grundgerüst des Spiels erinnert mich an eine Art Brettspiel nur eben im Gewand eines Compuertspiels. Zu Anfang wählt man sein Team bei dem es mit 20+ einzigartigen Charakteren genug Auswahl gibt um verschiedene Strategien verfolgen zu können. Mit diesem Team versucht man nun auf einer Expedition möglichst viele Token/Ressourcen zu erringen, um mit diesen dann Verbesserungen freizuschalten (Forschungen, Spezialisten, Helfer, Items) und damit dann wiederum auf der nächsten Expedition noch mehr Token/Ressourcen zu verdienen.

Zu erwähnen ist natürlich, dass der Glücksfaktor in diesem Spiel eine entscheidende Rolle spielt. Die Chance die verschiedenen Aufgaben zu bestehen lässt sich zwar duch das Verbessern der Fähigkeiten der einzelnen Crewmitglieder  positiv beeinflussen. Dennoch gibt es immer wieder diesen frustrierenden Moment, wenn die 98% Chance fehl schlägt und man ohne Artefakt weiterziehen muss. Würde allerdings alles immer nur nach Plan laufen wär's stellenweise wohl zu leicht. Der Mix aus rundenbasierten Kämpfen und den glücksabhängigen Aufgaben stellen meiner Meinung nach einen guten Ausgleich dar.

Mir gefällt an dem Spiel, dass es sich selbst nicht zu ernst nimmt und mich immer wieder zum Schmunzeln bringt. Seien es die Geschichten der Charaktere und ihr Verhalten untereinander oder auch allein schon die Tatsache, dass man die Gegner dadurch besiegen kann, dass man sie zum Weinen oder Lachen bringt. Die Grafik ist zudem in einem passenden und optisch gut anzusehenden Cartoon-Stil gehalten. Einzig die Laute, die die verschiedenen Charaktere während der Kämpfe von sich geben, empfinde ich persönlich nicht so gelungen.

[b]Positives:[/b]
[list]
[*] große Auswahl an verschiedensten Charakteren für eine hohe Variation bei der Crewbildung
[*] guter Mix aus Rundenstrategie und Glücksfaktor
[*] Strategie auf mehreren Ebenen (Crewbildung, Kartenerkundung, Kämpfe, Ressourcen)
[*] humorvoll gehalten
[*] netter Cartoon-Grafikstil
[*] jeder Durchlauf des Spiels ist anders
[/list]
[b]Negatives:[/b]
[*] die Sounds der Charaktere sind nicht so gelungen
[*] zum Teil kann der Glücksfaktor an wichtigen Stellen frustrierend sein
[*] kein Multiplayer
[/list]

[b]Fazit:[/b]
Dieses Spiel hält mich dadurch an der Stange, dass ich die Expeditionen mit allen nur möglichen Teams bestehen will. Und ich will sie nicht nur eben so schaffen, sondern zudem auch noch mit einer möglichst guten Punktzahl. Es macht auch einfach unheimlich viel Freude viele viele Tokens einzusammeln und diese dann am Ende der Expedition ausgewertet zu bekommen. Für alle Freunde von Rundenstrategie oder von Brettspielen oder von Rogue-Likes einfach nur zu empfehlen!

36684177.review:
Wasn't completely sure if this game would be something for me, so I bought it on sale. Have to say, never thought it being so addictive. Easy to understand, not as easy to master. And although there are generally only 15 different expeditions (of which you have to finish 5 to win the game) the developers added so many features to allow for a great replayability. E.g.:

- 24 explorer characters with different pros and cons allows for a huge amount of different possible explorer teams of 3 characters; even more considering the different captain perks of each character
- all expeditions are shuffled with every playthrough, i.e. map design is random; also some events/actions as well as trophies could be exchanged
- literally hundreds of different possibilities for character trainings, power-ups and entourage/helpers
- with DLC "Emperor's Challenge" the game offers additional daily and weekly challenges
- campfire stories introduce evolving character relationships and additional character buffs

This was well invested money and I can only recommend this game.

36603305.review: Эта игра целиком и полностью про гринд-геймплей. Соответственно, стоит ли вам ее брать или нет, зависит от того, достаточно ли вам одного только геймплея или нет. Здесь отсутствует сюжет, у персонажей номинальная индивидуальность, всё повторяется: вы посещаете одни и те же места, участвуете в одних и тех же челленджах, снова и снова развиваете свою базу с нуля, - и оправдывают это долгосрочные цели, такие как постепенное обретение всех доступных в игре сокровищ или прокачка десятков персонажей до ранга лидера. Режим аддона The Emperor's Challenge привносит соревновательный азарт, которого не хватает базовой версии RE, где вы противостоите только нехватке ресурсов и собственным неудачным решениям. С ним игра становится значительно веселее, рекомендую брать его с игрой сразу вместе. В целом же, на мой взгляд, RE слишком скучная, рутинная и повторяющаяся. Она больше подходит для мобильных устройств.

36586479.review: Renowned Explorers: International Society is mostly a turn-based combat Adventure with almost no main or sub plots, you just explore different islands or historical sites and find treasures to reach your goal and that's it, so it is not strictly an RPG because there is not much story. The combat is like the rock-paper-scissors thing where one kind of attack defeats the other, so you actually  have far less choices  than you think to how you want to tackle the situation regardless of your team's strength, which is a very bad thing. It has a lot of different skill rolls to see wether you can successfully complete a random task or not and the prize is either money, fame, or research points, and one of those 3 thing will be used to calculate your total expeditions point called Renown. You win the game with high enough Renown point. This game is awfully childish, the writing, the encounter, the dialogue, awful.I can actually see how this game be a very educational game for younger players, maybe to learn different english words. And the developers, while they are not as imaginative and original as they think they are, is actually a bunch of people full of passion and dreams, but still. you should buy this game only if these two criteria is fulfilled first:First, you have to be very young, most preferably not older than 15 year-old. I am not saying that older men cannot enjoy this game, it is just this game is quite childish, and I am a 34 yo Asian male from a developing country, so I know that my childish might not be your childish(i doubted that), please judge this accordingly. Second, if you decide to buy this, do not buy the whole thing including the DLCs like I did. I bought it all and found out the game is too childish to my liking so I never played the DLC at all. Buy the base game, play it for more than 5 hours(this is very important, you must play it for sufficient amount of time) and then buy the DLC if you still find the game enjoyable.
36586479.developer_response: Hey there! Sorry to hear Renowned Explorers turned out to be too childish for your taste, Bunny the Fluff. Different tastes I guess, as you mentioned in your review. :) Thanks for trying out Renowned Explorers for such a lengthy time though!

36376785.review:
Знаете, пожалуй что Renowned Explorers: International Society входит в тройку моих любимых представителей жанра rogue-light в принципе. Ну, как минимум, больше всего времени я провел именно в трех образчиках жанра: FTL, Darkest Dungeon и Renowned Explorers. Что удивительно, я даже осмелюсь сказать, что эта игра стоила всех тех танцев с бубном, которые понадобились, дабы запустить ее на моей кривой, не обновляющейся системе - но это отдельная, не заслуживающая особого внимания тема. Суть в том, что это один из самых увлекательных, так сказать, "генераторов уникальных историй", что мне доводилось видеть, имеющий, ко всему прочему, множество занимательных и по-своему необычных механик.

Основная тема этой игры, как можно догадаться из названия: приключения разношерстной команды исследователей и поиск сокровищ - все это в декорациях условного девятнадцатого века, преисполненных отсылок и пародий на самые разные культурные произведения, в основном приключенческого жанра. Общая концепция заключается в том, что, руководя командой из выбранных в самом начале трех бравых исследователей (на выбор представлено немало колоритных личностей), совершить несколько экспедиций, добывая сокровища, артефакты и сопутствующие ресурсы, и все для того, чтобы по истечении заданного лимита экспедиций обогнать всех конкурентов по заработанному престижу. По крайней мере, таковым является классический режим игры - адд-он добавил и альтернативный режим челленджей, если кто-то пресытится основной концепцией. Другой адд-он, кстати, добавляет отношения внутри команды и личные квесты персонажей - схематично, но все же достаточно, чтобы еще немного оживить историю.

Очень необычная боевка, интересный подбор команды с их характерами, навыками и способностями, хорошая система прогресса между экспедициями, предусматривающая множество различных путей к успеху, сами экспедиции, где каждый раз с вами происходит что-то новое, обилие интересных событий, квестов и столкновений, как занимательных в плане решения, так и попросту запоминающихся в плане разыгрываемых ситуаций, а также - некоторая порция отсылок и пародий на приключенческо-исследовательский жанр. Я люблю вещицы, которые позволяют наблюдать, как руками игрока формируется новая уникальная и при этом занятная история. Как пелось в одной из самых приставучих заставок всех времен: To learn a mystery or rewrite history (очень актуально, пожалуй, на фоне успешно стартовавшего ребута Duck Tales). И в этом плане Renowned Explorers демонстрируют себя как отличнейший образчик жанра. По крайней мере, львиная доля веселья в этой игре держится именно что на исследованиях, так что уж название свое она точно оправдывает.

Полный обзор - https://malavon.dreamwidth.org/640.html

36209469.review:
If you love Rogue-Likes --- You'll love this.

36158159.review:
Short version: Highly recommend this as a fun, tactical/strategic RPG. Cartoony artstyle, quirky humour and some really interesting and unique mechanics for the turn-based combat. High replay value.


Long version: At first glance Renowned Explorers seems a decent, light-hearted, strategic rogue-like game involving turn-based tactical fights. The more you play however, the more you notice and appreciate all the different layers of the game design and mechanics there are, that when put all together make for a much deeper game than it may first appear.

You select a  team of 3 explorers, from a large roster of characters from 4 different classes. Each character has different perks/abilities and they each have a different bonus when selected as captain, which gives them all a different playstyle and they all have different synergies with other team members.

You take your selected team to 5 different expedition locations, which you pick from a growing list of options and move across randomly generated maps, resolving encounters with skill checks from party members or in tactical, turn-based fights. 
The combat involves a unique "mood" mechanic, where abilities/attacks used affect whether your team is Aggressive, Friendly or Devious and the same applies to the enemy. This creates a shifting rock-paper-scissors game, where one mood will be advantageous giving a buff or a debuff, but use of another ability may shift the mood to a different buff/status. Additionally individual units have emotions such as Excited, Enraged, Saddened, etc that add extra buffs/debuffs.

Enemies have different weaknesses and resistances to various emotions and some react differently to changing moods as well. The amount of interplay between skills, emotions, moods and positioning/attacks all adds up to interesting gameplay with a lot more depth than the cheery cartoon artstyle may hint at.

Once you get used to the gameplay, a full run only takes a few hours, but the RNG nature of the map layouts and loot placement, as well as the large roster and combinations of team members, perks, items, skill bonuses, etc gives a huge amount of replayability. The developer support is great as well, with new daily and weekly challenges rotated in, which gives incentive to try out new team compositions/strategies than you may be used to.

A note on the RNG for skill checks throughout the game - the breakdown of whether or not a roll will succeed in the game is excellent. It shows you what your chance is, what the skill check is based on, as well as the contributing factors from character skills, items, buffs, etc are, so if you want to boost your chances/eliminate RNG you are given the information to do so. 

Overall, an excellent game with some great and innovative design choices and mechanics. Great replayabilty and definitely recommended.

A ground breaking game in which brute force is not the only and may not  the best way to win a battle. I give it an unequivocal thumbs up, but that's not to say it is perfect or the formula could not be improved, thus my Pros & Cons are as follows.

Pro: The game is set in a  cartoonish Victorian world before everything was discovered (and subsequently 3d mapped by Google) where Explorers with big personalities and bigger egos still scoured the earth for fame and plunder.
Con: The game is set in a cartoonish Victorian world that makes exploitation of indigenous  peoples  seem like a fun and harmless pastime. Personally, I  take the game with a huge grain of salt. If the developers had made the 19th century explorers politicaly correct to appeal to 21st century senibilities , how historically relevant would that be? ...Not very.

PRO: There is a good deal of depth to the strategy and economy of RE. Things that are fuzzy at first will become clearer the more you play and you begin to see the logic of it all.  
CON: The game is more complicated in my opinion than it needs to be. The number of commodities, tolkiens  and  systems will make your head spin.  For instance a Jouralist in your entourage will not join your expedition but works behind the scenes to give you positive  press. Cool idea but the journalist has no personality being just an icon that gives you a bonus and the entourage  system is way too convoluted. I think it would be be better if members of your entourage would show up occasionally, like a camp followers, on the battle screen, and give you aid.

35918236.review:
Imagine que você e seus amigos resolvam montar uma mesa de RPG de aventura com base em "Indiana Jones" e "Tomb Raider". Este jogo é o resultado disto.

Com mecânicas de um rpg por turno, roguelite, você controla uma equipe de três aventureiros com o objetivo de serem reconhecidos globalmente, seja pelos seus tesouros, pela pura e simplesmente fama, ou pelo progresso científico.


Ao começar o jogo, você escolhe os personagens da sua party, sendo um deles seu capitão. A variedade de personagens, lore de cada um [o background deles], habilidades e formas de combate é imensa, podendo assim criar sempre novas e interessantes aventuras. Há personagens mais amigáveis, outros mais antisociais, outros na base da pancadaria, outros mais asquerosos [que gostam de humilhar o oponente], outros que vão fazer tudo pela ciência, outros que querem conhecer novos povos, e outros que querem apenas a aventura em si, enfim, são personagens ricos e com um bom background histórico; a construção do personagem é VOCÊ que decide.

Na parte de combates, você pode resolver de modo diplomático, por combate [luta mesmo] ou humilhando seu adversário verbalmente. É um sistema interessante e fãs de "Undertale" certamente irão gostar deste jogo.

Na parte do RPG, a cada movimento há uma aventura a ser resolvida, com histórias muito boas e envolventes, umas dando enfoque ao relacionamento entre seus personagens, outras com enfoque na ciência, busca pelo tesouro, combate ou sociologia.

Os gráficos são em 2D, e eu gostei bastante da direção de arte do jogo, na rirqueza dos cenários e na variedade de inimigos e em países.

A dificuldade do jogo é alta por ser um roguelite, ele não é 100% procedual, mas é nítido que a cada jogo haverá mapas novos a serem descobertos.  A trilha do jogo é boa, porém acaba sendo enjoativa depois de um tempo, faltou diversidade musical. Não testemunhei bugs, só raros crashes do jogo.

Nota: 8,8/10

35904132.review:
This game has a pretty fun and rather unique approach to combat stages: you can fight your way out of them, sure... But you can also resolve matters in a friendly way, or break the spirit of those opposing you with mockery and intimidating words. Each style – peaceful, agressive, and mocking – work like a "weapon triangle", meaning one of them is weak against another one and strong against the other. By resolving more and more conflicts in a certian manner you get more "inclined" to this style which starts giving you bonuses for resolving conflicts "your way".

On adventurer mode, you can generally afford to "lose" your teammates twice per expedition until it's game over, so you have to be careful and cunning with your tactics and decisions. It's a good thing you don't actually need to reset because the game prompts you to do so anyway, which is might be a minor thing, but is still a very nice minor thing. Classic mode is absolutely brutal: once your part loses all of its resolve, it's over for you – forever. Resources you have to carry out expeditions are also limited, and you get penalties when you run out of them, so you have to plan where you go around the mission level in a careful manner. Boss fights could prove to be quite challenging, especially when you have debuffs and AOE-casting mobs keep swarming your party. While the stage design is nothing to write home about, some of the stages have classic choking points and "healing tiles" that can end up being your downfall.
The places you explore, aka expeditions – as they're called in the game – are all very varied, with their unique setting, opposing forces you confront, and local mini-plots. I especially liked the expedition to this Peruan-looking place where my explorers ended up finding an ancient treasure, banishing a necromant girl and overthrowing the government, all in one fell swoop. 
There are also RNG challenges that utilize your team's traits: diplomatic, athletic, archeologist, etc. Those traits aren't only used to pass skill checks, but also offer some combat bonuses. Some of those skill checks are simple events, some of them are a series of skill checks. It's important to know your team's traits and keep an eye on opportunities to enhance them, as leveling characters doesn't have an effect on that area, but on their skills in skirmishes only.

There's plenty of characters to chose from and teams to form; some of the character combos even unlock some sort of short story snippets and give those characters some kind of bonus. All characters have a preference for two ways of resolving combat situations, so it's important to make a team with the same dynamic, as well a teammate who's efficient at "healing" in critical situations. Interestingly enough, you can also neglect "healing" completely and go for an all-out agressive playstyle – there are plenty of variety to the character roster to be able to pull that off. 
There's a simple overarching story about how you're supposed to beat this Disney's Lady and the Beast Gaston-lookalike for... Uh... Fame, I guess, and you sometimes confront his goons on some of the expeditions as well. I'm pretty sure the story part might as well not exist because it's just so meaningless, and it's definitely not the game's strong point.

Overall, gameplay is top-notch and is surprisingly challenging. Exploring different places the world has to offer that all look so varied and unique is also a blast. Trying out different playstyles and party combinations helps a lot with the game's replayability. The fact that the soundtrack sounds very boring and uninspired and the overall plot feels kind of random don't really do much damage to my impression of how good this game is.

35828468.review:
Oh where to begin... This game is such a hidden gem in the sea of indie games. You form a party of 3 characters with different backgrounds and specialties from all over the world. Your goal is to surpass Rivaleux and become the most Famous Explorer in the world which you do by gaining Renown. The game consists of three segments: exploration, combat and the world map.

On the World Map you can set the location of your expedition, spend Insight(which you earn through expeditions) to get resources, hire helpers or specialists to help you on your journey, do research to benefit your party and buy trinkets to boost your power. All the tokens you get and the treasures you find also give you Renown. After you are done managing, you are off to find secrets and treasures on your adventure.

When you start your expedition, you start to explore the island, each tile using supplies. Exploration is fun and intriguing; forcing you to make decisions depending on your overall goal, the side goal and your supplies. On most tiles you will get events. The stories and the writing is engaging and the decisions you make will reward you with tokens -which you can use on the world map- and treasures -which give you Insight and other rewards of your choice-. Another positive is that although the game is still random, the randomness is reduced by how you build your party. Such as a "Diplomat" having the chance to persuade your enemies. But during most cases you won't be able to escape from the encounter and that brings us to combat.

The combat is very unique in which you can not only win aggressively but also by talking things out or mocking your enemies. Your approach, combined with your enemies' approach will determine the mood of the battle such as Tense, Friendly or Brutal. These moods give your party buffs or debuffs depending on the rock, paper, scissors-like combat triangle. You will also get different tokens depending on the way you solve the situation, some events even play out differently if you get through them in a specific way.

All in all a fascinating game that hooked me like no other did recently.

35821388.review: This game felt a little werid my first few plays.  Combat is a rock, paper, scissors of compliments, insults, and physical attacks...kinda werid..but it works!  Once you understand the combat strategy the game becomes really enjoyable.  By my 4th run I was loving it.

35780579.review:
Renowned Explorers is a turn-based strategy game set in the 19th century. You take control of 3 explorers, 1 captain and 2 crewmates to go on a handful of explorations to earn prestige and treasures.

You are a group of 3 persons, Each character have their Stats and Alignment that will help you in getting all kind of treasures and out of battles and net you more bonuses. Different team captains have different super powers, and so, each game with a different captain usually require different strategy and even different playstyle. Sometimes you will fight for the treasure, other treasures you need a certain ability to gain it and/or improve your chances of obtaining said treasures.

On the World Map you may choose a handful of expeditions that open up each time you venture forth and from there you may take any number of paths you choose to get to the treasure and boss. Paths are the same but each tile you land on may have different discoveries, positive/negative effects, and/or currency.

Combat in this game is done by a simple Rock/Paper/Scissors style. You will have either Aggressive/Friendly/Devious, each having a weakness and a effective counter.

The game keeps a fairly lighthearted and humorous theme throughout, which is aided by its bright and colorful art style. Don't let this fool you however - there is a surprising amount of depth to be found in the games combat and exploration systems. 

Pros:
+ Turn based combat
+ Large variety of enemies and encounterable NPCs
+ Loads of characters to choose from, each with unique abilities and captain perks. Makes for a huge diversity of playstyle variations
+ Large amount of replayability, though the gameplay doesn't vary so much after about 100+ hours
+ You need to replay many games to unlock all treasures and Abilities for all characters
+ You can save your progress, so if you ruin in some point you can Load it. Unless you prefer to go hardcore (Adventure Mode) where progress is saved automatically and you can't revert to previous save states
+ 4 difficulty settings for the game 
+ Great for all ages


Cons:
- Only around 8 maps and locations you can go
- Eventually the replayability slows unless you have a leaderboard mission to top the charts
- Can be frustrating


TL;DR:
8/10
Turn-based Rock/Paper/Scissor treasure finding strategy/adventure game with a large variety of unique, lighthearted humorous characters and simple animations.

35751562.review:
I really liked the game, it's a non-violent turn based strategy/exploration game.  You use a combination of compliments, insults, and other dynamics (or just kill them).  I would definitely recommend playing it.  You explore maps, and then have movement based combat where you try to deal with enemies, or just locals who you have to use diplomacy with.  It was really a cool game to play.  The art is nice too, good animation and coloring, etc.

However, I just wanted to give a heads up to the developers about two things that made me quit playing early that hopefully they could remedy for the sequel (because I would buy a sequel if these two were smoothed out):

1)  You are discouraged from exploring each part of the map because you run out of supplies much too easily.  As a title with exploration in the name, I like exploring, but I missed out on little bits and felt I had to rush to the end.  At least give some option to customize your explorers easily so that playstyle is a viable option (not just an option, but viable).  Hand of Fate the game had a mechanic where you could explore every tile and be rewarded for it (exploring).

2)  The campaign (I believe) was just a hard race to the end and if you got behind too much, you would still be playing to the end but you would have really lost about halfway through (I'm not sure if I'm explaining that correctly).  Especially when you are learning, it feels tedious to be exploring mechanics (because you are learning the game) and then know that you're going to have to start over just because you weren't playing the "right way," for instance, exploring a lot.  For instance, instead of a hard fail, perhaps do gradations.  For instance, in some games, instead of a hard countdown to failure (it's effectively a countdown in this game), SteamWorld Heist has security levels, where the longer you spend in the level (and not every level, only some), more and more turrets show up to make it harder to escape the level alive.  This way, people can explore, and even give themselves a challenge, without a hard fail.

Hopefully there's a sequel, it was a very cool mechanically funny and interesting game!  I know I wrote a lot about my two biggest pet peaves, and didn't write enough about the good parts, but it's only because I want to buy the sequel and have the sequel be even better than the first!  Great job!

Yvonne had misgivings, though, because I'd stolen a mask and she felt bad about it. When we reached the overly friendly village, this time we dazzled and praised them until the grumpy chieftain gave us a treasure to go away. 35408478.review:
This game is good, very good.

To start of this game is about exploration. Each game consists of 5 expeditions. After each expedition you can buy, research, expand entourage and a handful of other things to boost your expedition. 

Its also a RPG, you must select 3 predefined characters to go out and explore with 1 being the captain who has his own set of cpt attributes. Your characters gain skill, interact among themselves and the world they explore.  

The gameworld is cartoon style with a good sense of humor in it. Expect to be laughed at by hyenas, spitted by Lamas or teased by  monkies to name a few.

Combat is not all about physical. You can play agressive friendly or devious. Then there is the overall mood of the battle and charachter moods to keep an eye on. This mood system gives bonuses or weaknes and has a big impact on the outcome. It does take time to get familiar with.

The reason why this game is good: its so deep and rich of stategy features its a real challenge to play. Constantly the game challenges you to make decisions and without proper planning you will fail, a lot.  But, This is one of the few games where failing is not a bad experience. 35030628.review:
A tactical RPG/adventure/strategy game with roguelite elements where you don't have to kill anyone - and they can actually kill you with kindness too. It's a real thing.

Renowned Explorers is in the same vein as FTL for general structure. You go on adventures, choose what course of action to take based on each situation, and get urged toward the ever present end of the game by a timer (in this case, supplies) counting down a punishing you severely for milling around in search of goodies too much - and these adventures are periodically broken up with combat. And if you lose, you start over from scratch in rogue-lite fashion (unless you're playing on the easier adventure mode). That's about where the similarities end. 

Renowned Explorers combat is tile-based tactics-RPG style battles that feature a roshambo style "mood" system. Characters can use either weapons or words to do battle, and depending on how they use either, the general attitude of the combat can shift to be friendly, deceptive, or aggressive (read: actual fighting.) So, yes, you can actually befriend every enemy you come across instead of shooting them in the face. Or call them mean names until they're too depressed to continue fighting. You monster. But you might not want to stick explicitly to one strategy, because your approach also changes the prizes that come with a successful battle. There's a lot more complexity to it that I really can't touch on in a brief review, but the whole battle system works strangely well.

If you're someone who enjoys adventure roguelites like FTL and Convoy, I implore you to give Renowned Explorers a try - it might just be your new favourite. Or if you want a somewhat chill RPG experience, it's good for that too.

34789758.review:
Don't let the cartoony graphics fool you, this is one of the most compelling adventure/strategy games I've ever played, and I've been at for 35 years now!

I got a good fifty hours of joy just out of playing through the game, without too much mix/maxing or stressing about the finer points of the systems. Then another 50 hours working out those systems and starting to actually game the game.

Now I'm getting more value out of the thing by actually planning, in detail, my expeditions before I run them. This approach reveals the sheer genius behind the game design and exquisite balancing. 

For each expedition, you're trying to work out a sweet spot between (a) your choice of three characters (from a menagerie of 24 total), (b) your expedition pathway - five expeditions per game, selected from 14 expedition locations, (c) your character upgrade pathways; (d) your campfire chats; (e) your approach to encounters - aggressive? devious? friendly"; (f) the items you are intending to prioritise getting, and what bonuses to pull off them; (g) your town-building options (research pathway and entourage). 

Sorting out the interactions among all of these interrelated systems is loads of fun. You always have to make some compromises, you can never quite cover all the skill bases you'd like. Basically you're trying to set up a snowball of resources that continues to build throughout the game... sometimes the snowball grows way faster than you imagined it, other times it seems to just run flat. 

The joy of discovering an unusual approach to all of the above - it's just immensely rewarding. I only just managed to finally get a score of over 10,000 - which is sort of the ultimate accomplishment in the game. Now I find out reading on the forums that scores of over 17,000 are possible - so clearly I still have a long way to go building a better snowball! 

Aside from the strategising, the game is wonderfully atmospheric. The cartoon graphics have grown on me a lot, they are full of personality and I can only congratulate the character designers (text and graphics) for creating 24 highly evocative mini-characters with just a few strokes of the pen, and a few sentences of text.

Any cons? Not many... I have encountered some glitches, and the game crashes on me about one session out of 20. Some of the encounters are a bit too vague and could use some more imaginative drafting. That's all I can think of!

I can only recommend this game in the highest of terms for anybody who enjoys strategy, puzzles, and adventure games, and who appreciates a game that can be played quickly, but can also be meticulously planned for a deeper experience. 

Oh, and you have to be happy with randomness! If RNG makes you aggro, seek elsewhere. A "wheel of fortune" is an essential part of this game's mechanics!

34537594.review:
This game is nonstop charm. It's like if FTL, XCOM, and a mid-90s PBS edutainment cartoon had a baby. The visuals are cohesive, bright, and fun. The characters and writing are all cheeky and well done. The gameplay itself is pretty straightforward to pick up, yet has a suprising amount of depth. There are a dizzying amount of branching paths that the game can take every time you replay it, while managing to mostly avoid the feeling of RNG unfairness that procedurally generated roguelikes can--especially since most variation is based on choices you made.

Can't recommend highly enough. Goofy fun on the easier difficulty levels (especially as you see each area and the zillions of unique challenges/encounters for the first time), complex and interesting later on as you use what you know to craft specific strategies tailored to following a particular path. The Emperor's Challenge adds a whole new dimension, as you can get thrown repeated curveballs that can shake up your strategy and keep the game from falling into the rut of "find winning strategy, put it together to win every time." 

Great little game. Deserves more attention.

This is not a "endless sandbox" type of game as you will only be able to complete a few missions before your time is up and it's time to vote on the greatest explorer. 34382675.review:
I held off on reviewing this game for the longest while. I found myself just playing Renowned Explorers only every now and again. Over time I realized I kept coming back to Renowned Explorers. An expedition or two every Saturday or Sunday morning. Drinking coffee and deciding where to go and who to bring. Stumbling into crazy encounters against spitting llamas and evil crabs. Insulting a giant ape, being friendly with the sheep, storming a nunnery... Watching my quirky crew growing closer over campfire stories or more often then not creating strong rivalries instead. Trying to figure out which resources to gather and how to spend them. Balancing my agressive actions with devious takedowns to maintain the mood. 

All of these things are different everytime you play depending on the choices you make. Even trying to repeat a playthrough, with the same crew. as closely as you can recall is different. It's such a well done rogue-like. And it only gets clear how much content there is and divergence once you start trying different things. 

It seems cartoony and childish at first glance, but there is so much to learn to improve your game. It was frustrating at first, me being a person not to play below classic difficulty and I love how rouge-like adventure mode is (defeat means game over). But, learning how to play has been half of the enjoyment.

In all honesty this is by far the best indie game I hav ever played. I can only hope there will be continued support from the devs and possibly more very well done DLC. Very much recommend both DLCs, especially More to Explore.

34336058.review: Ich bin sauer, dass ich dieses Spiel nicht früher gekauft habe. Ich hatte mal vor längerer Zeit auf dem Schirm, habe es leider aber vergessen. Das Spiel ist unterhaltsam hat einen sehr guten Humor, ist exzellent geschrieben und hat einen sehr ästehtischen Look. Sinn des Spiel ist es eine Gruppe aus drei Entdeckern zusammenzustellen, welche zur erfolgreichesten Entdeckergruppe innerhalb von 5 Missionen aufsteigen wollen. Auf jedem Abenteuer gibt es verschiedene Routen und Events die man einschlagen kann in der Hinsicht ähnelt es FTL, wobei man in diesem Spiel besser planen kann, da die Wegpunkte ungefähr beschreiben, was einem in dem besagten Gebiet erwartet. Des weiteren ist das Spiel aber ein rundenbasiertes Strategiespiel. Hierbei entscheidet man wie man vorgeht, ob man den Gegner physisch oder psychisch besiegen möchte, je nach dem wie man Kampf gegen den Gegner führt kann das bestimmte Vor- und Nachteile haben. Die nächsten Playthroughs spiele ich im höheren Schwierigkeitsgrad und mit einer völlig neuen Gruppe. Es gibt eine Menge verschiedener Charaktere und herangehensweisen sowie Geheimnisse und viele Events, sodass sich mehrere Durchgänge aufjedenfall lohnen und immernoch Spaß machen. Die DLC ist auch durchaus einen Blick wert, da sie das Spiel nochmal um einige neue Orte und Events bereichert. Absolut empfehlenswert

33386045.review:
I found Renowned Explorers to be a fantastic strategy game with a good mix of tactical RPG battles (in the style of Disgaea, Final Fantasy Tactics, etc.), RPG-style leveling and character-building elements, and visual novel style storytelling where choices as well as skill checks matter. The game has quite a bit of resource management (in the style of FTL) and risk management, adding a definite "management" element to the tactics. (Sidenote: Those who complain about the RNG are missing the point that you've got to accept the fact that luck matters and focus on making wise management choices to minimize the risk of failure.)

The game is a perfect length of maybe 10 hours per playthrough with a huge amount of replayability and an emphasis on collections and achievements to keep things interesting. There are quite a few characters, each with their own skills, forcing you to play each game a little differently than the last. Then, if you get bored with the base game, the Emperor's Challenge expansion adds even more replayability by giving each game a unique set of objectives different from those of the base game.

33316021.review:
I keep coming back to this game after having played it for 50+ hours, so it obviously has something going for it.

The game starts by picking a captain and two assistants from a pool of explorers with different pros and cons; they then go on 6 expeditions from a pool of areas of varying difficulty and rewards.

The goal of each expedition is to get from the start to the end of an area while picking up as many rewards and treasures along the way. Once in a while the party gets an encounter, which plays out as a turn based battle on a randomized map.
Different characters have different abilities belonging to one of the attitudes aggressive, friendly, and devious with a particular damage type. Characters may be more or less vulnerable to particular damage types, and depending on which category of skills your party predominantly use to solve an encounter different rewards may be given.

On the maps a lot of tiles are skill challenges where the skills of the characters determine chanse of success. There are many kinds of skills - enough that you're probably not going to be good at everything. 

Every playthrough plays slightly differently thanks to how the maps are randomized; while the highlights of a map are always present somewhere it is never obvious what the best way to traverse the map from the start to the end node
is, and as the party only has a limited amount of rations (one is consumed every turn on the map, and if you run out a random character gets a random cumulative penalty for the rest of the expedition, some challenges may give some rations as a reward) luck is a big factor in how well an expedition turns out.

In between expeditions the party goes to a world map where gold can be spent on buying equipment giving better stats or bonus skill levels, fame can be used to recruit followers giving the party some kind of bonus, or research points can be used to write papers giving the party bonus stats, and it is the only way to obtain additional rations.

The game features a lot of funny writing, and some events may vary slightly depending on who is in your party.  Different party compositions do better in different areas, and different areas of the same difficulty have different kinds of rewards and enemy attitudes.

It does not require a lot of energy to play, and is a great way to relax when you are tired.

I do have some complaints too; Due to how combat is set up a lot of enemies can one shot the weaker characters, even while wearing armor. AI will attack characters randomly, so glass canons quite often get killed, and there doesn't seem to be much to do to prevent it from happening. This typically becomes a problem after you have already completed 2-3 expeditions, but can still bite you earlier than that if you're unlucky. It just feels cheap to have someone randomly walk up to one of my characters and just keep knocking them down. Each time a character is knocked down a unique resource that is hard to replenished is reduced by one, and when you run out it's game over. Characters can be revived by another character, but many boss battles are lost because the boss randomly decides to keep whacking the weakest character, and there is simply nothing to do about this if the character is to contribute at all.

The themed maps leave little choise for a party - an aggressive focused party is for example not going to have a good time fighting a ghost they are unable to hit, so for every party there is  a fairly obvious path that is optimal, and deviating from it typically quickly puts an end to the expedition due to one shotting enemies.

These are fairly minor complaints about an otherwise very nice game, but they begin to grate after a while, and I hope the developers will some day patch the combat to be a bit less unfair.

I strongly recommend this game if you like rogue likes.

Well, I'll open with what I didn't like. While amusing and actually fairly innovative, the "combat" encounters were, for the most part, heavily skewed towards Deception, Diplomacy, or a combination of those two. If in amongst your many types of party you decided that you wanted to go full colonialism and try an aggressive playthrough, you'll quickly realise it's untenable. Also, the roguelike nature can be a little restrictive; while you can go on and do the other expeditions after your campaign finishes, you'll find that does somewhat reduce replayability instead.

These however are not big enough issues to warrant not recommending the game, especially when it's on sale. It's surprisingly enjoyable, there's a lot of stuff you can do, and it's an amusing, endearing, memorable game. It doesn't take itself too seriously, it's got some appreciable humour, and most importantly it's rather fun. I can't speak for the paid DLCs, but the fact that the game gets both free and paid new content is a definite vote in its favour; a lot of indie games receive disappointing care following release, even abandonment (yes, I'm looking at you Battle Brothers devs), so seeing a small game like this getting some support is heartening.
