32695789.review:
I typically avoid games like this, but Renowned Explorers seduced me with it's fantastic art style.
And I am glad it did.

Despite the frustrating RNG-powered resource management system that FTL-like games often sport, the pros of this game make up for it's cons. Characters, despite not uttering any words (maybe have some voice acting in next game? I'd love to see what they come up with /hint), have very distict personality and traits, and make every playthrough different. 

The combat system in this game is a "social strategy" (©megakoresh, patent pending, all rights to use the term reserved, etc. etc.). Its a term I use for games where you can win fights without physically hurting enemies. In this case, in addition to straight up physical attack, you can also try to charm enemies, seduce them, or drive them to depression. Your actions affect overall mood of the encounter, which in turn affects how the enemy will respond, as well as significantly swings all friendly and enemy stats in one direction or the other. It's a fantastic system, that lets developers deliver character and story exposition through gameplay without even needing any dialogue. Ingenious!

On top of that the game sports a great sense of humour, incredible lovely art style (my favourite in all 2D games I played so far), and a great pace. The devs have also added a lot of extra free content since release and there are some DLCs available, that I'm actually gonna go buy (didn't know they came out already). Absolutely recommend it without hesistation. A great, cute, uplifting and clever game, equally fit for long sessions and 20 minute long dips.

32416890.review:
Renowned Explorers is a kind of mash up of turn based combat encounters, skill based choose your own adventure events and resource management. It makes for quite a good mix.

You pick 3 explorers from a selection of about 20 with each explorer having different strengths and skills. The goal in each playthrough is to complete 5 expeditions while trying to get as high a score as you can. The expeditions throw up different encounters and events which can net you resources or treasures but you run the risk of losing supplies or resolve.

The combat encounters also have an interesting twist. Each character has three types of attacks aggressive, devious and friendly which work like rock,paper and scissors. To add to this each battle has a mood that changes based on the types of attacks used. Different moods will either hinder or buff your party. It adds another layer of depth to the combat.

So overall Renowned Explorers is an interesting game which is surprisingly deep adnd challenging. Worth picking up if you enjoyed games like The Banner Saga.

32334765.review:
Renowned Explorers has many good features going for it; the cartoon graphics are fun, well thought out and lend it a sense of the old Saturday morning cartoons you watched as a kid (I am going to assume the average player is not a kid because the content of the game would be a little dry for someone under 12).  

It also has a sense of humor, is stylish and actually tries to place a little bit of historical content to its settings.  But in the end, it isn't enough.  Remember that part about dry?  This game is more than dry, ultimately it is boring.  

After putting about six hours into it and trying several team members, I have lost interest.  The settings change, but other than that, the expeditions don't.  Choose a path, follow it, read some text and hope you brought the right expert for the RNG/Price is Right wheel spin.  Succeed, get a treasure where it is not clear how its buffs really help you.  Fail, maybe take a ding to one of your stats.  Either way, more often than not you will next enter the fight mode.  

The fight mode will be familiar to anyone who has ever played Heroes of Might and Magic.  Walk your guy across a hexagon grid, choose your attack.  Despite there being three main schools of attacks, the type you prefer really doesn't matter.  If you do something violent, deceptive or friendly, there is no real long term effect on your character or game.  Just pick the one that does the most damage in the current situation.  

And that is the rub.  The designers have put a lot of time building up the three types of attacks, with all the requisite buffs.  They also added something of a "mood" system, meaning your enemies will react differently to each school, both at the start of the battle and while it wages on.  For instance, you can start off with friendly "attacks", but after a little while of complimenting the enemies and otherwise buttering them up, you will get a 25% boost to deceptive attacks.  This mean is it in your interest to now start insulting your enemies instead.  Kill one of them?  Don't worry, go back to complimenting the rest and they soon forget you ran their buddy through.  So long as you ignore heavy specialization, you will be able to pick whichever takes the most off the enemy health bar at the moment and ride out the fights.  

They should have sacrificed the complex buff system.  Honestly, unless your are really into minutiae or min/maxing, there is no reason or incentive to learn it.  Instead, they should have made the three attack schools much more unique and meaningful.  The type of attack your character uses should have real ramifications both inside and outside each micro battle. 

TLDR; Pros: graphics work for the game setting, dry humor.  Cons: Quickly repetitive and boring.  Needless detail in attack schools and buffs fails to really affect your game, so no real reason to learn it.  Not worth riding the DLC train, probably just more of the same.

32217915.review:
One of the better games I played recently.
The mechanics are challenging, but not frustrating, the graphics are cute, the facial expressions priceless, and the humour outstanding (just look at the small speech bubbles in fights!).
The story-points are fun to read, and vary with different crewmembers, as they have (fixed) personality traits and (customizable) skills that influence which options are available.
While speaking of crewmembers: It's pretty entertaining to learn more about them while playing, as the information is only revealed in small pieces, with several different game mechanics involved.

On the negative side, the adventures get repetitive after a few playthroughs, even though the maps are procedurally generated, and one starts to skip through the text (possibly missing crewmember specific options). Also, the game has the occasional (very minor, and definitely not game-breaking) graphics glitch.

32170149.review:
Любовь к своему детищу это первый шаг сделать по-настоящему хорошую игру. Конечно, не обойтись без основных навыков создания игры, но важна душа, которую можно заложить в проект. У Abbey Games это получилось, создавая Renowned Explorers: International Society, они сотворили что-то западающее в душу и оставляющее в памяти приятные воспоминания.

Renowned Explorers: International Society это приключение, которое совместило в себе элементы стратегии, ролевой игры и рогалика. Из этого следует, что пройти её за раз-два у вас не получится. если мыслить шире, то и после сотни прохождений конца вашему приключению не будет. Все дело не только в случайной генерации локаций, которые вы будете посещать, а в целом комплексе элементов, продуманных и гармонирующих между собой.

Саму игру можно разделить на условные этапы. Во-первых, необходимо подготовить команду для экспедиций. Три товарища, от способностей и характеров которых будет зависеть развитие вашей истории. Упор стоит делать не только на физические данные, но и на настроения и важные навыки для выживания. От приготовления пиши и охоты до красноречия и умения рассказать анекдот, от стальных мышц и выносливости до познаний биологии и астрофизики — все эти знания будут играть важную роль во время экспедиций. Из-за наличия одних вы будете зарабатывать славу и сокровища и отсутствия других будете терять ценные возможности, пищу и даже можете погибнуть. Присутствует условная система классов и в каждом подразделении есть несколько представителей со своими особенностями, так что будет возможность поэкспериментировать и собрать не единожды команду мечты. Таковой может оказаться не вполне банальное трио атлетов и плутов вроде Натана Дрейка и с большой вероятностью победу над лучезарным конкурентом вам принесет компания бабули, девочки и сумасшедшего ученого.

Перейдем к следующей стадии. Приключения. Вам будет предоставляться выбор места на планете, куда отправится в экспедицию, кроме самого первого, по-умолчанию выбираемого случайным образом. Затем местность, куда вы попадете, будет разделена на десятки пунктов назначения. Каждая такая точка генерируется случайно и пока вы её не посетите покрыта туманом. Можно лишь догадываться, что вас ждет впереди. Есть небольшие подсказки, которые дают понять, что впереди испытание или сражение или возможность получить сокровище, но с чем конкретно столкнется ваша команда известно одной лишь госпоже случайности. Эти передвижения от точки к точке во время приключения к конечному пункту бросают настоящий вызов. Вы будете ограничены пищей и «попытками». Первая тратится на передвижение и в случае когда еда подойдет к концу вы начнете терять характеристики. Второе — жизни. Потеря жизней во время экспедиции приводит к завершению игры и подсчету очков. Ключ к успеху стратегическое мышление и умение принести в жертву жажду наживы и желание спасти команду, чтобы двигаться дальше.

В основном, каждый раз попадая на одну из точек вы будете видеть текстовое окно с событием, на которое должны среагировать. Время подумать будет и даже избежать той или иной беды с минимальными потерями есть, но иногда иного выхода кроме как испытать удачу у вас не будет. И тут уже трудно сказать, что лучше ввязаться в бой или покрутить колесо фортуны, когда процент успеха, дай бог, дотягивает до 30%. В последнем случае мы можем или выйти победителями или нарваться на крупные потери. В случае сражения переходим в другой режим игры. Пошаговая стратегия с тремя видами атак.

Бои в Renowned Explorers: International Society специфические. Помимо применения грубой силы, мы можем попросту нагрубить противнику или заставить отступить его лестью. Если копать глубже каждый метод имеет несколько разных подходов, кроме тумаков. В итоге бой может закончится тем, что вы вгоните врагов в депрессию, или наоборот так вдохновите их, что они будут выкрикивать еще на поле боя слова поддержки в ваш адрес. Чем дальше вы будете двигаться, тем более понимать какой стиль боя вам ближе и прокачивать именно те навыки и те бонусы, которые выгодны вам. Но об этом после. Завершается каждая экспедиция посещением финальной точки, заданной с самого начала. Пути назад уже не будет, так что собираем все силы в кулак и идем на самое сложное испытание на карте, оно почти всегда заставляет покрутить колесо удачи, перекинуться парой словечек с противником и приводит к неминуемому сражению с боссом.

Наконец, последний этап — стратегическая карта. Это тихая гавань, где вы сможете потратить все накопленное за время экспедиции. Очки славы, науки, а также деньги и обменять сокровища на возможность рассказать свои истории миру и получить ещё больше очков перечисленных выше. Все это добро имеет свое место применения. Деньги тратим на экипировку, науку на прокачку общих навыков, разбитых на диаметрально отличающиеся друг от друга ветки, славу на привлечение разного народа, дающего бонусы во время следующего приключения. Они являются вашим пассивным бафом, который числится формально, так что во время приключений вы все ещё непобедимое трио, ну или тройка жалких неудачников, которым просто разок повезло.

Кстати, почувствовать себя неудачником можно будет себя не один раз. Порой случается так, что даже дерзкая и умелая команда встает на черную полосу и каждый шаг приводит вас к все большему и большему разочарованию, а затем и к смерти. В каких-то случаях это неумелая тактика и поспешно принятые решения, в иных случаях это воля той самой злосчастной случайности. Однако, со временем можно будет нащупать свою стихию и каждое прохождение будет, если не щелкаться как орехи, но хотя бы завершаться иным финалом ежели смерть. И в этот момент за дело принимаются дополнения, потому как после n-ого путешествия вам будет становится скучно.

Кураторство - http://store.steampowered.com/curator/5763270/

32141722.review:
After sinking 75 hours into this game I feel it deserves a review.

I had seen this game on my 'recommended' list for a while but was put off by the cartoonish and casual look. When I finally got it during a steam sale a few weeks ago I wasn't expecting much but felt I would get a dozen or so hours out of it before it became stale. My first few runs were indeed fairly standard casual fare. By the third run I had beaten the game (a lucky run) and felt I had seen everythiing this game had to offer. I was convinced that it would be shelved along many of the other games that once beaten I would never return to again.

That's when I saw the weekly community challenge. I was intrigued, especially when I saw the huge scores some people managed to submit. I was miles away from those score and couldn't immediately understand how people did this. So I went back and started to analyse the game mechanics in more detail. And that's when I realized that below the casual look was a very deep and complex game with many interlocking components. To get one of those high scores you had to understand those relationships and plan ahead. Both character development and resource management were important and balancing short-term vs long-term advantages was key. And most of all I started to realize that while luck and randomness do play a role, good preparation could mitigate this to a degree where it never became frustrating. My next few runs were all focussed on maximizing my chances of succeeding in challenges, starting to get a feeling for what perks would be best suited for which expeditions and events and which resources were best to invest in for each playstyle. 

What strikes me the most is that despite the fact that the same challenges and events come up after a while it never really feels repetitive. At each point there are real and meaningful decisions to be taken. I cannot quite put my finger on it but there is something here that means that each run feels very different. And going back to the community challenges, those are a great way to keep the game fresh, forcing you to approach the game slightly differently.

The combat too is quite well thought out, mixing both standard turn-based tactics with a attitude management system that again looks simple on the surface but is actually quite deep once you understand the mechanics. A seemingly overwhelming encounter can be beaten by shifting the mood to constantly keep an advantage over the opponents. 

I don't have the expansions yet, I hear they add a lot to the game, allowing even more options and advanced strategies, but even after 75 hrs I still have enough fun with the base game that I don't feel I need them yet.

10/10 - Would impress Sheep again!

32111186.review:
This game just exudes charm with its whimsical, freewheeling adventures and approach to character.  Despite the relative short length of any one campaign, no two adventures are exactly the same and I found myself coming back for more just to see if I could pass a skill check that I failed before, and what would happen if I did? 

Simply moving across the various maps and encountering the little stories+skillchecks is fun enough for me in itself, but it is also a tactical RPG and in that the game excels more than I was expecting. The novel approach to tactical gameplay in Renowned Explorers is incredibly interesting--instead of focusing on, say, weapon types, encounters revolve around setting and reacting to the mood of the battlefield.  In addition to the challenge of making sure you use the right kind of action to set the mood to give your party a potentially life-saving speech buff, you're also trying to make sure that the overall mood of the battle resolves in a way to net you particular rewards.  It's a lot more complex than I gave it credit for at first, and quite addicting.

This is a gem of a game that's fun and entertaining at any skill level.

32040088.review:
Renowned Explorers is a good game, where good is defined as "a series of interesting choices." It's like an infinite fractal of interesting choices. You choose characters who have disparate abilities and define a theme for your party. You choose which resources to pursue. You choose how to make those resources more valuable. You choose where to get those resources from. You choose how to fight. You choose when to take risks and make choices that can make risks into sure bets.

This is a game about choice and the rush of seeing results from your choices. Choose this game.

Bought this with the DLC/Expansions and the Devs other game for $23. It is worth that price I think. I am glad I did not pay full price because I am cheap, and because after about a week of play I feel like I got $20 worth of fun out of it. Like the other more detailed reviews say the combat is rock-paper-scissors style and each attack generates an emotion from the enemy which effects how strong different types of future attacks are. Seems simple, but can be quite challenging. The game is also deceptive because the art style looks like something you'd get while playing a phone app. The expeditions start to finish take me about 3 hours each, maybe a bit longer if i am struggling.

The best way to describe it is think of the game like a choose your own adventure book. It is a lot of somewhat random story elements that you select and try to overcome. I like that kind of thing, but I could easily see people not liking it becasue they expected more action. After 20 hours of play, for me, it seems like this is the type of game you obsess about for a little bit when you have some free time, but not enough for a more indepth game, or if you are like me and play Path of Exile it is a great way to pass time while you wait for content updates/between leagues. 

So if you are into choose your own adventure stories and turn based strategy games this may be a game you try as well. Try to get it on sale though.

31909588.review:
Renowned Explorers: International Society (per brevità RE:IS) è un gioco piuttosto complesso di cui sento la necessità di fare una recensione il più possibile semplice (per i miei canoni): se provassi a dettagliare ogni singolo aspetto delle intricate meccaniche di gameplay questa recensione finirebbe col diventare un noioso manuale di istruzioni delle dimensioni di un dizionario. Cercherò quindi di presentarvi solo un piccolo scorcio di quello che si cela dietro questo titolo indie a mio avviso molto interessante, lasciando alla vostra curiosità il compito di prendervi per mano nella scoperta del quadro nella sua interezza.

In RE:IS vestiremo i panni di un gruppo di esploratori membri di una esclusiva società, per l'appunto la Renowned Explorers International Society. Viaggeremo per il globo visitando i luoghi più disparati alla ricerca di misteriosi tesori e antiche reliquie, in modo da accrescere la nostra fama e il nostro prestigio e vincere la classifica degli esploratori a discapito della nostra nemesi, l'odiato (e odioso) esploratore francese Matthieu Rivaleux. 

Il gioco è essenzialmente uno strategico a turni, con una serie di caratteristiche che ci permettono di ascriverlo nel novero dei roguelite, il cui gameplay può essere diviso in 2 macro-fasi.

La prima fase è quella della pianificazione della spedizione. In questo frangente potremo valutare i diversi siti da esplorare, ognuno dei quali sarà contrassegnato da un indice di difficoltà e riporterà una serie di suggerimenti sulle migliori strategie di approccio; avremo inoltre a disposizione diversi "store" in cui acquistare equipaggiamento per i nostri esploratori, sviluppare veri e propri skill tree come nella migliore tradizione degli RPG, o ancora "acquistare" dei seguaci che ci seguiranno nelle nostre missioni e ci garantiranno risorse bonus durante l'esplorazione.

La seconda fase consiste nell'esplorazione vera e propria, in cui potremo sondare il terreno (inizialmente avvolto da nebbia di guerra) alla ricerca di diversi tipi di risorse e preziosi tesori nascosti. La parte più interessante del gioco è senz'altro il libero girovagare sulla mappa, che ci porterà ad imbatterci in una miriade di incontri ed eventi generati randomicamente che metteranno a dura prova le abilità diplomatiche e/o belliche della nostra cricca. Ogni mossa all'interno della mappa di gioco avrà un preciso costo in termini di rifornimenti: questo aspetto ci spingerà a pianificare minuziosamente il nostro tragitto, pesando attentamente i costi e i benefici di rotte differenti. Attardarsi nell'esplorazione senza approvvigionamenti causerà infatti delle conseguenze spiacevoli all'interno del nostro team che ne limiteranno l'efficacia nei combattimenti e in alcuni casi rischieranno di compromettere il prosieguo della nostra avventura.

I combattimenti, o per meglio dire gli "incontri", sono l'aspetto in cui RE:IS mostra tutta la sua originalità. Ciascun componente del nostro gruppo ha una tendenza innata a risolvere le dispute in modo amichevole, ambiguo o aggressivo, e persistendo nell'utilizzo di abilità della stessa tipologia finiremo con l'instaurare un "mood" specifico. Lo stesso discorso vale anche per i nostri avversari: i mood di entrambe le parti verranno confrontati secondo una logica in stile sasso/carta/forbice e ogni accoppiata potrà garantirci un "mood effect" positivo o negativo. Per fare un esempio pratico: se terremo un mood amichevole mentre il nemico ha un atteggiamento ambiguo le nostre difese risulteranno aumentate; se terremo un mood aggressivo viceversa subiremo un malus alla difesa.

Dal punto di vista della grafica lo stile di RE:IS, con i suoi colori colori sgargianti e il suo tratto moderno e vivace, ricorda molto da vicino alcuni cartoni animati di Nickelodeon. Un punto a favore del comparto grafico è l'estrema leggerezza dell'engine, che lo rende accessibile e pienamente godibile anche a chi (come il sottoscritto) non dispone di hardware di nuovissima generazione. Nella mia estrema pignoleria ho trovato i caratteri dei testi non particolarmente ispirati: un font meno anonimo avrebbe dato quel quid in più all'esperienza visiva, ma si tratta tutto sommato di osservazioni di poco conto in quanto in generale RE:IS rimane un piacere per gli occhi di chi sa apprezzare i videogiochi dal disegno di stampo fumettistico.

RE:IS è una ventata di aria fresca, un piacevole diversivo sia per i "rogueliker" più impenitenti *alza la mano*, sia per gli appassionati di TBS più canonici come i ben più famosi Civilization, Age of Wonders o Heroes of Might & Magic *rialza la mano*. Come anticipato in apertura, vi invito a prendervi il vostro tempo per metabolizzare le meccaniche di gioco principali, magari dedicando qualche minuto agli ottimi tutorial in-game: la curva di apprendimento è piuttosto ripida ma non impossibile, e la vostra perseveranza verrà premiata con momenti di spensierato divertimento che vi faranno perdere la cognizione del tempo.

31904960.review:
Renowned Explorers is an Exploration game with a Choose Your Own Adventure style story and Tactical Combat. I like it very much and it "feels" almost like FTL (exploration) mashed up with Civ V (Tactical Combat, Multiple Paths to Victory) to me, but is unique enough to stand as its own thing. 

The game is played by choosing a location to explore, traveling from node to node while managing your supplies and trying to get the most rewards out of a location before heading to the final confrontation. Sometimes a thing just happens and you get a reward, sometimes you have a challenge which you must pick a charecter and roll on the adventure wheel for success with a higher chance of success based on that charecters skills and the choices youve made, sometimes you must face combat which can be resolved in one of three ways: Aggressive, Friendly or Devious. Ultimatly you are looking for treasure and rewards which also help to make you stronger for future expiditions. After 5 sussecsful expiditions the game completes and if you managed to get enough Renown you win the game. If your resolve ever runs out or all your charecters fall in battle you lose the game. 

It can sound very complicated but you can freely play on lower difficulties without having to master all the systems. Also the higher risks you take in the game the greater the rewards you get, but it is entirely possible to win by playing it safe. Renowned Explorers is very fun for me and I would reccomend everyone to try it out if it sounds appealing to you.

31896989.review:
Fantastic game with an unexpected amount of depth. A solid title, currently an 8/10 that would become a 9/10 with some more updates.

Despite seeming like a simple board-game, combat is surprisingly strategic and requires significant planning and thought rather than some boring hack and slash. You have to take into account the mood and combat tactics you and your enemy are using, gear for your party, specific weaknesses the enemy might have, status effects that you apply, taking advantage of AOE effects and much more. 

The characters that you can select have quite a few overlapping skills (a few more new skills assigned to different characterws would be appreciated), but it's not too bad. The biggest saving grace here is the incredible stylized art which makes every scientist, soldier, scout, or speaker feel unique in their own way. You've got the big, burley (but well-meaning) Russian bear, a stuffy, German school-teacher, the beautiful Latin seductress (Hola!), the insane eletricity-obsessed scientist, and much more.

The number of "expeditions" could be a bit higher. Considering that the game is rogue-like and you'll be replaying quite a bit, the game suffers from a feeling of redundancy too soon that could be remedied with additional maps. Currently there are 3 maps for every challenge rating (total of 13 I believe, there are only 2 five-star and four-star challenge expeditions), but after your first 6 or so runs it may get a bit stale.

There is a bit of a learning curve, but that's to be expecting in a rogue-like game. Your first three or four adventures will end in disaster, but you simply accept your mistakes and improve upon them the next time!

Overall, great game for it's price, especially on sale. The two main gripes one may have is if you are not keen on luck-based games (which a substantial portion of this game is based on) and the medicore number of expeditions. (note, they are slowly making more, but some are hidden behind paid DLC) Still, the positives far outweight the negatives.

31895554.review: A cross between tactics games and FTL-style exploration, RE:IS is a fun and humorous game about exploring exotic locations and preparing for the next journey. The fun, easy-to-grasp game mechanics have a surprising amount of depth to them, both in encounters and in the exploration map. The game's great sense of style compliments the slightly humorous and cartoony gameplay and narrative, with characters straight out of Tintin and adventures out of Ducktales. Do you happen to meet some friendly highlanders on your way to a lost Scottish artefact and talk some sense into them with seduction? Insult and berate wolves into leaving you alone while you excavate forgotten ruins? Or just fight like a gentleman (or a thug) to clear your way to treasure?

31884899.review:
How did I ignore this game for so long?  It is one of the best "rock, paper, scissors" strategy games I've ever played.  It is certainly one of the most fun strategy games I've ever played. 

The goal of the game is simplicty itself.  Explore different locales to gain renown and become the most renowned explorer.  You gain renown from treasures you find.  You also gain renown from choices you make on a research tree as well as from helpers and associates you hire.  The associates mostly just amplify the choices you make in the research tree.  I'm not explaining this very well, but it is super fun.

The game has a ton of replayability.  There are so many combinations of explorers and each group you pick plays differently.  You get to buy items for your explorers, and the small inventory space makes for some tough decisions on how to equip them.  Items can boost attack, defense, amplify certain skills and even add additional skills to an explorer. It's a cool system and adds a lot to the game.

Even when you can beat the game every time every time with your favorite crew, it will take a lot of play until you can beat every time with a random crew.

Three thumbs up, good value and a ton of fun.  Check it out the next time it goes on sale.

养成+策略+rogue-like，各部分把握的恰到好处，游戏主题明确。
画面虽然谈不上精美，却也简洁明了，至少让人看的还是挺舒服的，漫画般明朗的线条还是很对我的胃口的。
音乐方面尚可，契合游戏氛围，然而确实缺少变化，谈不上精彩，基本不能为游戏内容加分。
rogue-like部分中规中矩，养成倒还不错，装备技能科技天赋（找不到形容词）等等一应俱全，不得不说可玩角色确实不少，策略部分倒是让人眼前一亮，情绪的设定还是蛮有意思的（顺便吐槽下好战情绪有点弱鸡）。
一局游戏的时间不长，而且完成后还可以继续探索，这倒是挺不错的。
总体上来说是一款很不错的游戏，价格的话也不算高，游戏内容还是值得这个定价的。

31764273.review:
Игра совершенно беззастенчиво позаимствовала свою концепцию у Curious Expedition (под вашим управлением находится отряд путешественников, который вы посылаете на различные экспедиции, стараясь заработать как можно больше очков и стать самым знаменитым исследователем), однако она не "тупо" ее скопировала, а привнесла свои уникальные элементы. К тому же в  отличие от последней , здесь гораздо меньшее место отведено рандому, а основной упор делается на грамотное планирование, стратегию и тактику, что для меня лично является огромным плюсом. 

На выбор вам дается 20 исследователей (каждый со своим деревом навыков), из которых вы можете взять в команду только трех. Отправившись в экспедицию, вам покажут место, в которое вы должны попасть и вам нужно будет рассчитать свой путь к конечной точке так, чтобы и ресурсов хватило, и чтобы наград можно было нахапать побольше. Во время своих путешествий вы будете выполнять различные небольшие текстовые квесты, результат в которых, во многом, зависит от умений ваших приключенцев и иногда вступать в бои с недружелюбно настроенной фауной, аборигенами либо же вашими соперниками. Система боя тут сделана довольно интересно--она построена на эмоциях. В зависимости от настроения вашей команды и противников вы будете получать различные баффы или же дебафы. 

Между экспедициями вы можете прокачивать свой отряд "туристов", покупать им различную экипировку, исследовать технологии, нанимать специалистов и рабочих, которые будут давать вашей команде различные баффы и увеличивать количество ресурсов, которые вы можете притащить с экспедиции. Все это вы делаете в различных "хабах" на мировой карте, которые так же можно прокачивать. Так же хотелось бы отметить интерфейс: он простой и очень удобный. Например, наведя мышкой, на абилку, вы четко видите все ее эффекты. А если вы вдруг забыли какую-то механику, то к вашим услугам подробный встроенный в игру справочник. Правда, русификацию в этот раз не завезли.

В итоге, игра получилась весьма достойная и, на мой взгяд, гораздо лучше и интереснее Curious Expedition. Если вы любителей стратегий и пошаговых боев -- берите, не пожалеете.

I bought Renowned Explorers at 50% off with The Emperor's Challenge & More to Explore expansions and it's 100% been worth it.

This is an excellently executed & passionately made adventure, with interesting mechanics & just enough RNG to keep our primitive brains engrossed for hours at a time. 31719100.review:
I downloaded the game earlier and played through two runs, hoping to get a contribution in for the community challenge #71 going on this week.

What I didn't expect was to spend over three hours having way more fun and being way more engrossed than I thought I would.

This game is a beauty for anyone who enjoys turn-based strategy board games, or even turn-based strategy in general. Oregon Trail is something I kept thinking of while playing. There's definitely inspiration from board games in RE, though, and along with the characters and the witty writing, as well as the unique battle mechanics, there's a huge amount of charm to find in this game.

That's not to say this game is forgiving. Not in the slightest. There's a lot to grasp starting out (thankfully the tutorials are straightforward and not too drawn-out), and I'm sure some meta tactics are out there to maximize your resources in various ways. There's a lot to explore (see what I did there?) in terms of the game's depth through its mechanics, and you can always improve your score, so replayability isn't that big of an issue. And for anyone who may somehow find themselves exhausting that replayability, there's DLC packs to continue the enjoyment at very reasonable prices.

Renowned Explorers: International Society is well worth your money, but more importantly, it is certainly worth your time. If you like this kind of game, don't hestitate to pick it up.

31704369.review:
I purchased this game because I'd picked up "The Curious Expedition". I enjoyed TCE, in spite of some harsh flaws, and noted that many reviews mentioned "Renowned Explorers" as being a similar and superior version of the idea. It went on sale, and I took the plunge.

It's a bit prettier if you don't like seeing aliased edges. Looks like vector art to me, coupled with some cut-out style ragdoll animations. I can see how some might find that objectively superior to little blots of pixels that wiggle a little and pop up and down once to indicate a combat action. It wasn't an issue for me.

RE also has a more tactical combat. TCE's combat system is pretty bad: it's simple, heavily random, and leans toward brutal outcomes. I still like it more, because RE's combat isn't even combat. It's a combat system that pretends you're all really just having a row. The outcomes aren't brutal, they're mostly carebear. You win by emotionally overwhelming your opponents. Yes, most of your attacks are either meant to make your opponents feel so bad they run away in tears, or feel so grateful to you for pumping up their ego that they wouldn't dream of interfering. 

And you have to deal with their mood. Yes, your strategy changes depending on whether the bad guys are friendly or cranky. Except, it doesn't. Mostly it's just a matter of which type of attack you use most. Sometimes it's the red button. Sometimes it's the blue. Sometimes it's the green. It all depends on which one will break their spirit the most, as determined by what kind of spirit they brought you to break.

There's another couple layers of rock-paper-scissor tacked on, so that there are different buffs/debuffs for different... (*sigh) moods. Yes, the vibe in the air, the interaction of the opponent's emotional state and the emotional state your opponents percieve you have, has a 25-30% influence on some action or another.

There's a small novelty value to the window dressing at first--but only as long as you think of it as quirky window dressing. If you actually think of it as a game where most battles are won by alternately praising and verbally abusing or intimidating your opponents, then suddenly it's somewhere between catty and psychopathy. Do you really want to roleplay as someone who gets what they want through bullying and emotional manipulation? Is that even someone you want to pretend to be? If so, good news! They finally made a game for the pathologically passive aggressive, and this is it!

If, on the other hand, you prefer to pretend to better than you are, or much much worse, this isn't going to cut it. The paladins are going to puke their armor, and villains are likely to be dissappointed at how little damage they get to do, and how shallow the manipulations are. It's not like you're weaving together a detailed conspiracy and watching your puppets dance as you tug their emotions with subtlety from the background. It's more two groups of children shouting on the playground and alternating between "poopy head" and "Hey bae!" with the occasional "I'm gonna bang your mom" for good measure.

Think I'm exaggerating? I don't blame you. But keep in mind most of these emotional attacks also inflict (yes, inflict) emotional states ranging from enthusiastic to enraged to terrified, and most of them also have buffs or debuffs.

Did I mention your party members heal each other by saying nice things to one another? And the battle resolution is never about death or injury, they just run off the field weeping in joy, fear, anger or confusion about all the mixed signals. Basically it's a little too close to how I see people resolve conflicts in real life. Not the sort of realism I was looking for. 


Even worse is their boss encounter system. Most encounters are mop up type missions where you keep going untill everyone else has run off in some flavor of tears. Boss encounters continue until the Boss is weeping, sometimes into the shoulder of a consoling henchman. Excuse me, hench-person. They all summon more henchpeople during the fight. That's what makes it a boss encounter. That's the main difficulty lever.

Granted, it does make the combat tougher. It doesn't keep it interesting.

Renowned Explorers does stand above The Curious Expedition in variety of storylines. I saw lots of repetition in the first hour or two of TCE. In three hours of RE, I was still seeing new storylines and events.

However, I think RE might have ruined this niche genre. No, not rogue-likes--this is not a roguelike. That would be like saying tag is like cribbage. This genre is "popularity contest", the realization of which is what has killed my interest. 

It's not as obvious in TCE, where your primary means of gaining popularity is returning from adventures abroad with a shipload of treasure and lots of exciting stories to tell. But in RE, where about a third of your resources go to hiring an entourage provide buffs to your income--and you purchase them with 'status'... it's a little too blunt for me.

In TCE, you spent your money on real equipment: rope, climbing gear, torches, food, etc. In Renowned Explorers, you buy accessories to improve your stats. Things like "good boots", "memento", "decent book"--yeah... the paint is really peeling off now. This is a game for your inner middle school mean girl.

I do acknowledge they've corrected my internal misspelling of renowned. I guess that's worth something.

Diese Bewertung ist nur ernst zu nehmen, falls man sich ein anspruchsvolles Strategiespiel mit ca 15 Stunden Content gewünscht hat (bei zügigem durchspielen). Pro:
- neuartiges strategisches System (ist auch eher anspruchsvollere Strategie, als in anderen Strategiespielen)
- witzige Charaktere + viele verschiedene Charaktere

Contra: 
- Das Spiel ist schlichtweg viel zu kurz für ein Singleplayer Game. Es gibt zwar Upgrades (kostenpflichtig), womit es länger dauert durchzuspielen (ca. 2 Stunden ohne Upgrade), aber ich kann mir auch mit den Upgrades  nicht vorstellen, dass es dann genug lang dauert. Man kann das Spiel auch ein zweites Mal mit einer anderen Gruppe von Charakteren durchspielen, aber es läuft einfach aufs Selbe hinaus.... wird halt langweilig, weil es immer das Selbe ist. - Das Kampfprinzip ist zwar aus strategischer Sicht sehr gut gemacht (ähnlich wie Schach), aber die Animationen müssen nicht so lange dauern...
- Es gibt einfach viel zu gute Konkurrenzprodukte im Bereich "Strategie", um dieses Spiel weiterzuempfehlen.

31600658.review:
Renowned Explorers ist ein erfrischend anderes Spiel. Hier geht es darum, 5  Areale zu bereisen und dabei möglichst viel zu entdecken, um schlussendlich zum ruhmreichsten Entdecker gekürt zu werden.

Die große Stärke des Spiels ist dabei die Abwechslung. Jeder der 2-3h langen Durchgänge ist anders, sodass das Spiel eine Menge Wiederspielwert bietet. 
Das beginnt schon bei der Auswahl der Crew. Jedes Crewmitglied hat unterschiedliche Eigenschaften und Fähigkeiten. Zum Beispiel ist Harry ein "Rogue" und/oder "Beguiler" und kann so gut als Schurke agieren (Schleichen, Schlösser knacken etc.) und Leute bequatschen, aber keine Aufgaben erledigen, für die es einen Kraftprotz braucht. Gleichzeitig hat er eine Pistole mit 3 Reichweite, was ihn eher für ein "aggressives" Team prädestiniert.
Das Kampfsystem ist vielschichtig und voller Humor. Wenn Harry z.B. mit seiner Pistole einen friedlichen Dorfbewohner beschießt, ist er im Vorteil. Allerdings sind aggressive Gruppen anfällig gegen Provokationen. Provozierende Gruppen haben es wiederum schwer gegen freundliche Gegner. Und dann gibts noch Auswirkungen, wenn Gruppen gleichen Gemüts aufeinandertreffen (z.B. Beleidungsduell mit Affen). Wer im "Kampf" dann auf einmal statt freundlichen Worten dem Gegenüber die Faust ins Gesicht schlägt, ist dann schnell "aggressiv". So kann man das Kampfsystem zu seinem Vorteil nutzen. Hört sich alles furchtbar kompliziert an, spielt sich aber einfach. Die Kämpfe sind aber nur ein Teil des Spiels. Wer mag, kann vielen Kämpfen auch einfach aus dem Weg gehen. 
Es wird einem nämlich angezeigt, was einen (grob) erwartet, wenn man ein bestimmtes Feld bereist. Beispielsweise ist auf einem Feld ein Kampfsymbol und ein Forschungssymbol. Wer nur nach Gold sucht, schickt seine Helden also lieber woanders hin. Auch hier sei nochmal die Abwechslung erwähnt. Die Areale, die man bereist, sind nämlich weitgehend zufallsgeneriert, deswegen findet man auch beim vierten Mal auf der Karibikinsel einen neuen Schatz.

Insgesamt betrachtet ist das Spiel immer für eine Runde gut. Irgendwann merkt man dann, dass man hier viel mehr Zeit verbracht hat, als bei so manchem Vollpreisspiel. Und man bereut es dabei keine einzige Sekunde, wenn man mal wieder ganze Inseln plündert, sich mit Highlandern anfreundet oder einen Riesenaffen so lange traurig macht, bis man ihn einsperren kann.

You are the leader of a plucky team of wayward adventurers, exploring the world in the name of... profit, science, or simply fame, the choice is yours. Diplomacy and trickery can be your weapons, or you can achieve victory through your honest and cheerful demeanor, but as a last resort shooting everything that moves is always an option.

A wide variety of tintin-esque action-serial adventures await you on the far flung reaches of the globe, but the clock is ticking and you have to balance resource constraints against your limited time, and weigh risky but profitable ventures against safer alternatives. Success means the cherished Adventurer of the Year trophy, failure, and you are but a side-note in the annals of history.

The production values are very high, the cast of characters rich and diverse, the missions plentiful and entertaining, and the combat system well rounded. Frankly, there's not much about this game I don't like.

What makes this game great:

* relatively short playthroughs, with huge replay value
* progression doesn't depend on how many mobs you kill
* just the right amount of randomization to keep things fresh
* nails the victorian-steampunk-explorer vibe
* chill soundtrack

What's holding it back:

* another dlc pack with more expeditions would be awesome
* lacks internationalization (but if you can read this you likely don't care)

31477617.review:
Summary: Excellent game, with interesting gameplay mechanics, great graphics and sound, that is marred only by its failure to deliver enough content, or a truly random system of adventure generation to extend game play indefinitely.  8/10

Renowned Explorers is a phenomenal game that I'd highly recommend to anyone, though there are some issues with it.

The game has a very fun gameplay style which emphasizes personal preference and choice for playing the game.  There's no right way to play it, and any play style is rewarding and fun.  There's quite a bit of depth to the encounter system where you have to carefully manage the mood of your party, your enemies, as well as the general mood of the encounter.

The character system is well done, using a simple ability 'tree' to decide how to customize your characters as they gain experience, as well as a very pen and paper feeling perk system to highlight the skills of your characters.  Unfortunately, for me at least, the character system can feel a little shallow, with few choices and levels, each character has a very limited spread of paths they can take.  Some people would likely argue that the simplicity makes it more appealing, but I've always prefered more depth and complexity to games.

The campaign is fun, and relatively short (a few hours to beat it).  Much of the premise of the game revolves around the idea of the game being highly replayable, and while superficially it appears to be, after a number of plays, I find that the game begins to grow stale.  In terms of content, there are only 11 expeditions in the base game, 3 of which are mutually exclusive (you play the one that is most suited to your team's playstyle as the first expedition, the others can never be chosen), leaving you with only 8 choices for the rest of the game.  Within each expedition, there's quite a bit of variety, and no single expedition ever takes the same path, but they always reach the same destination.  Once you've played an expedition once, you always know how it will end and this takes away a lot of the fun of exploring.  After a few campaign playthroughs, its likely that you've played every expedition multiple times and have seen most, if not all, of the optional events within.

The campaign also offers a marathon mode, which allows you to continue exploring with your team, until you've completed every expedition, however the level cap is usually reached after 5, leading to no additional character progression, beyond events within expeditions.

Overall the game is excellent, and very worth the price.  Unfortunately it is lacking in content, which takes away from its 'endless adventures' premise.  The devs have released one expansion pack as of this review, with 2 new expeditions, and other is due in a few weeks with a 3rd new expedition, but I do not believe that a few new expeditions are going to be enough to improve the long term gameplay enough.  I would like to see them add additional variation to each expedition, allowing the random generator to also randomly generate the goal of the expedition, and add in a number of new goals and treasures to that end.  It would go a long way to improve the general randomness and unpredictability of the game, and greatly extend the game's lifespan, in my opinion.

31436377.review:
Very impressed with this so far. It's by the same studio that made Reus, and there are some familiar elements, unsure to what extent it takes the "you need to have the wiki open to play this" style that Reus had but I can say it's not zero. As far as this niche of fire emblemy rougelites goes, this looks like it might be the best of them.

Edit: After playing a lot more, I'm happy to recommend this as an excellent rougelike. Once you know the game pretty well the mechanics come together in a very coherent package, and many of the elements that make this genre work for me are present:
-Really encourages greed. The map is basically the same as FTL, except rather than just being stuck when you run out of fuel, you can keep moving but acquire a temporary debuff each move. Since there's always a boss at the end of each area, acquire too many of these debuffs and the boss will mulch you... but so many shinies! There are similar opportunities to be greedy in all the other scopes of gameplay.
-Adaptively set your own difficulty. Relating to the above, the basic goal of the game is actually pretty simple (get 2.5k points in 5 runs). Then the game gives you a subtle "but what if you got 10k points???" and thus you get to balance maximizing your score while not getting completely stomped because greed.
-Diverse playstyles. I've got a main team, and quite a few ideas I want to try. There's a big aspect of building team compositions, and most of them are viable depending on how greedy you are.
-RNG that creates variety but doesn't usually screw you. In terms of procedural generation, it makes the maps unique but all the things you'd want to prepare for are guaranteed and obvious in advance. The dice rolls can mostly be bypassed, and don't kill you outright so much as make combat harder (and you're gonna do that to yourself anyway).
-Informed decisions. Play for 5 minutes and you'll see what I mean.
-Nuanced combat. Sure early on you can just oneshot everything, but once you start getting greedy you'll have to find depth in the combat, and there's a lot of it. It's fire emblem except you can control enemy aggro, and have several emotion systems to leverage to win a 3v10.

So yeah, if you're into this sort of roguelike, pick this up. It's not meant to be played determined to get the highest possible score every time, but if you like making a vague plan and then seeing what you can accomplish in each run, RE:IS is the best of these I've seen.

31329205.review:
I'm re-reviewing this because I feel like I didn't gush enough about it before. I'll let my playtime speak for itself. I'll also preface this with one very important thing: [b]If you enjoy darkest dungeon, and can cope with the complete reversal of style, YOU NEED THIS GAME.[/b] It's like a way more colourful and slightly less 2d darkest dungeon and it will probably feel very familiar.

So what kind of game is Renowned Explorer? It describes itself as a rogue-like, but that's not strictly true. It's not a classic rogue-like, and arguably it doesnt really [i]feel[/i] like one. The game is split into three distinct modes, the expeditions themselves, combat during them and preparing for your next expedition. Combat is self-explanatory, pitting your team of explorers against many fantastic enemies. From angry Scotsmen in the highlands, to Voodoo Pirates in the Carribean, to.. well, some of the more incredible fights are actually best left to discover for yourself. Let's say you may be uncovering the truth about a few famous myths and legends!

There's three (and a half) currencies you earn throughout the game, each giving you some sort of boon when you spend them in between expeditions. Gold buys you items, either plain old armor and weapons or little trinkets which benefit your explorers in some way. Status buys you friends, either generic helpers who can make it so you earn even more money/status or ones that can do stuff a bit more unique. Research acts much like skill trees in any other game, in simple terms. You unlock a tree and then spend exponentially increasing amounts of research to improve it. The game does a really good job of explaining it so don't worry if that doesn't make sense.

Expeditions feel a lot like a choose your own adventure campaign, I'd honestly liken it to dealing with encounters in DnD. The map is split up into nodes and each one will (usually) have something on it. Sometimes your team stumbles upon a bunch of gold coins. Sometimes you come up against angry scorpions. Sometimes your team has a bit more of a choice.

As an example (and I'll spoilertag the end bit because it's really one of the best moments in the game when you find it - and actually its in one of the DLCs anyway which as an aside YOU REALLY SHOULD BUY): At one point in the game you find yourself face to face with someone blocking your path down a mountain. He insists that you must beat him in some ancient game. You can face off against him fairly, and having someone who knows tactics will do well. You could cheat, but, is cheating on an ancient boardgame really ever a good idea? OR: [spoiler]if you have someone who's a really good survivalist, you can [b]take the game board and surf it down the mountain. It's an absolutely awesome moment that you really need to see for yourself.[/b][/spoiler]. I'm spoilertagging that because it's a hidden choice, and the game is full of them. There are often points where it seems like you'll never be able to get past this normally and you're resigned to your fate, until you go there with a certain explorer...

Difficulty wise? It's hard, but it's not frustrating.. most of the time. It can be a bit annoying when you wipe to an encounter you really should have prepped better for, but since a full game takes about 1 to 2 hours, its no big loss. If you love achievements, there are a ton in this game. You only need to beat the game on the hardest mode with every single explorer for a captain!

And lets take that to talk about the characters. God, every single one of them is so fun and unique and full of charm. Each has their own upsides and downsides and, with the More to Explore dlc, their own campfire story which gives them a little bit more characterization than you'd normally get. It's hard not to feel your heart melt when you see your other two party members cheer on Emilia, the shy botanist from Poland, as she finds a super rare flower that she's been looking for forever.

Seriously, not only are the characters each unique and charming, they're also diverse. Honestly, how many games can you name featuring a main character from Ghana? Kwame is a diplomat hailing from an Ashanti tribe and he fits in perfectly with the rest of the cast. Bia is a freedom fighter from Greece. Kiwi came to the society from Samoa, making her own damn boat to sail to Australia and then on to London! The Emperor's Challenge DLC adds Phaillin, a deceptively charming speaker from Thailand and Suh Min-Jeong, the very young Korean scientist. I think you get the idea. Abbey Games should be commended for creating such a diverse and interesting cast! (well, there's no explicitly gay character yet.. although the charming Maria gets a campfire story that causes another crew member of any gender to fall in love with her- although she'll reject a female crew member saying she's 'out of that phase' now, which isnt great but its something at least)

In closing, I really really recommend this game. If any single bit of it looks interesting to you, you should buy it. Right now, it's 60% off which is an absolute steal in my eyes. Please buy this game.

31231015.review:
A game about 19th-century globetrotting exploration ("rogue-like" in the sense that it has procedural content and optional permadeath, but it's not particularly hard to survive to the end). There's three main facets to this game:

First, there's a series of text-based events describing the people, places, and artifacts you encounter on your expeditions. You can make choices about how to respond, with the skills and personality traits of your crew unlocking extra options or providing bonuses.

Second, there's grid-based tactical combat. They've got a medium-weight combat system where each character has 3 basic moves and learns more specialized techniques as they level up. You can defeat opponents by beating them up, or by breaking their spirit with taunts and insults, or by winning them over with compliments and friendly banter. The moves you choose to use change your party's overall attitude, which can provide combat bonuses or penalties, influence enemy tactics, and change your rewards for the encounter.

Third, there's a resource management system. As you journey, you collect gold, fame, and research that can be used to upgrade your equipment, recruit an encourage, and research new abilities. Many of the things you can buy feed back into resource generation for future expeditions, so it's got a growth-optimization angle that reminds me a little of Civilization and similar games (though the actual mechanics are thoroughly different).

The skill system is notable: characters have skill ratings in general categories like Archaeologist, Diplomat, or Athlete, but your rating is simply a count of how many individual skills you have within that category (for instance, the Diplomat category has things like Languages, Customs, and Politics), which are sometimes individually important and also influence how you can rank up (there's no benefit to getting Diplomat: Languages from 2 different sources, but there is a benefit to getting both Diplomat: Languages and Diplomat: Customs).

31077778.review:
This game is a delight! It manages to tickle my imagination in the way that a good children's book can while capturing the pleasure of a well designed board game.

The gameplay and mechanics are simple enough that a novice can complete the game easily within their first half-dozen attempts. But the high-end challenges nested within the game are enough to occupy any hardcore table top strategy gamer. The pacing at which these challenges unfold and reveal themselves to the player masterfully handled. And the Steam acheivements are well designed in that they help guide a gamer towards these challenges over time.

Even more enjoyable than the gameplay is Renowned Explorers sense of narrative. Character specific and skill specific narratives have been woven throughout the game. These are so much fun to discover and follow through to completion.

My only beef with the game related to the default settings. My first few playthroughs had the long combat animations turned on. I found these dragged out battles, making the game insufferably slow. Thankfully, the developers have made it so you can toggle these off. Once switched off, I find a full game, if successful, lasts about 1.5-2 hours. Considering the number of short indie titles & sometimes overly long civ-like strategy games in my library, I find that Renowned Explorers occupies a unique category and sweet spot in terms of the time commitment required versus the depth of play available.

I absolutely recommend this title and its expansion, More to Explore, to anyone.

One final note for families, this game is very wide in age appropriateness, offering good stuff for players aged 8 and plenty of fun stuff for any adults who enjoy good old fashioned adventure serials.

30765464.review:
I seduced a nun, got spat on by a llama, fought Charles Darwin riding a dinosaur, and made grown men cry. 1000/10

But if you need more of a reason to buy this game, here's the breakdown: you play as a group of explorers, traveling the world, earning status and money while doing research, collecting treasures, and all around making a nuisance of yourself. It's a turn-based strategy game with a really interesting mechanic: moods and attitudes. Each side of the battle (you vs. them) each have one of three attitudes (friendly, devious and aggressive), and the combination of your attitude and the enemy's creates an overall mood (ex. hostile = both parties aggressive or persuasive = you friendly and them devious). Each mood has bonuses or penalties, and there's a rock-paper-scissors system so you know which way to shift your attitude to get the bonuses and avoid the penalties. (Friendly beats devious, devious beats aggressive, aggressive beats friendly.) You win battles with your built-in powers. There is some overlap between characters on the powers, but not a lot. There are area attacks, line attacks, and single-target attacks, and by default every character has one attack from each attitude, plus some bonus ones that fit their own personal strengths and personalities. (Yes, seduce is an attack you can actually use, and no, it's not gender specific). It's good for all kinds of different playstyles.

But that's just the battles! 

The other main part of the game is exploring. You have 5 expeditions to a campaign (you can do more after that, but most of the achievements are turned off for anything past 5). Each expedition puts you on an island with tons of people to interact with, and depending on which three characters you have in your party, the outcomes can change. Ex. If you don't have a character with a high enough level in archaeology you won't find a really cool thingamajig, or there is one boss I didn't even realize I hadn't actually faced because I couldn't get past the skill checks to fight him. The options are basically things like "This person needs food. Help this person out (Lose 1 supplies. Reward: Gain status)" or "Help them out, but for a price (Lose 1 supplies. Reward: Gain 1 Collect)" or "Don't help them and move on." You can also do things like punch people in the face and start a fight, decide which people to send on supply runs, whether to skip a fight at the cost of supplies, etc. Your choices often require a spin of a chance wheel, with your various applicable skills increasing your percentage chance. Certain islands/areas that you travel to will have research, money, or status collectibles, each of which will help your party gain renown and come out on top in the eyes of the Renowned Explorer: International Society and beat your rival. There are also treasures you collect, which have special one-time or permanent bonuses (if you get the DLC you get to choose the bonuses from a list), which add to your renown.

There are also a ton of difficulty levels: easy, normal, classic, and impossible. Easy might make the battles easier, but I've still died plenty of times, and after 100 hours of play (including the DLC), I still haven't found all the treasures. In addition to the difficulty, there are two ways to play: Discovery mode (where you can restart a battle if you kill your party or run out of "resolve," which you can also collect), and Adventure mode, which makes it more like a Roguelike with no restarts. There are also TONS of achievements for both modes, and there are 20 achievement for winning the game with each of 20 characters in any mode and then 20 more for doing it with each of them in adventure mode, so there's going to be a lot of replays if you want to go to 100%.

Overall:

Pros:
+Great art.
+Adaptive music. Much of the music repeats, but it's adaptive, and will become more aggressive when the mood changes or more laid back when the mood drops back to more friendly terms.
+ TONS of depth. Playing with just one different character in your party can open up new avenues for the same interaction. Finishing a battle with a different attitude can give you different treasures, or open up new avenues of exploration like hints to hidden treasure.
+ Skill upgrades. Each character comes with a few built-in skills, which you can upgrade. Your character can be super amazing at one skill, or multi-talented in a bunch.
+ Items to purchase! Items give attack bonuses, defense, or additional skills. You have to upgrade shops with money to get better items, but items come with really good bonuses or tons of extra skills.
+ Entourages. You can spend status points to gain helpers and specialists who give you bonuses in research, collect, and status.
+ Research trees! Spend research points to collect renown faster, get bonuses for ending battles with a certain attitude, get extra skills, etc.
+ Unique characters! 4 classes, 5 different characters in each class, all with different weapons, behaviors, skills, homelands, an designs. No photocopied characters here. There's even more background to them in the DLC. Personality traits even affect your choices in interactions. Ex. A greedy character in your party will, in one case, go back for more treasure and decrease your chance to escape through a closing tomb door in time.
+ Your choices matter! You can only go on 5 expeditions. The first one is chosen at random, then you have your choice of 2-3 new expeditions, then after that one you have 2-3 additional choices, etc. So although there are a limited number of choices, you can decide whether to play it safe and explore only easy islands, or go for the big rewards and go for the hardest ones. Some of the expeditions are suited to different types of parties or attitudes (aggressive, devious or aggressive), or they may be tempting because they are high in money, or research, or status. Once you're on an island, you have a limited amount of supplies, so you can't search everywhere for treasure without getting serious penalties for the boss battle. Luckily, each spot is labeled with all the possible types of events that could happen there, so you have a hint of what may come, and can plan your route accordingly.
+ DLC is great. There should be another one coming out eventually, but the current one has two new expeditions (with tons of treasures and new mechanics, plus Charles Darwin riding a raptor). There are also collectible campfire stories to get more bonuses, skills, and backstory for your crew. These campfire stories do make it easier to beat the game without dying quite so much.
+ Great sound design. Characters don't talk, but they do make Sims-esque, barely intelligble noises during battle that are great.
+ TONS of achievements.
+ Interesting fight mechanics (see earlier)

Neutral:
~ Great variety of difficulty settings, but even easy is not free of death or total party death.
~ Some people might get bored by the lack of a long campaign. Just 5 expeditions and the game is *basically* over and you have to restart, and there aren't a ton of different exhibitions. I've played 117 hours thus far, so it doesn't bother me.
~ A lot of reading. It's nice that you can cycle through it really fast, and it has great flavor to it, and sometimes hints as to what choice to make for which outcome, but I skip it most of the time and just look at the choices. It often means missing vital information.

Cons:
- You can't move after you attack? What the hell?

You will collect a metric sh*t-ton of stuff. You will murder friendly sheep. You will slap people. Dinosaurs will wiggle their butts at you in taunting. Scotsmen will punch you. You can die via friendly thumbs-up. Just play this game. It is fun. It will make you smile. If it doesn't, you are dead inside.

30596250.review:
Je ne savais pas trop à quoi m'attendre avec ce jeu, si ce n'est que le concept me semblait bien sympa et que le jeu est développé/édité par Abbey Games, créateurs de [i]Reus[/i], jeu que j'ai adoré...donc quand il est tombé en offre du jour à -75%, j'ai acheté tout de suite. Et je ne regrette absolument pas cet achat.
Dans [i]Renowned Explorers: International Society[/i], on gère une équipe d'explorateurs dont le but est de devenir la meilleure équipe d'explorateurs au monde, et pour ça il va leur falloir acquérir de la renommée à travers 5 expéditions durant lesquelles ils vont faire des découvertes, récolter des trésors et trouvailles, et amasser richesses, études et réputation.
Cela dépend comment on joue, mais comptez entre 15 et 30 minutes par expédition, pour souvent une partie entre 2 et 3 heures. La force et l'intérêt du jeu c'est sa rejouabilité, parce que en fonction des personnages que l'on prend et la façon dont on veut jouer, certaines destinations sont plus adaptées que d'autres, et surtout les évènements varient en fonction des personnages et de leurs classes/compétences, donnant accès à d'autres actions et trésors.
Niveau personnages justement, il y a 4 classes : scientifique, scout, combattant, et orateur ("speaker"). Avec 5 personnages par classe, cela nous donne 20 explorateurs différents avec chacun leurs caractères, compétences, attaques, et animations bien sûr. Et comme pour faire une équipe il faut désigner un capitaine et deux autres membres, cela laisse beaucoup de combinaisons possibles.
Concernant les combats, il y a 3 approches : amicale, vicieuse, ou agressive. En fonction des attaques et émotions des personnages et ennemis, les dégâts et effets seront différents. Et en fonction des différentes approches, les évènements et choix et seront différents pendant les expéditions. Encore une fois ici, c'est à vous de choisir comment vous jouez parmi une multitude de choix.
En bref, il y a énormément de contenu dans ce jeu et énormément de possibilité dans la façon de jouer.
Côté musiques et sons, c'est très agréable et réussi, l'ambiance est au rendez-vous. Graphiquement, ça a son style particulier et ça fonctionne vraiment bien. Notez aussi une grosse dose d'humour dans le jeu, que ce soit dans les dialogues, situations, personnages, animations et autres dessins.

Néanmoins si je devais critiquer quelque chose dans le jeu, ce serait sa répétitivité. C'est-à-dire que même si il y a plusieurs façons de résoudre/approcher/subir un évènement, l'évènement en lui-même reste le même, donc on est souvent amené à revoir les mêmes choses à chaque fois qu'on va dans une destination, l'impression de nouveauté n'est plus trop là. Mais bon c'est inévitable dans ce genre de jeu. Il y a aussi assez peu d'expéditions à faire. Il y a tout de même une bonne dizaine de destinations différentes, mais lors de la deuxième partie on fait celles qu'on n'a pas fait pendant la première, et à part 2 ou 3 autres destinations tutos inclus on a fait le tour une première fois. C'est une critique sans en être une, c'est plutôt une remarque, l'impression que j'ai eu en jouant, je m'attendais juste à plus de destinations je pense.

Mais malgré ça, [i]Renowned Explorers: International Society[/i] est un super jeu que je vous recommande vivement. Bien que répétitif, j'y ai quand même passé un peu plus de 20 heures et je n'ai pas encore fini tout ce que je voulais faire. Le système de jeu bien pensé et complet plait et donne envie de repartir à l'aventure avec de nouveaux personnages.

30590403.review:
Pour faire très court : Un bon jeu, original et à petit prix !

Pour faire plus long : Un jeu qui n'a rien de "petit" et qui m'a agréablement surpris... C'est un peu un mélange des genres. On retrouve des éléments du rogue-like, du RPG, du jeu d'aventure mais aussi un peu de gestion.

Concrètement, une partie se déroule en cinq expéditions. Durant chacune de ces expéditions, vous aurez un certain nombre de déplacements et de rencontres sur un plateau, jusqu'à arriver à un trésor. Vous devrez y accéder en évitant soigneusement les pièges que rencontreront les membres de votre équipe. En théorie ! Entre vos expéditions, vous aurez accès à un écran "mondial" qui vous permettra de vous ravitailler en stuff, soutiens d'expédition, lancer des recherches... une foultitude de décisions vous attendent, que vous devrez prendre en fonction de votre équipe mais aussi en fonction de ce que vous souhaitez en faire.

Le jeu s'adapte à tous les profils de joueurs et de joueuses : vous voulez des parties ardues et punitives ? Commencez le jeu en mode Aventure dans les difficultés supérieures, vous aurez votre content de rage. Vous êtes plutôt du genre à vous raconter des histoires dans votre tête ? Vous avez envie qu'on soit gentil avec vous ? Passez la difficulté en "exploration", et tous vos soucis (ou presque!) auront disparu...

Il y a beaucoup, beaucoup de choses à faire et à voir dans ce jeu. Que ce soit en contenu à explorer, découvrir, lire... il y a plein de petites choses qui apparaissent au fur et à mesure, dont je ne parlerai pas ici pour ne pas vous gâcher une éventuelle surprise. Ce qui est certain, c'est que ce jeu est un peu plus qu'un simple jeu d'aventure et d'exploration. ;)

Bref, sans être un OVNI, ce jeu n'a pourtant pas vraiment d'équivalent à l'heure actuelle (et à ma connaissance). Si vous avez la possibilité de vous faire une idée par une démo, profitez-en. Autrement, je pense que vous ne risquez pas grand chose à vous lancer dans Renowned Explorers, surtout soldé !
