30287726.review:
Renowned Explorers: International Society is a game that is stands out from the pack and is not like any other game you've played. One playthrough of the game only takes about 5 hours, but this isn't a game where you just play it once. You need to play through it multiple times to get the most out of it. The good thing is that there is tons of replaybility to the game.

First off, you have 16 characters to choose from in order to make a team of 3. Each one of those characters has unique starting stats, and different skill sets divided into four different classes. On *top* of that, each character has a special ability that gets put into place when they are the captain of the team, but in order to unlock 12 of the characters to use as captains, you need to play through one full game using those characters. So you have plenty of incentive to try different teams to see who works well together and unlock the additonal characters as captains.

In addition to that, since there are multiple locations you can visit in a single playthrough, but can only visit five in total, you can taking a totally different route each time. Even if you take the same route, the nodes on the maps can be different each time, or you might end up being able to tackle different challenges with different team members, or being able to take a different approach to certain situations can change things up significantly. In each of the five playthroughs I've had, I've experienced very little repetition.

Oh, and one more thing. You have multiple difficulty settings, ranging from Easy, up to Impossible. There's also two modes available; Discovery, which allows for saving/loading anytime, and Adventure, which is an Ironman-style, every decision counts type of mode that turns this into a roguelike. Since you can use any of the four difficulties on either of the two modes, you effectively have EIGHT different difficulty settings.

Of course, there has to be enjoyable gameplay to make you want to play through it again and again, and this game offers that in spades. You have a world map, where you can spend 'Insight' that you earn to acquire resources like status, gold, and research, all of which you can then spend in various shops to improve your crew members. 

From there, you go to one of the expeditions, travel through various nodes exploring what you can based on your supplies, which deplete as you travel. Each node can offer different challenges and encounters that will reward you with resources and treasure as you progress towards the final boss of the map.

Now, your ultimate goal in all of this is acquire more then 2500 renown and become the worlds most renowned explorer, and you earn this renown through treasures, and from the various resources depending on how you play the game. It is actually fairly deep and complex so I'll leave it to you to figure out yourself, but once you get it figured out, it's very rewarding.

The most enjoyable part of the game, at least for me personally, is the encounter system. It's based around emotions; you can be aggressive, which is your standard just 'beat the crap out of everyone' type of thing; but then have devious abilities, which consist of taunting and mocking your opponent to make them angry, sad and scared; or you can even use friendly moves to make them worship you in amazement, or convince them that your cause is the best one. The battles can change drastically depending on which mood you use, and what your opponent decides to use. Also, resolving specific encounters in different ways offers different rewards, and depending on who is in your team of three, you might be better suited to one type of mood or another. There's a bit of a rock/paper/scissors deal with the emotions, but sometimes it's not as simple as using the right emotion at the right time. Again, I'll leave the intricate parts of this system for you to figure out.

If you hadn't figured it out yet, I 100% recommend this game to everyone who's a fan of turn based games, as this offers something completely different from the normal stuff you find. The replay value alone is worth the money, along with excellent developers, a welcome community, and weekly challenges available from the forums that you can try your hand at for bragging rights. 

Bottom line: go buy the game and get to exploring!

30265071.review:
This is a cool little game that combines rouge-like elements with tactical RPG battles.  The UI isn't as polished at it could be, but the gameplay more than makes up for it.  It's one of those games that you can play for an hour, and then walk away from if need be.  It's pretty difficult, but certainly rewarding.  

Also in regards to the battle system, I think it's really cool that fighting isn't the only way to solve conflict.  You can get through battles by being 'nice' or 'devious' in addition to just smashing the opponent.  These three techniques are kind of a rock-paper-scissors kind of thing, so be wary of which one you're using for each encounter.

I'm only ~12 hours in at the time of this review, but I'm confident that I'll be playing plenty more.  Excellent game!

30248441.review:
RE:IS is excellent at what it tries to do, but might not be right for everyone.

RE:IS is highly polished, runs flawlessly on Win10 and is a refreshing take on D&D style games where you send a group of explorers into dungeons/wilderness in search of treasure. With cartoonish charm, they have reduced death and violence and substituted  manipulation, charm and seduction instead. A welcome change to killing everybody all day all night! Violence is one of 3 options. Instead of Hit Points, the battle is won when Resolve (the will to go on) is reduced to 0.

With four classes to choose from, you create a team of 3 exlorers and send them on 5 expeditions, returning to town in between. In town, you improve your gear and skills and level up your toons. After 5 expeditions, the game is over. There are a few maps to choose from but not a huge number, but you can replay them with a different team, skills and gear later. There is some randomness to how the maps are generated and play, but each map is a story, and the bullet points of the story are the same each time. Each time you play the Hungarian Fort map, you are seeking The Alchemist, for example.

As an older gamer, I find some of the graphics and sound effects a bit childish but simultaneously charming. And the ability to use speech instead of violence is totally overdue in this kind of game - VERY refreshing. This game will not be a life-replacement game for most people, but it is fun, solid and without any bugs that I could find. None. Very easy to get 50 hours of fun. I will probably get 200 out of it utlimately. Some people complain about the RNG, but I did not find that to be a problem. Yes, if you chose a boss fight, you might get swatted hard, but if you prepared properly and chose wisely beforehand, you will probably be OK.

30242191.review:
When I started to play, I fell in love with this game right from the start. Here is why:

1) gameplay mechanics. Simple to understand, yet different from any other games I have played. You can approach every fight the way you want - be friendly about it, scare them off or fight them directly. Mix in emotions and moods, and you have a hell of a fight.
2) art style. It is cartoonish, but in a good way.
3) great replay value, even if some playthroughs take away from you only 2 - 4 hours (you may want to increase difficulity or switch modes where the game takes longer time to complete and there are no chance of saving as well).
 4) While some games give u the feeling of Deja Vu (the feeling - you have been there and done that), this game is a complete opposite - it gave me this unique experience.

Overall an A+ game. I would recommend this product to everyone who likes the thrill of excitement exploring and discovering new worlds.

30227190.review:
Achievement kasmak istiyorsanız uzun süre oynayabileceğiniz bir oyun.
Ancak ingilizcenizin yetersiz olduğunu düşünüyorsanız kesinlikle uzak durun derim. Zira oyundaki seçimler çok önemli ve textler oldukça önemli bir kısmı kapsıyor. Hikayeler ve mizahi durumlar da bir diğer önemli unsur.

Öncelikle oyundan hoşlanmanızın muhtemel olduğu durumlar:

*İlk olarak tabii ki strateji seviyorsanız,
*Oyun turn-based combat; Tur bazlı mücadele seviyorsanız,
*Tarih ve kurgu hikaye seviyorsanız,
*Oyunlarda ırk ve ırklara özgün eklemelerden hoşlanıyorsanız,    (Bkz: Turban, Ottoman's etc..)
*HC olayından hoşlanıyorsanız,  (Oyun achievementları genel olarak HC üzerinden. yani save'i geri alma şansınız yok öldüğüzde tayfanız siliniyor.)
*Mizahi bir dili mevcut, okurken gülmeyi istiyorsanız,
*Progressive mantığını seviyorsanız. (Oyunda sürekli gelişim halindesiniz ve yeni opsiyonlara sahip olmayı, farklı karakterleri deneyimlemeyi istiyorsanız sabırla oynamaya devam etmelisiniz. Ve birçok kez ölmeyi de göze almalısınız :)..  )
*Son olarak hırslı biriyseniz beğeneceğinizi düşünüyorum. Çünkü oyun sizi kolaylık derecesiyle aptal yerine koyup, zekanızla alay etmek yerine, zekanızı ve daha da önemlisi şansınızı test etmenizi mümkün kılıyor.


Yalnız sürekli hikaye okumaktan, seçim yapmaktan veya tıklamaktan rahatsız oluyorsanız pek size göre olduğunu söyleyemem. Ayrıca oyunda şiddetten çok arkadaşça tavır gerekli oluyor :) 
Yani vur kır parçala hebele hübele yapmadan efendi efendi üslubunuzla takılmanız daha faydalı.

Dipnot: Kwame Amanquatia adlı inançlarına bağlı, 120 cmlik kabile üyesi abimiz oyundaki en işlevsel karakter bence.
Yanına bir tank koyarak ''Dance'' yeteneğini kullanıp, tankı öne attığınızda almış olduğu defansla birlikte  tankı çok güçlü bir hale getirebilirsiniz. Tabii arkadan tankı, abimizin healer yetenekleriyle desteklemeniz gerekiyor. Bir de üstüne 
''+Bonus dmg. when excited'' lı bir şey takarsanız tanka, tamamdır. Neyse, çok uzatırım ben burayı. alın gitsin, güzel oyun.

30226203.review:
Amazing game! Buy it!

It takes the "dungeon delver" genre to a truly unique place. If you like rogue-like games, or adventure games, or just want to try something new, buy it!

It does rely on reading comprehension, and the many new mechanics perhaps takes a while to master, but it has a good tutorial. Think while you play, and don't be afraid of losing, and you will be fine.

Now, it does have some flaws. Most notably, it lacks a real end game. The goal of the game is to get 2500 Renown in 5 expeditions, but if you play the game sort of half-decent, even on harder difficulties, you will get way more than that ( have ended with more than 4000 when playing Iron man mode). Sometimes you get to that amount on 4 expeditions, and if so, the last expedition loses much of its thrills. I was expecting something to happen after the fifth expedition and the end of the game, but no. If you have enough Renown, you win. 

So, the real challenge of the game is not to gather 2500 Renown at all. The challenge is to survive till the end!

The game is still in development, and another expansion is in the works, so perhaps a new end game will be added. Even if not, the game is still loads of fun. 

Buy it!

30214555.review: très bonne surprise sur les 10 premières z'heures de jeu.C'est vraiment super agréable d'explorer :)  Je recommande même s'il on entrevoit assez vite les limites (notamment du mode combat)

30200535.review:
Turn-Based Strategy is one of my favorite game genres, dating back to the original Age of Mythology and Age of Wonders.  (I like a bit more of a fantastical edge to my strategy games).  I'm also a fan of old school RPG's like Icewind Dale and Baldur's Gate that require you to work with the strength and weaknesses of a team to be successful.  That being said, Renowned Explorers has elements of these games, but also somehow presents a concept I've never really seen before.  And they do it well.  

The game is high in replayability, mental strategy, and unique gameplay.  It offers a range of difficulty settings, but even the lowest offering presents enough of a challenge to make it not seem like just a point-and-click.  I particularly enjoy the multitude of offerings to enhance your team at the end of each campaign, with the ability to spend the spoils of your exploration not just on items, but also on helpful followers, researched enhancements and paid jobs.  

The only thing I've disliked so far is how they keep the goal of becoming the top explorer in a short amount of campaigns as part of the gameplay even after the tutorial, making continuation after that achievement seem a little less important, even though there are plenty of campaigns available at that time.  They also cap the growth of the group members to five  new skills, which is generally reached right at or soon after becoming "Top Explorer".  I haven't played the Adventure Mode, nor have I looked at what the DLC has to offer, so maybe some of this is remedied there.

All in all, I highly recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a new, enjoyable twist on turn-based strategy.

30199350.review: It's boring, has a nonsense system (in which you perform friendly moves after beating the shit out of your enemies, and for some nonsense reason, it not only works but it's the way it's mean to be played), tediously repetitive and no replayability what so ever, unless your standards are very low and you enjoy repetitive shit over and over.

30186070.review:
This game is truly amazing, although I may be saying that due to my love of exploration and collectables. Nevertheless, I almost cannot fault Renowned Explorers in any way - the gameplay for example is intense but rewarding, the combat being different to what you might expect in a very good way, utilising a peculiarly mini-Civilization style of game progression.

RE:IS has more going for it than just the gameplay, though - the artwork in particular is incredible, and can honestly I am in love with the gorgeous art style and humurous atmosphere, as well as the color scheme and everything you can see on screen; it's all beautiful. As previously said I find it difficult to fault any part of the game, although as a warning to those not aware:

Renowned Explorers is set up to engage you in multiple playthroughs, and so each completion of a new game (with the DLC) adds more content during your 5 expeditions per game, and by the fourth or fifth playthrough you will have a much better understanding of the game and its mechanics. If this puts you off, for example if you prefer a larger campaign in your games, then maybe this is simply not the game for you. However if this excites you then go ahead and buy Renowned Explorers: International Society ASAP; it might just be up your alley.

30185881.review:
FTL+덕테일즈+택틱스 스타일의 로그라이크 게임

세계 곳곳을 다니며 탐험을 하고 명성을 높여서 경쟁자를 제치고 1등 모험가가 되는 게 목적이다. 기본은 로그라이크라서 세이브, 로드에 제약이 있고 죽으면 끝난다. 하지만 일반 게임처럼 세이브, 로드가 자유로운 디스커버리 모드가 있어 스트레스 덜 받고 게임을 할 수도 있다.

과학자, 스카우트, 파이터, 달변가의 네가지 직업 20명의 캐릭터 중 3명을 골라서 모험을 떠난다. 직업이나 캐릭터별로 특성이 다르고 게임 자체도 길지 않기 때문에 조합을 달리해 가면서 다회차 플레이를 하게 된다.

일단 모험에 들어서면, FTL처럼 갈래길을 한 칸씩 움직이며 진행한다. 도착한 장소에서 다양한 이벤트가 벌어지고 때로는 전투도 한다. 각각의 이벤트는 텍스트 위주로 진행되지만 영어가 크게 어렵지 않고, 선택지에 따른 결과나 성공확률 등이 표시되므로 진행에 어려움이 없다. 해당 지역을 돌아다니며 수집, 발견, 학습, 탐색 등의 점수를 얻는다. 이동에는 물자를 소비하며 물자가 떨어진 상태로 움직이면 능력치가 떨어지므로 잘 따져가면서 이동해야 한다. 물자를 얻는 이벤트도 있다. 

전투는 택틱스 스타일에 좀 캐주얼한데, 분위기 시스템이란 게 있다. 전투는 평화, 기만, 공격의 3가지 형태로 이루어지는데, 평화는 적을 칭찬하거나 자신를 뽐내거나 하는 등의 행동을, 기만은 위협이나 조롱 등의 행동을, 공격은 말 그대로 물리적인 공격으로 적의 전의를 꺾는다. (HP가 아니라 Spirit이다.) 특정 분위기의 행동을 주로 하면 전황 자체가 그 분위기로 바뀌는데, 그에 따라 전체적인 밸런스가 바뀐다. 공격적인 분위기에는 기만이 잘 통하고, 평화적 분위기엔 공격이 잘 통하는 등 가위바위보의 상성관계가 있고 캐릭터별로 분위기에 따른 강약이 있다. (적도 마찬가지.) 여기에 전투를 어떤 분위기로 끝내느냐에 따라 보상도 다르기 때문에 나름 신경을 쓰면서 해야 한다. (중간 난이도 이상은 전투 자체도 쉽지 않다.)

모험을 끝내면 얻은 각종 점수들은 돈이나 지위, 연구, 명성으로 전환된다. 문명세계?로 돌아와 여러 학회에서 성과를 발표하여 보상을 얻는다. 이걸로 아이템을 구입하고 각종 특성을 올려주는 조력자를 얻으며 여러 수치를 높여주는 연구를 하여 팀을 강화해 나간다. 이런 식으로 5회의 모험을 끝내면 된다. 엔딩은 따로 없지만 최종 목적지인 샹그릴라에서 라이벌 마튜 리발로를 물리치고 1등을 하는 게 진엔딩인 듯.

게임이 전반적으로 아기자기하고 코믹한 느낌에 1회 플레이 시간이 길지 않아 부담없이 할 수 있다. (게임 모드와 난이도에 따라서는 엄청난 스트레스를 받으며 진행할 수도...) 다회차 플레이가 기본인 것치고는 모험할 곳이 많지 않은 건 단점이지만 게임이 꾸준이 업데이트를 하고 있으니 늘어날 여지는 있다.

30183829.review: An amazing tactical game that will you keep you entertained for a good few hours. This game has a lot of secrets as the game suggest and it's fun to unlock new things. Definitely recommend it. (I got it on sale)

30176595.review: Renowned Explorers: International Society is not your typical party-based RPG/Adventure game. I'm not even a good example to review this product, since this this is not my game genre, but when I bought it I decided to take a shot in the dark and, oh boy, was I glad I did... This game can suck an entire day out of your life simply because you are having too much fun with it and not even realizing. The sense of progression (the RPG part) is extremely satisfying: Every time you get a new perk or a new item for your charecter, you end up rediscovering the entire game. The sense of a strong party is also really good, since after three or four "encounters" (battles), you get a hold of your entire deck and understand the roles which your charecters will assume once in battle to achieve maximum efficiency. Of course the game's focous is the adventure you see yourself in and the infinite deck of possibilities is what really makes it fun. Choosing who is going to do what in a certain event decides everything you'll get from an exploration. To top it off, I'd just like to add how the devs perfectly integrated a dynamic combat system, with nine different variables that affect the gameplay, all of which depend on a charecters emotional strength, mood and defense power. You can learn more about this in the store page or just buyin' the game already, cause that is going to be my final point: Even if nothing in this review called your attention, many other things in-game will, being why I strongly suggest that you should buy Renowned Explorers: International Society.

30105024.review: RE:IS takes a simple idea that is feels similar to many other TBS games, and elevates it to a new level. Playing the game once through is quite short, only a few hours if you try to do as much as you can. What makes RE:IS so interesting however is its replayability. Each play-though can be done with different characters, each with their own personality quirks, and the maps will change with every new game. This means that there is a good deal of randomness which takes each short play-through and turns it into a springboard to enhance your subsequent play-through. Each character is quite fun to learn how they act and what their strengths and weaknesses are and this only enhances the play-through, seeing how different pairings lead to better, or worse, teams.

30087084.review: Oh man. I'm not even wuite sure where to begin with this game. This game is great, from it's charming, quirky characters to it's amazing replayability, or even the fun crew stories. the closest thing I can compare it to is a choose-your-own-adventure book, but so much more. Each time you play you find new treasures, new events, sometimes even new enemies. But don't get me wrong, it's still challenging at times, when you're not sure whether to head to the main ruin or explore for some of the minor ones, and you've only got so many supplies left. it takes anywhere from 2-5 hours to beat a game, depending on if you beeline straight for the main ruin or if you traverse the whole map, but it's easy to just hop into a new game  because you're so excited to see what you'll find on your next adventure. I would reccomend this game to anyone, it's a game that's great for young kids or people who aren't as experienced with video games, and even people who consider themselves proffessional gamers will enjoy this.

30072113.review:
Ce jeu est une très belle découverte, sorti en 2015 sur steam ce n'est que maintenant que j'apprends son existence. (Merci les rabais steam)

Le but est simple, faire des explorations, trouver des trésors, augmenter sa renommée et devenir le meilleur des explorateurs. Vous faites une partie (Il existe deux modes) Découverte et aventure. Ainsi que des modes de difficulté. Une fois votre partie terminer vous pouvez en relancer d'autres avec de nouveau chef d'équipage de débloquer. Vous pouvez explorer d'autres endroits que vous n'aviez pas été dans votre partie précédente. Trouvez de nouveau trésors pour remplir votre collections (qui elle ne se reset pas à la fin de chaque partie) Si vous aimez les achievements, c'est aussi un très bon jeu qui est pas ''nul'' et ça donne un objectif suplémentaire.  À chaque fin de lieu explorer vous êtes de retour à Londre et pouvez dépenser vos points de recherches/or/réputations etc pour avoir des bonus, armes etc. Pour vous aider dans vos prochaines explorations. 

+ Graphiquement le style un peu BD est très beau 
+ Les dialogues sont amusants (Par contre seulement en anglais mais avec des bases ça va)
+ La possibilité d'affronter vos adversaires avec 3 modes de combat (Agressif, Amical et surnois)
+ Différents lieu agréables à découvrir
+ Bande sons agréable

- Le jeu est uniquement en anglais donc ça peut être un désavantages pour ceux qui ne le parle vraiment pas.

Cependant, je tiens à dire que je suis pas un expert en anglais mais j'arrive à bien comprendre 90% des textes du jeu

Un gros 8.5/10 

En promo ça vaut encore plus la peine d'acheter le jeu

30067483.review:
Wonderful game, a joy to play.

Hand pick your team of 3 from 20 colorful fighters, scientists, diplomats, and scouts with a wide variety of backgrounds and abilities.  Explore mysterious maps and overcome both text-based skill check challenges and turn-based combat.  Use charm, guile, sheer brute force, or any combination to win over, scare off, or pulverize your enemies as you search for treasure, gather resources and, most importantly, work to uncover the mysteries of the lost world.  But be ready for anything - relying too much on a single strategy will leave you wide open against its "rock, paper, scissors" vulnerability.

Did you play FTL?  Of course you did.  [i]Renowned Explorers[/i] has a very similar structure, in which each expedition is like a "sector".  There are numerous points of interest and limited supplies, forcing you to carefully manage where your explorations take you.

A new addition to the formula is the downtime between expeditions.  Return to London, write research papers, shop for better equipment, gain an entourage, share your findings with prestigious universities.  Fine tune your team to optimize for your particular goals.  (Example: my first team was led by a scientist, and geared towards collecting research, gathering followers and unlocking buffs to magnify the rewards from scientific challenges.)

RPG elements are not fantastically deep, but satisfy quite well enough in context.  Like FTL, this is a game made to buzz through half a dozen adventures, build up to a final tough confrontation, roll credits and start again with a new team and/or on a higher difficulty.

Just about worth it full price, a no-brainer on sale.  Play it!

30064467.review:
Don't get me wrong this isn't exactly a bad game. It just that for somebody who's used to strategic games it gets dull VERY fast. Some review compared it to Final Fantasy Tactics, which couldn't be further from the truth.

The games throws a lot of shiny options at you which seem like a lot of content at first, until you realize that in the end it's heavy rock-paper-scissors combat without further depth, packed in a short campaign with no meaningful story or incentive to be replayed, since the unlocks don't really make your next run that different. (Opposed to say Faster Than Light where ships / layouts play REALLY different)

30030714.review:
Renowned Explorers: International Society is a humorous choose your own adventure style strategy game with rogue-like and RPG elements such as inventory management, turn based combat, dialogue choices, and unique character upgrades/skill trees. The game is set in a vibrant and quirky version of the late 19th century where both magic and quasi-steampunk technology abound, making for an incredibly colorful and interesting world full of weird and wonderful people and places to discover. It is well written, thoroughly enjoyable to play, and suitable for all ages.

The goal of the game is to achieve the title of "Most Renowned Explorer" by assembling a team of intrepid adventurers for the purpose of collecting treasures from various exotic locations around the globe. Each location has its own set of mysteries and treasures to uncover, and every character has his or her own individual backstory and unique personality that can affect their synergy with other characters, your interactions with the environment, and thus your overall chances of success. The team you choose and the decisions you make along the way will determine whether or not you rise to unprecendented heights of fame and glory, or fade into total obscurity... or worse.

The game also features an innovative turn-based combat system that incorporates emotion and mood into the tactical gameplay, allowing for battles to be resolved peacefully as well as by the usual violent means. The result is a 'rock, paper, scissors' style element to fighting that adds quite a lot more depth to combat than the standard RPG fare of merely switching between physical attacks and magic attacks. Choosing to resolve certain conflicts with a particular method can even unlock new dialogue and treasure-hunting opportunities, which makes having to choose between a well rounded team and a highly specialized one all the more compelling.

In conclusion, I highly recommend this title to anyone looking for a truly one of a kind, lighthearted, and endlessly replayable adventure/resource management/strategy game in the spirit of FTL: Faster Than Light or Reus. An instant classic, in my opinion, and one made even better with the addition of the DLC. 

10/10
 
P.S. If you do purchase the game, be sure to check out the weekly challenges hosted on the RE:IS Steam forum for fun stories, friendly competition and lots of extra replay value! :)

29932380.review:
Renowned Explorers (RE) is my kind of game:  quirky, unique, slow-paced, easy to snack on, and just variable enough to motivate repeated plays.  Which is not to say it's without some flaws.

RE defies categorization.  You'll see it described as a "rogue-like" but I think that's a misnomer.  It certainly doesn't feel like one to me.  There's greater characterization and better narrative, and you have a distinct goal (win-condition) beyond just surviving for as long as possible.  Rather, it reminds me of big, theme-heavy adventure-RPG boardgames like Arkham/Eldritch Horror, Runebound, Fortune & Glory, etc.  Collect a party of heroes with different skill-sets, send them to unique locales where they will face challenges (i.e., skill checks) and gain experience & loot.  Then, level them up, buy better equipment, and set out for a tougher but more rewarding expedition.  GIven that I love boardgames, it's perhaps not surprising that I quite like RE.  

For brevity's sake, here's my quick list of pros and cons...

Pros:
1.  The length of a single "campaign" feels just right to me.  In order to win, you need to complete 5 expeditions - with the additional goal of accruing enough Renown to rank higher than all your competitors.  In actual playtime, this can take you around 1-3 hours (depending on how leisurely you are about shopping).  That's perfect for a relaxing Saturday morning with a cup of coffee.

2.  There's a nice ebb and flow to RE.  You go on an expedition, which will involve ~7-15 "encounters" - some of which are battles and some of which are skill-checks.  You'll win most of your skill checks, but there's enough chance for failure that it's still tense when the RNG kicks in.  Combat is interesting and maybe a little muddled (more on that below), but you'll have only a few battles per expedition and, again, that feels just right.  Once the expedition is over, you fly back to London to spend research points, buy better equipment for your crew, and gather an entourage (which boost your ability to collect resources).  The back and forth between exploring and leveling feels great.

3.  There's a fantastic selection of characters to choose from, and it's here where a lot of the replayability in RE comes from.  There are different classes that comes with different starting skills (scientists, scouts, etc.).  There are glass cannons and tanks and everything in between.  You'll want to try another run-through with an entirely different cast.  And these crews will largely determine how you approach combat:  with friendly diplomacy, devious emotional manipulation, or outright violence.  Once you learn the systems of the game, you can start seeing synergies and possible strategies (e.g., choose 3 characters with the ability to terrify and unlock the research tree that enhances the power of terror). 

4.  The difficulty seems tuned just right.  It's tough to win a campaign, but not so tough that you're discouraged and wondering if the designers are sadists.  It took me 3 play-throughs to win my first campaign on the "classic" (hard) difficulty.  It felt good winning and I thought that I had made a lot of solid decisions that helped me get that far.  After 15 hours of play, you'll be able to win most of the time unless you take big risks to try and max your renown.

Cons:
1. There's maybe not enough variability in the expeditions themselves.  I'm already a little tired of seeing the same locations and fighting the same bosses.  This game will really benefit from DLC and mini-content updates.

2.  There's definitely not enough variability in the equipment.  I was disappointed to discover that shops always carry the same stuff, and it never varies between games.  That seems like a missed opportunity to make every run-through feel different.  As it is, I'm already finding myself gravitating towards the same items/build-order on each playthrough.

3.  The combat is opaque at first - and once you discover how it works, I'm not sure if the added complexity is worth the price of admission.  It all depends on whether you're looking for another position-based tactical game (X-COM, etc.) or whether you're willing to try something new.  There's less emphasis on positioning and % hit-rate, and much more emphasis on trying to maximize damage output via manipulation of the innovative emotion system.  On your first couple playthroughs, you'll be largely confused about the variety of effects and modifiers - but if you persist, the tactical layers reveal themselves in a very satisfying fashion.

Overall, I strongly recommend the game.  A great mix of adventure-RPG-tactical gameplay.  One of my favorite gaming experiences of the year so far.

29734541.review:
This is a unique game in many ways, and also very enjoyable. It's not the kind of game where fast clicking or amazing eye hand coordination is much help at all, and for me, that's fantastic. It's a strategy game with some story and a lot of humor, and I find I get very attached to the characters in my party very fast.

(such as screaming 'No Vlad, you can't have Ivan!!!')

The game is set up so you can select a party of three explorers of varying strengths, and you can choose throughout the game how they'll develop.

One of my favorite aspects is that you can choose to be very different explorers from game to game in how you 'battle' those who you encounter. You can be friendly, devious, or outright aggressive, meaning that talking is not a free action anymore and can in fact defeat an opponent, whether through messing with their head or convincing them that you're awesome and they should help you.

I highly recommend this game for its unique approach, its humor, and its art. Also, it's not 'America-centric' in its choices for your explorers, as they come from every continent and many different backgrounds, from a tiny Austrian magician to an Argentine diplomat's daughter to a wild Australian (and of course a loveable Russian giant).

Personally, my favorite explorers are Bia, Daisy, and Anna, but I haven't even gotten to playing all of them yet, so who knows if it'll stay that way.

On the negative side this is not quite a rogue like you won't get through the 2nd playthrough without getting repeat events and by the third or fourth that's all that you'll see.  This game would benefit greatly from user created content but as they seem to only want new content from their DLC that's a major weakness.  Also the classic hard mode "the way the game is meant to be played" is punishing and not in a good way, in a any mis step after the 2nd mission in combat mode will end your adventure, and as this is randomized turn based combat, you can just get unlucky with enemy placement and get into near immpossible situations.  

Overall though I still do recomend this game, it is fun, just doesn't live up to the potential I feel it has with some more polish and the ability for users to generate their own content.

29657645.review:
I reccomend this game despite my issues with it. It's a fairly fun tactics game that has a unique twist on your turn-based battle system. I think the aspect of non-violent victories is interesting, and I love the diverse cast of characters to choose from. Mechanics are enjoyable, although a bit chance based. I actually rather enjoyed the gambling aspect of encounters and also being able to mitigate luck through skills.

However, the issues I've found is that for a game designed around multiple playthroughs, and from having different win possibilities, the gameplay starts to feel a bit repetitive. There big plot points remain identical through playthroughs without new dialogue or different outcomes. I will admit that there are a variety of locations to pick from, and plenty of perhaps unexpelored encounters i did not see that do add variety, but it all funnels back to the same ending for that respective location. Still, overall, a fun game, but if you're like me and bad at these sorts of games despite loving them, you will find yourself dying and starting campaigns over fairly consistently which can be a bit tedious due to the repetition.

One other note I'd make is this game is not optimized well for Mac. I'm on a brand new macbook pro with graphics card and memory both fully upgraded and I still had graphical issues in the skirmishes. I've researched the issue and it seems the general answer from the developer to mac users is to run it through bootcamp with Windows OS. For a game that is not as graphically intense as other games I've played successfully, I was disappointed to see it having such issues.


7/10, buy it through a steam sale!

28927636.review:
If you're looking for an inventive turn based team strategy/adventure game with rogue-like elements, (or you might be after reading all of that), you can't go wrong with this one.  It's got deep wells of style, humor, and strategy, and it's set in a wonderfully re-imagined 19th century. That is to say, it's a 19th century nearly without heavy restrictions on women or colonized peoples and with 100% more cybernetic limbs and tesla weapons.  To be clear, this game is about colonizers and thieves of cultural artifacts, but it lets everyone in on the joke.  The art and animation are worthy of the experience, and the characters prove to have surprising depth.  The strongest suit here are the MANY options for building your party and playing them, with a ton of unique characters and an 'emotion' based combat that you've just never seen before.  It can be played for hours or for a few minutes.  You'll find a treasure trove of things to enjoy if you're still reading.  Without offering too many spoilers, in this game you can:

-Take a team of archaeologists to Egypt, ransacking treasures like the glory days of colonial nostalgia
-Help a sailor grow a beard
-Insult sheep to advance the game
-Have your German professor get everyone drunk
-Punch out a nun and have one of your characters feel awful about it for the rest of the game.  

Bonus points from this anthropologist for having anthropology be the encounter-based research field, even though even 19th century anthropologists rarely engaged other cultures with their fists.  The devious approach, however....

Easily recommended.

Overall, it's quite a nice game. The art style is cartoonish and playful, and the mechanics are smooth and easy to use. The idea of three different approaches (Friendly, Devious, or Aggressive) to your expedition is unique, and it's fun seeing how your choice of emotion affects your opponents. The variety of characters is enjoyable as well, as they all have different personalities and looks. 

But as nice as this all sounds, I can't recommend this game. My initial impression was "oh man! With this many characters and options to customize the difficulty, I'll be playing this game forever!". Unfortunately, I was wrong. After one incredibly short playthrough (took me about three or four hours), I was satisfied. Two days later I started a new game with new characters and a new Agressive approach. To my great disappointment, I found myself terribly bored within the first Encounter (what the battles are called in-game). All the dialogue and text between encounters was almost exactly the same, not to mention the story and plot stayed as dull as ever. I played on, but could not get myself to be nearly as intruiged as I had been during my first playthrough. 

I'd rate Renowned Explorers a lowly 4/10, giving it credit for unique gameplay style that the developers did not expand nearly enough on and the aesthetic art style. The game definitely isn't worth it full price, and hardly worth it on a sale. Sure, put it on your wishlist and get it on sale if you curious, but keep in mind that it will most likely only offer you a few hours of time-killing at most.

28818344.review:
SUMMARY: A fun, clever, challenging, and character-filled "exploration and Tactical RPG roguelike" set in a fictional 19th century.  Manage a party of explorers, choose different ways to deal with enemies and challenges, unlock mysteries, and try to become the most renown explorer ever. There's a lot to do and find - and you can play an entire game in an hour or less . . . then do it again.  A must-buy for fans of good adventure/SRPG games.

Renowned Explorers: International Society takes place in a fictional 19th century where Exploring is the big thing, and most countries get along to sponsor investigations of the mysterious phenomena of the world - and find all sorts of amazing treasures.  You're running one of these adventuring groups seeking fame, fortune, and of course to show up that complete jerk Rivaleux with the great hair that keeps ruining EVERYTHING by finding it.

Plus, you get to do this your way.  The game is all about choice:

* Select a party of 3 adventurers from 4 differnt types (Scientists, Scouts, Fighters, and Speakers).  Each adventurer is a unique personality with special abilities, skills, looks, and even backstories you can unlock.
* Send them forth on adventures where you travel strange lands seeking fortune, fame, information, encounters, treasures, and occasionally lost sheep and llamas.
* Face assorted challenges that will test your skills and planning (or at least risk management), and weigh your options wisely.
* Exchange campfire stories to boost your abilities or find out more about your crew - and watch them develop
* Have them enter into conflict with assorted inhabitants and enemies, and decide how to handle the issues - friendliness, deception, or aggression.  Abilities and your options change as you use them and as the "mood" of battle shifts.  You could find yourself sending an enemy home in a body bag, off crying, or have them decide you're a great person and leave you alone.
* Improve your characters as they gain experience, with new skills abilities.
* Return home with treasures you find or select.
* Upgrade your research, hire helpers and specialists, buy equipment, and even deliver lectures to raise resources.  As you explore more, Exporer groups will help you out, further increasing options.
* Head towards the inevitable conflict with famous explorer and walking smug grin Rivaleux to show him up as best explorer!
* As you play keep unlocking more possible lead characters, extra stories to tell around the campfire, and more.
* Try and find every treasure and campfire story.  Oh and beat Rivaleux!
* Participate in various weekly challenges.

Renown explorers packs in adventure, mystery, choice, resource management, three kinds of conflicts, and plenty of humor - and a campaign takes at most an hour to play!  Since each game often unlocks more options after you play, you can try it again with a new mix of characters, new leaders, new stories, and randomized settings.

Along with the great game play is excellent graphic design, with a colorful cartoony world, a good soundtrack, and snappy writing.  The game is even self-aware of how bizarre it's world is, with characters commenting on and embodying old tropes of pulps and victorian adventure with gleeful self-awareness.

On top of all of this there's a great tutorial and clear controls, so it's easy to pick up for people who aren't always into the tactical RPG genre.

So who should by this game?
* First and foremost, if "easy to play/hard to master roguelike cartoony Tactical RPG with base management" pushes your buttons you should buy this.
*If you like a good character-optimizing and exploration-focused adventure game, you'll enjoy this.  Getting things "just right" is a challenge.
* If you're looking for a fun rouglike RPG - though this is more map-point exploring than corridor-crawling with tactical battle over simple click-and-fight.

It's hard NOT to reccomend this game to people, it's that much fun, that easy to pick up, that challenging.  Except to Rivaleux, he's a jerk.

This game was an instant favourite of mine and it still is. Usually I buy a game, get lost in it for a while and then don't touch it again for months. This isn't the case with Renowned Explorers, so I'm going to tell you why it seems to be a perfect game for me and why you will love it, at least if our gaming preferences are similar.

It's easy to learn. You can get started right away, the tutorial blends in nicely with the campaign and is not too long. Also, if you don't play for a few weeks you won't have forgotten how to play or where you were in your campaign. The combat system is very creative and cute, easy enough to learn but you can play it the hard way if you want to. Replayability is high because of the many different ways you can build your team and the different approaches you can take. Since the expeditions are slightly randomized you can visit them again and again, with different teams and different approaches. It comes as a cute clicking game, but has actual depth and demands you have a plan and some tactics. 

The graphics are absolutely cute, I love all the explorers, the other characters and the little animations of their attacks. It's varied and funny. This one time I insulted a nun and she got really sad. This game fulfiils my childhood dream of becoming a celebrated explorer and my adulthood dream of insulting random people.

The first DLC did not only bring new expeditions, but new mechanics as well, it's definitely worth the price. I hope the developers will continue to enrich this great game.

28266949.review:
Like the previous title Reus from this studio, Renowned Explorers (REIS?) suffers from similar flaws in the shape of a steep learning curve which requires you to memorize a lot of some obscure game elements and mechanics. Also like Reus, it is a pleasantly unique and colorful game which art style is adapted to any age while gameplay definitely has some suitable to a mature audience depth to it. Note that I only played the game with the DLC "more to explore" and is fully part of this review.

So in RE you manage a team of 3 explorers from a pool of 20 and from 4 different classes each with it unique abilities, bonuses and (minimalistic) skill trees. You start with choosing a captain which gives you a specific bonus and 2 crew member and you jump in directly into the adventure with the supplies you have. Your main goal is to reach a point of the map where your final encounter for this expedition is while trying to gather as much tokens, treasures and bonuses as you can. At the end of each expedition, your tokens will be automatically converted into the 3 ressources of the game which are used to buy gear, hire helpers and specialists and perform research (all of which provides you various bonuses). You will also get "renown" from many of your actions and from the token conversion, which is actually a reflection of your score.

Between expeditions you can use all those ressources, plus one that is called "insight" which allows you to perform jobs to receive extra tokens, to improve your characters and team but also improve the token rewards for the next mission. Unfortunately a run in the game is pretty short as you will do 5 expeditions for the ladder ranking and you can then finish all the expeditions on the map if you like and this "reward at the end" system pretty much is not backed up by an actual proper game ending, as when you do your last expedition, unless you care about the score, you will simply not care about gathering anything and will just go to the end encounter as safely as possible.

Another thing I have noticed in my own (succesful) playthrough is that you may end up with too much of a ressource and no use anymore for it. Typically, with an economic and fame oriented team I ended up with several thousands of gold and reputation in reserve and nothing to spend it on in the last few expeditions so it was just accumulating. There as well, there could be improvements.

There is a nice system of unlock which is motivational as you need to complete some expeditions with some characters to be able to use them as captain and also unlock "campfire stories" (cards) which can give significant bonuses to your party. So there is plenty to do and some replay value in the game, although once you got a bit of experience you will easily recognize (and predict) all the events and encounters that you may find on each specific expedition, although randomly placed on the map, those are rigid and linear scripts. A bit more diversity/procedural generation would not hurt there as well as maybe more customisable starting options (i.e. expanded ladder for more expeditions).

"Combat" phases can be difficult especially when you want to keep a specific "mood" for the fight, as even with high defenses you are almost always outnumbered by the opponent forces and it comes down to placing and getting rid in anyways of enough opponent as fast as possible. The friendly, devious and aggressive stances are an interesting system as it encourages you to use certain abilities instead of others and in certain proportions even when the opponent are highly resistant (or even immune) to the attacks of those stances. Quite challenging are Boss fights and elite encounters which keep spawning minor mobs and are about balancing between eliminating reinforcements and taking on the high damage and life (spirit) boss to end the fight.

Several events trigger the RNG god and the odds are determined by the skill composition of your team members and it is up to you to decide (although sometimes you just have the choice between bad, worse and very worse) to have an audience or not with the divinity of randomness. Some of those events may even cause you to lose "resolve" (your life pool, which means game over when it reaches 0).

Despite the replay value (due to unlocks, as the content itself is pretty easy to discover in just a few runs), you can already feel the game is definitely meant to be further expanded (the world map has much more empty space to fill) by some other DLC(s). I hope that some of the game mechanics of the base game will be improved and some of the "issues" I highlighted (i.e. ressources becoming useless in the end game, lack of procedurally generated nodes, bad end game mechanics, etc.) will be acknowledged by the devs and fixed.

Though I may sound pretty critical of the product I still highly recommend it. If you are an optimizer or completionist, there is definitely material here to keep you busy for hundreds of hours. If you are just willing to go through the game once, well it is a very enjoyable experience and considering you may have to restart a few times it will also keep you busy for a bit of time.

27804977.review:
Renowned Explorers, пожалуй, один из самых стильных рогаликов последних лет. За мультяшно-забавным визуальным стилем скрывается достаточно хардкорная (или не очень - спасибо разработчикам за прикрученную возможно выбирать сложность) и глубокая игра.

Цель игры проста: пройти своей командой исследователей 5 экспедиций и стать более известным исследователем, чем местный герой Ревалю. Победить его можно, как встретившись лицом в лицу в последней экспедиции, так и заочно, однако во втором случае удовольствие будет не полным.

Свой ролевой потенциал игра показывает уже на этапе выборе команды: от того, кто из многочисленных персонажей станет лидером, а кто двумя помощниками. Все герои делятся на 4 категории: учёные, бойцы, дипломаты и скауты, а так же имеют свои отличительные черты и способности. Так, некоторые из них предпочитают грубую силу, другие же - острое слово. Именно от набора качеств команды и будет зависеть стиль игры, а следовательно, и экспедиции, которые лучше посещать.

В заключение хочется добавить, что игра пронизана тонким юмором и духом лучших частей Индианы Джонса.

Пожалуйста, поиграйте в Renowned Explorers - это очень хорошая, но не очень известная игра. Дайте ей шанс и вы, скорее всего, не разочаруетесь.

Renowned Explorers Internacional Society é um jogo desafiador, não deixe sua aparência enganar, nele você controla um grupo de aventureiros que procura a glória de alcançar o mais alto posto dentre os exploradores de um famoso clube. O jogo tem diversos elementos pulps que você encontra em literatura e filmes do gênero como Indiana Jones, Tarzan, Zorro, Doc Savage, Rocketeer, o Sombra e a Liga Extraordinária. A ambientação é cartunesca, leve, bem humorada e situada no século XIX. Uma época em que desbravar continentes misteriosos e encontrar civilizações perdidas eram o auge da conquista.
Você escolhe três dentre uma seleção de 20 exploradores das mais variadas personalidades, etnias e raízes. Cada um deles tem uma especialização composta por uma combinação de habilidades e perícias que se enquadram em 3 abordagens: Amistosa, Malandra e Agressiva.

Uma vez escolhido o grupo, você escolhe entre seguir o tutorial (altamente recomendado) ou ser jogado de cara numa primeira expedição, curta e simples. Mesmo sendo a primeira expedição, a chance de derrota logo de cara é muito real. Os chefes são crueis e o próprio jogo te avisa isso.

Boa parte do jogo será você escolhendo o percurso no mapa que menos gasta mantimentos, decidindo como melhor resolver pequenos desafios e combater os oponentes dos exploradores.
Combate esse que é resolvido num intricado sistema de pedra-papel-tesoura que utiliza da interação das 3 abordagens com buffs e debuffs (melhorias e penalidades temporárias) causados pelos personagens de formas positivas e negativas. O resultado são escorpiões sendo impressionados a ponto de desistirem, piratas sendo intimidados por velhinhas e lobos ferozes tão confusos que acham melhor simplesmente sair do combate. É lógico que a tendência de certos oponentes é seguir a abordagem mais lógica à sua natureza, porém o jogador não é obrigado a fazer o mesmo.
Durante a expedição você precisa ficar o atento o tempo todo à sua determinação (resolve) que se reduzida a zero significa o fim do jogo.

A outra parte importante do jogo é resolvida num mapa mundi onde o jogador deve gerenciar seus recursos adquiridos na forma de fama, estudo e ouro para ampliar as capacidades de seus exploradores e assim avançar no jogo. Além do mais, esses mesmos recursos podem gerar quantias variadas de renome que serão determinadas pelas melhorias adquiridas nas árvores tecnológicas. Quanto mais renome, maior será seu placar final. 

A diferença crucial deste jogo em comparação aos outros ditos rogue-like (que assim como este são apenas roguelite) é que ele quer ser difícil para esfregar isso na sua cara e te afastar do jogo. Ele te mostra de antemão que a cada jogada você pode planejar o seu próximo movimento. Dicas de como proseguir baseado no seu estilo de jogo vão aparecer quase que em todas as telas e interações do jogo e isso por si só já é um atrativo ao gênero.

Renowned Explorers International Society foi a maior surpresa de 2015 e me proporcionou horas de entretenimento no último mês do ano. Espero que ele também divirta você!

Si scelgono 3 avventurieri, ognuno con proprie caratteristiche e abilità, e si parte all'avventura per dissotterrare tesori nascosti ai quattro angoli del mondo. Per la verità le mappe sono abbastanza limitate, ma la rigiocabilità è ugualmente molto alta, grazie al numero di personaggi presenti e ai mille percorsi e approcci diversi che potremo scegliere durante il nostro viaggio. Non mancheranno i combattimenti contro animali e avventurieri ostili, che potremo di volta in volta affrontare con atteggiamento aggressivo, sfrontato o persino amichevole, riducendo talvolta le battaglie ad esilaranti scontri dialettici, con cuoricini volanti e nemici che si ritirano dalla lotta perché ci amano troppo! 27716258.review:
This game has a lot going for it. The most obvious thing would probably be the interesting artstyle that makes the game very unique and helps it stand out from its rogue-lite competition.  
However there is a bit more to the game than just repeating similar procedually generated environments over and over again. Most rogue-likes I have seen so far, do not have a really indepht combat system, but RE:IS is one of the rare exceptions to that. The turn-based strategical combat system has an asounding amount of depth, even though it is relatively easy to explain and get started in, really getting the hang of the system and using it to its fullest potential takes time, but esspecially on the higher difficulties you will not be able to succeed unless you make use of every possibility you have. I will not lie, the game is not easy and there are random elements at basically every corner, but one thing the game is very clear about is always showing you exactly how high your chance of succeeding is and in most cases bowing out of the risky challanges is an option aswell.  
The game is centered around repeating playthroughs, each time starting of with a new crew. This of course means that there is mostly no influence from your previous playthroughs, except your own increase in skill and understanding. Even though different team compositions will generally result in different playthroughs, even playing the same team can give you a different experience as there are slight changes made to the events you might encounter each time you start a new campaign. This increases the feeling of never beeing 100% certain what you will find in a certain location, even though you have played through the game several times, which ties nicely into the exploration theme. 

Overall this is a really good game that ties tactical combat and FTL style exploration into one neat package.

27547171.review:
I, like many, have a Pavlovian weakness for turn-based strategy games. Late into the night, I find myself wondering WHY OH WHY I have been compulsively playing Civilization for hours, when there's hardly a lick of story to care about as you progress and battles are formulaic.

Not so Renowned Explorers! I picked up the game primarily for its adventure-explorer narrative; as a person who named their pet rabbit after the leader of the "Kon-Tiki" expedition, how could I not? The premise is remarkably well done: it's full of tongue-in-cheek humor and bizarre excursions to exotic locales, vying for the renown of the global exploration community. 

What really shines about this game for me is the blend of mechanics. First and foremost, the fact that you can choose three different styles of combat for most of your encounters (Friendly, Devious, Aggressive) provides a fun and engaging challenge. Part of the reason I love RPGs is because they offer alternative options to combat such as talking your way out of trouble. Renowned Explorers pulls these approaches into its combat scenarios by providing characters with separate stats for physical combat and "speech" combat. Balancing the different strengths of your crew in each encounter makes it more nuanced than just having the biggest guns in the game. 

In addition to more varied combat options, crew set-ups make this game extremely replayable. You pick three people as your expedition crew, and the characters' different skill sets make each combo play very differently. 

Finally, this is an adventure game afterall, so strategy elements, while present, don't take up all your time. You can buy gear, perform research, recruit assistants, and give lectures to earn strategic resources. The options available here are enough to impact your expeditions, but they truly are secondary to them.

I do have two minor complaints. First, each game "ends" before you complete all of your available expeditions. I expect that was done to allow people to complete more playthroughs with different crews and strategies, but it makes the game seem too short and a little incomplete. Yes, you can play the rest of the expeditions on the map after you "win," but you'll be past the point where you can unlock new strategic resources, and a lot of the battles get pretty easy. 

My second - and again, minor - complaint, is that the character's speech combat animations don't make much sense and add little to gameplay. If I remember correctly, Ivan's "Terrify" action always produces a speech bubble of a teddy bear. I guess maybe the idea of a character that burly with a little teddy bear is a bit unsettling, but without actual dialogue, it all gets a bit nonsensical. 

The annimations for physical combat are much more cohesive. Anna's special attack is particularly cool, and there are 20 other characters with special abilities and differing stats to try out.

27450030.review:
The reason this game will always hold a dear place in my heart is, most of all, the sheer level of over-arching strategy. It may not seem it at first, but this game is very well balanced in such a way that you will *always* be making compromises of some sort, and what matters when it comes right down to it, is your grand scheme - how you play to whatever specialisations you take, how you sidestep or cope with your shortcomings, and how you take all the various decisions flung at you from various sources and grab whichever ones you are able to afford and lash them together into a raft thatll take you to shangri'la 

The strength of this game lies in its sheer replayability. This game is for you if you are the sort who enjoys picking a detailed game in attempt to learn its every nuance and aspect. Every playthrough will play out differently, amongst the choice in captain and team, the choice specialisations, your expedition plan, papers researched. You can only ever hope where you have all of these variables so thoroughly mastered that you might change one of them, and intuitively be able to bend the rest to compensate 

the only shortcoming is the combat, which is by no means terrible

27411093.review:
I'm no star at writing reviews, so I'll keep it fairly short.

This game is fun.

Too short?
Okay.
This game is lots of fun.

But seriously. I really enjoy(ed) this game. The aim is to become the Most Renowned Explorer...well duh.
You do this by collecting treasures, gaining Fame, Fortune, or Scientific discoveries, and kicking bottom.
You travel across a map that is slowly uncovered as you go along, and fight in turnbased battles, or beat the odds by spinning a wheel, until you reach the final destination. Once you have conquered whatever it is that waits at the end of every expedition you get to spend what you found, improve your character, add helpers to your team, and get ready for the next expedition.
Slowly you'll become stronger, and you might just become...duh.

I love the style of the game, it's nice and crisp and colorful.
The battles don't take too long, and the map will have you thinking where to go next instead of just blazing through.
There's plenty of gear and stuff to fiddle with if you want to micro-manage everything, or just click, click, click and go!

So is there anything bad I have to say about the game?
Sure!
My friends all have higher scores than me...but they had the game long before me, I think the scoring changed so I'll have a hard time beating them...or I just suck...

Highly recommended game, you don't need me to tell you that, but hey, you read all my "nonsense" anyway.
Cheers!

27398715.review: Have you ever wondered what it would be like to play a game that is a fusion of game mechanics/traits from isometric strategy games ( A la XCOM) , RPG elements (skill leveling, roles), roguelike replayability, collectible searching, and resource management (kind of like the Civilization series or other simulation games)? Probably not, that is quite a specific niche of a game but if so (or if that sounds interesting) then I would point you towards Renowned Explorers: International Society. A game that has so many events, character combinations, and challenges that its bound to give you at least 8 hours of gameplay just in trying to finish each mission alone. There is even more replaybility in choosing different crews to take on the expedition and challenging each mission with a different disposition. The dispositions are made up of Friendly, Agressive, and Devious which create a Rock-Paper-Scissors style of strengths and weaknesses and different crew members have different abilities that affect a certain disposition. Even deeper into the encounters is a mood system which gives debuffs or buffs based on the person's mood and also affect a general positive negative balance. This is barely scraping the surface of the encounters and not all events lead to encounters and most tend to rely on percentage chances based on crew skills and stats. Inbetween missions you get to allocate resources towards improvement of your crew and your ability to gain more resources. The goal is to collect treasures (i.e. the collectibles) in an attempt to beat your rival in popularity but you must carefully balance this with crew resolve and supplies to avoid a game over.  The game is a great pick-up if you are a fan of XCOM or Banner Saga style games but also provides a bit of everything to satisfy anyone

27310484.review:
Now this is a very difficult game to describe. The closer comparison to a prior game, though not perfectly accurate, would be FTL -Faster Than Light- except instead of being in space, you're sent back to the exploration time of the late 1800.

The goal of the game is to become in 5 "expeditions" the most "Renowned Explorers". To do so, you need to select a team of 3 explorers, among 20, with their own stats and skills, and try to gather as much "renown" as possible by collecting treasures during the expeditions.

An expedition is a semi-random map of interconnected nodes containing various ressources and treasures gated behind skill-checks and/or fights, and must be completed by reaching and defeating its associated boss. You have a limited number of free moves or "supplies" to explore the map, with some potential resupply here and there. You can explore beyond these free moves, but doing so will net some random penalties to your crew's stats. Too many penalties and defeating the boss may become impossible!
Between each expeditions, you can spend your hard gained ressources on various improvements: team stats, skills, supplies, amount of ressources or renown obtained etc.

A full run will usually take 2h, or around 30 minutes per expeditions. The first expedition is set (sort of) but you get to decide the next 4 among the 8 available in the base game (10 with the More to Explore DLC). They all come with different difficulties, skill-requirements and themes. The harder they are, the better the rewards.

Of course, a game about exploration wouldn't be complete without a world to discover. Renowned Explorers offers a colorful, lighthearted and witty one. You'll be befriending sheeps, insulting lamas and slapping monkeys (they deserve it) while you visit tropical islands, the deserts of Egypt or the forests of east Europe.

If my 200 hours on the game have not hinted on it yet: I fully recommend this game.

27246398.review:
This is such a charming and fascinating game. It combines many gameplay elements including turn based strategy, RPG, roguelike, and storytelling into a very tight and balanced package. The game is fairly short but emphasizes replayability like most roguelikes. The adventures and stories varied and have multiple results so you end up seeing something new every time you play. RNG is used pretty extensively but it feels suprisingly fair.

The multi layered rock, paper, scissor combat system is very unique and adds so much to the charm you could easily confuse it for a Nintendo game. The story telling is light hearted and silly that it's hard not to smile. The secrets and collection elements are very rewarding as well. The game is challenging but beatable even on the hardest difficulties. There's a large number of difficulty settings so it's even playable If you want to adventure with your kids or just want to experience the stories.

The best part of this game is the community. The developers have encouraged community driven weekly challenge events that have brought together the most positive gaming community that I have ever seen. The players are constructive and the deleopers are responsive to feedback. It's easy to get advice from the pros and trolls are delt with in a calm manner.

This game is great and the only complaints that I have seen are in regards to the length. If you don't like playing roguelikes that favor replayability then this may not be the game for you. It's also pretty silly so you should consider staying away if you prefer your games violent and grim.

27235457.review:
This game has not sold enough copies!

It's a great little tactics game in which you gather a band of 3 explorers to travel to different countries and find riches and fame. In each place, you'll progress by going from one encounter to the next (similar to FTL) until you reach the final encounter in which you can gain the main treasure of the place. During all this you have to manage your resources (food) and the progression of your characters to get strong enough for the specific encounters. If it comes to a fight, you'll be thrown into a turn-based tactics game with pretty strong mechanics (despite the harmless look). 

One playthrough takes only about 1-2 hours and you are encouraged to try different locations or a different set of adventurers. That said, all in all, I'd like to see a bit more variety and more options, especially when it comes to the locations. 

All this is set in a lovely and fun scenery with a great art style and a cute sense of humour. I can only heartily recommend this little gem of a game.

I can not stop playing this game. I adore it. If Indiana Jones designed a strategy game, this would be it. 

I'm normally a point and click / puzzle / story type of game person, but this one just has me hooked. I love that you don't have to be violent to win, and in fact, to unlock achievement you have to play nice once in a while. Every time I play I get a little more out of it: a new treasure, a new campfire story, or new team leader wins. Play time is short enough to not be frustrating and long enough to keep you occupied for an evening if you like.

And as a beginning gamer, this game levels up with me. It doesn't punish you for taking it easy, as so many do. So when I'm in the mood for a challenge, I can have one. But when I just want to explore and unwind, I can too. 

I've also just recently discovered its active community, with the game designers playing a large role. They put out weekly challenges for you to solve, which, again, keep the game new. 

This is by far my favourite game in the world right now. Please please please keep expanding it. I wish there were more like it!

27005653.review:
Renowned Explorers is a rogue-like exploration game with turn-based combat. After selecting a team from different roles (Speakers, Scouts, Scientists, and Fighters), you go out into the world to find treasures and meet new characters to become the most renowned explorers. Every team composition has the ability to be great at Fighting, being Devious, or being Friendly to your enemies, and how to end each encounter (Aggressive, Devious, or Friendly) has the potential to grant extra rewards... or extra hardships.

The game's unique battle system puts phyiscal and verbal combat together into one unique system that works so well. Each side has an attitude that creates an overall mood in the battle that can give your characters unique buffs or debuffs depending on the rock-paper-scissors style attitude system: Being Aggressive beats being Friendly, being Friendly beats being Devious, and being Devious beats being Aggressive. Adjusting your battle styles will change the moods and attitudes of the battle, granting boons to your side and more favorable end battle results. The battles can be very hard, and you typically are out-numbered, so mastering the mood system and how to coordinate all of your attacks together will help you overcome the difficult encounters ahead.

The game awards you with tokens that grant you money, research, renown, or status that you can spend to improve each character and your crew as a whole. The tokens have some RNG associated with their values, but depending on the outcomes and choices you make in the game, those values can increase, leading to very potent rewards if you decide to focus one or the other. The beauty of this game is how you are able to even pick the same team and go to the same locations but still do something completely different each playthrough. You can focus on one reward type over another or try to balance all of them.

The game overall does have a somewhat steep learning curve, but if you are able to master all of the different systems inside the game, you'll be able to go into the higher levels with relative ease. Also, each game session tends to be somewhat short (~2 hours, give or take), but the game is meant to be replayed... a lot. Try out new teams, new paths, new areas, new combinations, new research... the replayability of this game is incredible.

This is a game that I have greatly enjoyed and definitely recommend it to those who like unique turn-based RPG games with a little exploration and rogue-like aspects to it.

26972626.review:
[h1] A Modest Modern Masterpiece [/h1]
First of all, I’m a pretty big fan of roguelikes, I don’t enjoy the punishing difficulty that usually accompanies them; but, I do love the anything-can-happen feeling that they provide. Oftentimes, a sharp, well-tuned “little” game can outshine most triple-A titles. This is one of those times. 

[i]Renowned Explorers: International Society[/i] hits on a lot of levels for me, I love Indiana Jones, roguelikes, upbeat humor, and pop art. If any of those things don’t interest you, this might not be your game irrespective of anything I have to say. If you’re still interested, lets hit some pros-and-cons.

[b]Pros[/b]
More Fun(ny) than a Barrel of Colloquialisms

Fantastic Art that Complements the Experience and Conveys the Characters

Replay Value that is Actually Worth Replaying™

Deep Combat Strategy and Dozens of Characterful Combinations

An Ever-Faithful Adherent of the All-Wonderful, All-Good RNG (long may he reign)


[b]Cons[/b]
Cons were a lot tougher to come up with, and so I’ve written a bit more than word-bites for them, but it is important to recognize flaws in even those things that we love.

I don’t much care for 1000% voice acted titles, Morrowind had plenty enough of the talky-talky for me. Plus, you will always be able to tell more story with the written word, and that’s really what we want... more story, more game. This particular game’s sound is pretty good, but in a game that punches this far above its weight, the sound becomes a key weakness in an overall above-and-beyond style title.

Remember that deep strategy? It comes at something of a price, the emotional rock-paper-scissors that carries the strategy behind this gameplay can break your party without even asking nicely (it’s a hazard of roguelikes but can hit out of the blue like few other titles I’ve seen), and remembering what’s-good-for-you-and-bad-for-those-guys can become burdensome after a few back-to-back playthroughs.

I understand that it’s more roguelike and only RPG-lite...but I will always complain about not-robust-enough RPG features. If character build and customization options are absent, I’m angry; if they’re limited, I’m mad; and if they’re as-robust-as-all-hell with a side of Grim Dawn meets Skyrim… I’m still mildly annoyed. For the record, this game only makes me mad.


[b]Conclusion[/b]
My conclusion is that this game is nearly as good (and better in some ways) than FTL; it perfectly captures what a roguelike should be, brilliantly evokes a setting often overlooked, and manages to inject a heavy dose of that good old fashioned just-one-more-turn. So, my hat’s off to you Abbey Games, the modest game you’ve made is nothing less than a modern masterpiece. 


tl;dr: If I could only pick five games to play--for the rest of my life--this would be one of those games. 

[b]9.5/10[/b] would explore again.
