22194188.review:
Renowned Explorers: International Society on sympaattinen ja hiukan camp-henkinen peli, jossa lähetetään kolmesta henkilöstä koostuva, sekalainen retkikunta kahjoilemaan ympäri maailmaa. On tiedemiehiä, puhujia, taistelijoita ja tiedustelijoita. Antagonistina toimii Rivaleux, tuo pröystäilevä egoisti, joka pitää tietenkin kunniallisesti päihittää löytämällä parhaat aarteet ja keräämällä mahdollisimman paljon kaikkea mahdollista muutakin matkan varrella.

Eri hahmoja löytyy valittavaksi parikymmentä, ja heillä on omat persoonallisuutensa sekä erikoistaitonsa, jotka kehittyvät jonkin verran leveloinnin sekä pelin aikana hankittujen erikoistaitojen myötä. Yksi heistä täytyy alussa valita ryhmän kapteeniksi, ja jengiä voi myös hiukan varustaa. Tarkoituksena on kerätä pelin aikana mahdollisimman paljon pisteitä, joita saa mm. aarteiden sekä erilaisten tokeneiden ja resurssien keräämisestä. Pelin kulku koostuu yhteensä viidestä tutkimusmatkasta, joiden vaikeusaste vaihtelee, ja tietenkin niistä saadut palkkiot vaihtelevat reissujen vaikeusasteen sekä suorituksen mukaisesti.

Reissuilla kuljetaan kartalle merkittyjen pisteiden välillä, joista löytyy aina jonkinlainen keskustelu, aarre, taistelu tai muu sattumus, joka pakottaa pelaajan tekemään valintoja. Aika usein täytyy myös pyörittää eräänlaista onnenpyörää, jolloin onnistumisprosentti milloin missäkin tehtävässä riippuu suorittajan henkilökohtaisista tai joskus koko tiimin taidoista. Kartalla kulkua on rajoitettu tarvikkeiden määrällä, joita eri maastoissa kulkeminen kuluttaa eri määrän. Mikäli tapahtuu tosi paha moka, tai jos joku tutkimusmatkailijoista ottaa taistelussa tavalla tai toisella köniin, pelaaja menettää yhden pisteen "resolvea", jonka loppuminen päättää pelin siihen paikkaan. Tutkimusmatkojen välissä ko. resurssia saa aina hiukan lisää.

Monet ovat verranneet Steamin arvosteluissa tätä FTL:ään, mutta on tämä mielestäni varsin erilainen peli. Saman genren aallonpituudella kuitenkin liikutaan: esimerkiksi tutkimusmatkojen kartta sekä niiden aikana tapahtuvat eventit näyttävät hiukan samantyyppisiltä kuin FTL:n jump point -kartta. Tarinankerronta on myös samantyyppisesti humoristista, mutta ehkä hiukan omaperäisempää kuin FTL:ssä. Myös, edellisen tapaan, randomisointia löytyy tästä pelistä paljon, mutta kuten tyypillistä, osa asioista on skriptattu tapahtumaan vain tietynlaisissa paikoissa.

Varsinkin taisteluiden mekaniikka on RE:IS:ssä täysin uniikki, enkä ainakaan itse ole missään nähnyt vastaavaa. Jokaisella omalla sekä vastustajan hahmolla on tietenkin tietty määrä hipareita (spirit), jota niiltä isketään pois erilaisilla iskuilla ja erikoisiskuilla, missä nyt ei sinänsä ole mitään kummallista. Taisteluissa on kuitenkin myös yleinen ilmapiiri, joka on aina jotain ystävällisen, vihamielisen ja epävarman väliltä ja tähän ilmapiiriin vaikutetaan joko ystävällismielisillä, kieroilla tai jopa aggressiivisilla iskuilla. Eri tyyppisten iskujen tehot riippuvat merkittävästi vallitsevasta ilmapiiristä, eli aggressiivisenkin vastustajan voi voittaa ilman suoranaista fyysistä väkivaltaa. Lisäksi jokaisella hahmolla on taistelussa "fiilis", joka voi olla negatiivinen tai positiivinen, jonka lisäksi eri kyvyt aiheuttavat henkilöissä erilaisia tunnetiloja, esim. surullinen, suuttunut, itsevarma jne. joilla on omat vaikutuksensa heidän suorituksiinsa fiiliksen mukaan.

Pelin grafiikat ovat sympaattisia ja persoonallisia, mutta mitä väliä. Tätä on pirun hauska pelata. Viimeistään siinä vaiheessa, kun Transilvaniassa asuva vampyyrikreivi kokee kettuilusi jälkeen itsensä ulkopuoliseksi ja haluaa mukaan tiimiisi bonuksia antavaksi erikoisavustajaksi, koska olet vaan niin cool, on pakko hiukan herähtää nauruun.

Jos jostain pitää antaa pientä miikkaa, niin eri tutkimusmatkoja on ehkä hiukan vähän, varsinkin pelin loppuvaiheilla. Pelattavaa niissä riittää silti. Tekijät ovatkin ilmeisesti haistaneet tässä DLC:n mahdollisuuden, mutta ainakin tähän asti kaikki DLC-sisältö on tainnut olla ilmaista. Muistaakseni olen jostain foorumilta lukenut, että jokin maksullinen lisäosa saattaisi olla tuloillaan. Tässä tapauksessa laatu kyllä korvaa määrän ja mielestäni on parempikin näin päin.

22189908.review:
After playing 'Reus' I was really excited to see what else this studio came up with. This is a talented group, and there is definitely an audience for this game, but I think the audience is too "niche" to warrant the sweeping positive reviews.

Stylistically, I think the campiness was a weird choice. After playing the tutorial and seeing the evil "rival" I was thinking, "Hey, this would be a fun thing to show to my 7 year old nephew" but then I realized there's way too much reading for someone of that age and the difficulty is too high for him to enjoy... so... I don't know, I thought it was silly. Let's go plunder a native tribe by telling them jokes... :|

The bonuses are fun. You get LOTS of shiny throughout the game. It doesn't pay off unless you complete a whole level, though, and the boss fights were the deal breakers for me. I think in the last fight I did there were 4x as many enemies as my I had in my party. Challenging fights are fun... but I hadn't even really completed a full level (past the tutorial), so it seems like it just ramped up too fast. And while the game is technically a 'tactics' game, in that it has a grid and you walk around, there seemed to be less tactical decisions focused on positioning, movement, cover, etc... and more so just their 'mood' system.

21720822.review:
Renowned Explorers: International Society (RE:IS) is a turn-based strategy adventure roguelike. Boy is that a mouthful! I have never seen quite a game like this. RE:IS draws aspects from each of its genres and combines them into a unique experience. 

Upon first glance at this game it can be somewhat puzzling or appear glaring simple even. You take a team of three explorers, making one of them your captain who gets an extra perk to help you along the way, and conduct 5 expeditions across various regions around the world. Each playthrough will have its own ups and downs and no two will every be alike. 

At first glance the game doesnt appear to have much content. But the replayability is so high that after ~80 hours of gameplay I am still finding new treasure or trying out different strategies. There are 20 different characters to choose from. Thats 6,840 different combinations! With over a hundred treasure to collect you will find yourself sinking countless hours and playthrough into this game to master every detail. Plus the devs are constantly improving the game and adding more content!

There is more than one way to play. Combat is its own unique formula utilizing a rock-paper-scissors weakness chart creating different moods that effect your team. But even this gives way to more depth after you master the basics. Perhaps that boss that is easy to defeat deviously gives a different reward if you are friendly, but becareful because friendly abilities only do half damage to him. 

The art and the story are both fantastic and the events continue to be amusing even after you've gone through them before. With an active community and weekly challenges there is always more strategies to try and scores to improve.

If you like turn-based strategy and roguelikes this is a game for you.
It quickly became one of my favorite games to play and I am still learning more and more about the secrets of hidden treasures.

21718809.review: It's high adventure in the golden age of exploration, with bright, colorful graphics and a tongue in cheek tone. The gameplay is fun (if challenging at times), and the replay value is great, as in addition to selecting an entirely new crew, you'll find that there are various secrets tucked away in every expedition that'll take multiple attempts to uncover.

21615908.review:
ターンベース型シミュレーションだが、敵味方にfriendly,agressive,deviousという三種類のmoods（ムード）と呼ばれるジャンケン式のフィールド効果があり戦闘スキルと連動していて、その駆け引きが飽きさせない。ただし、ゲームのゴールはrenowed(名声）をあげてNo1になることで、三人一組のパーティーメンバーを戦闘だけではなく、資源や財宝獲得のランダムイベントで有利になるように組む必要があり、その悩ましさがまた楽しい。戦闘やイベントに絡むパラメーターが非常に多く、また選択肢によって結果が様々なので、（簡単な英語だが）テキストをちゃんと読む必要がある。最低でも各所に表示されるツールチップに目を通しておくと良い結果を得られやすい。
冒険の合間のワールドマップではホールでさらにボーナス資源を獲得したり装備品の購入、獲得した資源やお金を使ってリサーチツリーの開発や資源獲得のヘルパー増員などができるが、リーダーによって得意な資源とその獲得方法が異なるので優先する資源を一つか二つに絞って、得意分野を伸ばしていく方向で育成しないとなかなか名声が上がらない。一見パラメーターアップにしか思えない各種perkがイベントで重要になるので、お金は無駄遣いせず（できるだけ早く店をアップグレードして）perkつき装備を買うと楽。
一見運の要素が大きくて淡白なゲームに思えるが、パーティー構成や育成方法に気を使えばきちんと成果の出るところが繊細で非常によくできている。

Tactical RPG with Rogue-like elements.

Definitely worth purchasing. 
My only real complaint is that it could use a bit more polish, and I've run into the occasional bug (but they aren't game ending and are easily fixed)

Edit:
I've seen a couple reviews complain about RNG in the overworld aspect of the game. I had trouble with that at first, but if you're having significant trouble with RNG, you probably built a lousy group, or made poor character advancement decisions. on my last playthrough, about 3/4 of the time I had an option for 100% success because my group were well developed in diverse areas of expertise. Most of the time you are also given the opportunity to not take the risk also, there may be 3 options, then a 4th that basically says walk away with no reward (and no penalty).

If you're looking for some less hardcore turn-based game to break up the XCOM marathons then look no further. The art style is fantastic and the characters are very well drawn and look great. It's good for a quick fix as you can finish your 5 expeditions in a couple of hours but isn't tedious and has endless replayability thanks to the crew combinations so you can play it for long periods of time.

21311124.review:
Renowned Explorers n'est pas, contrairement à ce que ses graphismes détaillés et chatoyants pourraient laisser croire, un "roguelite", mais alors, pas du tout. Il s'agit peut-être d'un des plus purs et durs roguelikes récents, mais avec des atours prenant en compte l'évolution des résolutions d'écran depuis 1984. Le but est d'explorer un certain nombre de donj... euh régions, pour accumuler suffisamment de prestige afin de niquer sa race à l'aptement nommé Rivaleux.
Commençons par le principal reproche régulièrement effectué contre le jeu : oui, le nombre de régions (faites à la main avec amour par un petit artisan que Jean-Pierre 'Pernod' ne rechignerait pas à prendre en bouche) est très limité.
Mais dieu, que ces régions regorgent de secrets ! Et même de secrets qui interagissent entre les différentes zones ! Et même que ça dépend aussi de votre équipe ! et de ses talents ! Argh, je m'emmêle les pinceaux.
Voilà, c'est cela, ce jeu : une série de systèmes incroyablement malins et entremêlés, dont il faudra tirer l'écheveau de la motte de la peau de l'ours. Le jeu est très exigeant : prendre des notes est plutôt nécessaire, et le chemin est long avant de commencer à maîtriser ces systèmes (et s'en souvenir).
Alors oui, il y a répétition, comme dans toute pédagogie. Mais lorsqu'il s'agira de mettre en œuvre le savoir ainsi ingéré, là, laissez-moi vous dire que c'est bandant.
Tout ça pourrait ne donner qu'un bon gros puzzle une fois démoulé, mais la cerise sur le gâteau, c'est que le jeu se fend même d'avoir une espèce de narration émergente, guillerette et légère en sus. Les personnages (alliés ou ennemis) ont tous de la personnalité (sic) et leurs interactions rendront certaines épopées plus marquantes que d'autres.

Je ne peux pas tarir d'éloges quant à cette petite merveille. Un jeu intelligent, diantre foutre, ça existe ?!

21291327.review: Really flavorful and interesting rogue lite where the difficulty is high but allows for very strategic play.  I really enjoy this game, and it's got a TON of replay value (obviously) with many many different possible crew combinations.

21280162.review:
RE:IS is basically a generic "we made a roguelike look at us guys" game that is so poorly balanced that it's almost laughable. The first half of the game is a total steamroll, while the latter half features a cheating AI and really cheap game mechanics (bosses with infinite reinforcements that arrive every turn which are also damage sponges) to try and counter the steamroll. There's also a lot of cheap screw-over mechanics where unless you have a guide open displaying every possible outcome to everything you are probably not going to be getting anywhere.

Devs have nerfed every possible winning combo to the ground because "muh singleplayer game balance" making it even more un-fun than it already was.

Renowned Explorer (RE) is a really great game, the gameplay is a mix of strategy, tactics and exploration, with some RPG elements (xp, loot, equipment, chose your own adventure), and the mix holds really well thanks to a great execution by Abbey Studio.
But more than that, it is really an adventure you should experience. It makes you think, design your own stategy & test it on the map. You will fail miserably at times, just to retry and enjoy Epic victories
So what's not to like ? well it's just personal, but the reason I didn't buy it sooner was because of the heroe's portrait design, it could use some improvement, after all they are the heroes of this game and they should deserve extra care, the rest of the design is well done, the music complements well the feeling of being part of a great adventure.

I really look forward to extensions and improvements to get my team on another epic adventures.

21202011.review:
Игра просто отличная. Большое разнообразие персонажей, их прокачка, напряжённые битвы, хорошие сюжеты развития действий, уйма сокровищ. Правда есть маленький минус - это конечно-же малое количество мест для путешествий. Но это поправимо. Игра просто ДОЛЖНА развиваться дальше и добавлять как можно больше всего.

21198551.review:
This is going to sound insane, but this game actually is what Darkest Dungeon claims to be. Look beyond the anachronistically inclusive pastel Victoriana and the fact that you can win fights by hurting everyone's feelings. Fuck being "hard," this game is complicated. It is also just straight up hard though. 

The combat is very deterministic. While there is some very minor variation in damage output, so that you can sometimes gamble on killing someone that might otherwise take two hits, the RNG is mostly living in the encounter layout. Once you've seen the board, you really do live and die by your decisions. Everything that matters, including aggro, is something you can manipulate once you know what you're doing. And it's always open to you to say "Hell with this" and burn long-term resources so that you don't have to really watch what you're doing in a given fight. Likewise, even if you're down to your last handful of reserve, if you know what you're doing and aren't up against the final boss, you can usually get through. 

While the tactical side is all good and everything, the strategic layers are where this thing sings. Every single node event is interesting, with a variety of possible solutions. But you can't build a party that can do everything, and you can't always choose what you need to do.  Even before you're picking your actual battles, you have to pick your battles. Throughout, the writing is solid and transparent. Figuring out how to milk a map, calculating how many debuffs you can handle before the boss is confronted, this is great fun. 

And then on top of that, your entire map behaviour is influenced by a complex of tech trees, stores, and social groups. Spending resources almost always makes the campaign at hand easier in the short term, but resources are almost always more valuable later in the campaign. Is it worth 200 gold for this guy to be great at archeology if it means I can't buy him the best armour later? Should I melt these tokens now to make sure I get through Mali, or gamble that I can beat it without them because the payout will be better after? These are meaningful choices, and you are obliged to make them constantly.

This whole game is just lousy with interlocking systems, and they all work extremely well together. It's possible there's some one optimal group and strategy that snaps the game open, but as far as I can tell this just is about the best-designed game of its kind since FTL. It's a bummer that because all its chrome screams "CASUAL" people are unlikely to give it the time of day, but it's genuinely balls hard as a game and the fluff is really entertaining. I would strongly recommend this game to literally anyone; you will find a difficulty setting that makes it fun for you.

21091043.review:
[h1]"Лара Крофт и Индиана Джонс уже не актуальны!"[/h1]

Конечно, это не так, но Renowned Explorers достойна осесть в библиотеке любителя исследований, рогаликов, местами хардкора или любителя собирать ачивменты. Это очень красочная игра, с нехитрой задумкой и крайне симпотичным исполнением. Но давайте разбирать сундук с сокровищами по порядку.

[b]1. Подготовка.[/b]

Вы возглавляете небольшую команду исследователей и авантюристов, которые стремятся всеми возможными способами доказать мировому сообществу - что они лучшие. Для этого, вы набираете в команду троих бравых смельчаков, ориентируясь на их профессию и боевые навыки. После этого, конечно же, ваших подопечных нужно одеть и выдать им снаряжение - самое лучшее, чтобы не пропасть в коварных джунглях или топких болотах. Пользуясь своим положение "Великого исследователя" вы можете нанимать в свою штаб-квартиру ученых или журналистов. Помимо рядового персонала, есть возможность нанять [i]специалиста[/i] - того же британского летчика, который обучит одного из парней азам пилотирования. Не обошлось в игре и без исследований - шесть небольших деревьев по 5-6 пунктов в каждом. 
Ну, вроде все изучили, людей наняли, протеже одели - вперед, к приключениям! А в Лондон мы всегда сможем вернуться после успешной экспедиции, чтобы обновить гардероб или нанять еще людей.

[b]2. Экспедиция.[/b]
За всю игру, мы сможем пройти не больше пяти экспедиций одной компанией. Да-да, это все-таки рогалик. По окончании пятой вылазки в свет, игра подсчитает ваши победные очки и отправит собирать новую команду.
Что касается геймплея, то в этом самый сок исследовательского духа. Передвигаясь по карте мы обязательно попадем в какую нибудь смешную/опасную/нелепую ситуацию, выход из которой придется искать вам, с помощью ваших подопечных. Нашли высокую башню, на вершине которой наверняка есть клад, а добраться до него никак? Думаю, инженер сможет найти тайный вход в конструкции башни, или же наш бравый гимнаст просто вскарабкается по выступам. Все зависит от умений вашей команды и небольшой толики удачи, ведь проверка на успех проходит на рулетке. Чем больше навык персонажа - тем больше шанс успеха.

[b]3. Боевая система.[/b]
Вся боевая система строится на технологии "Mood", по-русски - "Настроение". В игре есть три типа настроения, дружелюбное, коварное и агрессивное. Каждый персонаж может вас либо ударить (Агрессия), либо улыбнуться (Дружелюбие), либо сказать, что ваша мама жирная обезьяна (Коварность). В зависимости от поведения  всей команды, выстраивается так называемое "командное настроение". Если вы сражаетесь с волками, то очевидно, что их командное настроение агрессивное, потому что ничего другого они не умеют. Итак, подошли ко главному - от сочетания командных настроений (вас и вражеской) зависит атмосфера всего поля боя. Если вы настроены дружелюбно и противники дружелюбно - то все проявления агрессии получают +50% к силе. Если противник агрессивен, а вы коварны - вы получаете +25 к шансу увернуться от атаки. В общем то, эта система хоть и проста, но работает на ура и позволяет выстраивать целые стратегии, в зависимости от настроения ваших персонажей.
В остальном, сама боевка, ни что иное как стандартная пошаговая стратегия на гексагональном поле.

[b]Подытожим.[/b]

Игра красочная, с приятной рисованной анимацией и расслабляющим видеорядом. Музыкальное сопровождение соответствует духу исследователей, что не может не радовать. 
Боевая система вполне приемлема - в игре четыре уровня сложности, и если первые два довольно просты для прохождения, то остальные два заставят попотеть (короче игра может в хардкор).
Наполненность вне-боевого контента тоже радует - все эти ситуации, в которые попадают герои не могут оставить равнодушным, хотя большинство из них вы запомните после второго-третьего прохождения.
Плюсы можно перечислять очень долго, а вот основных минуса могу заметить только два:
Мало локаций, серьезно! Отсюда и небольшая реиграбельность, что можно объединить в один минус. Пусть даже в виде DLC, но новые локации важны, нужны, ожидаемы и уже заранее любимы! 
Нет локализации. Серьезно, всю тонну красочного текста придется переводить, если у вас не лады с забугорным языком. 

Понимаем, что эти два минуса и могут стать решающими, но вы всегда сможете вернуться, когда выйдут новые карты и локализация. Игра стоит того!

20963713.review:
Renowned Explorers —отличная по-настоящему [b]приключенческая[/b] игра про охоту за сокровищами. Смесь пошаговой стратегии и настольной игры с картой и выборами с вкраплениями системы прокачки из ролевых игр. 

Сперва нужно выбрать трех героев из двадцати возможных, разбитых на 4 класса. У каждого свои способности и стартовые умения. Сам игровой процесс состоит из перемещения по локации, с выборами в случайных событиях, и периодических стычек с противниками.
Одна из особенностей игры это то, что многие боевые способности вызывают у героев и их противников различные эмоциональные состояния. Где еще можно не только пугать врагов, но и расстраивать, впечатлять и воодушевлять настолько, что они не захотят больше продолжать бой?
Также в игре присутствуют два игровых режима с несколькими уровнями сложности для каждого. С ними можно превратить игру в легкую прогулку или же сложнейшее приключение.
Минус могу отметить только один: пока что не очень много карт, а как следствие и игровых событий. 

9 кнутов Индианы Джонса из 10

20953221.review:
First time I saw this in the store, I immediately dismissed it. The graphical style makes it look like a cheap iPad game, the combat grid system looked completely average and generic. I forgot about it, and it was only when I saw a favourable review did I decide to try it.

Turns out, I'm an idiot for not picking it up sooner. Buy this game.

The exploration aspect is very FTL-like, but the complexity in the combat and the crew setups is what makes this game shine. The addition of moods and emotions (and its continuation to the exploration map) really adds a whole new dimension to combat. 

Yes, it appears at first to have a steep (almost unfair?) difficulty curve. Yes, you can be on a roll and be entirely screwed over from bad luck. But yes, yes and yes, you will want to play this again and again.

A few minor points - would be nice to have the tools button more obviously shown for beginners. Would be nice to have little reminders to level up before continuing. Would be nice to be able to see characters' attacks while in a shop, without having to close it and switch pages. And I'm still not a fan of the graphics. But all that is minor.

20908097.review:
REIS is a great strategy rogue-like with lots of heart poured into the gameplay and writing. This game caters for all types, but I feel gamers who enjoy chasing high scores will particularly enjoy it. Although the game does have a slightly steep learning curve, the multiple difficulty settings and varied playable characters let players set their own difficulty. 

Do note the plot is window dressing for the game, so people out there who play for story might be disappointed. Having said that, each location you visit feels unique and matches thematically with the events which occur there. 

I'd also like to point out that the devs at Abbey Games are wonderfully active. They want to continue expanding the game through 2016 and have pushed out regular updates (both balance and content) since launch. They have community challenges on the game's Steam discussion boards which encourage fans to try different combinations of characters and scoring conditions. They also listen and discuss suggestions made by players to continue improving what's already a strong base package. 

REIS is a fantastic game made by fantastic devs. It is worth your time and money and I encourage anyone who is at all interested in tactical games and rogue-likes to give it a go.

20900894.review:
If I had to describe Renowned Explorers: International Society in one word it would be 'weird'. It's not a bad game, in fact it's a rather good game and my first impressions are promising. That said it's like nothing I've ever played before. At face-value it's a turn-based exploration and combat game. Explore the overworld until you either get a text-based encounter or a combat encouter. There's more to the encounters (combat in particular) though, you can be aggressive, devious or friendly. Certain moves will affect your enemies emotion, and the attitude of your moves will affect the overall mood leading to certain buffs and debuffs. The combat system is fairly easy to come to grips with but leaves much room for strategising and planning. 

On top of the aforementioned mechanical pleasures the game is a joy to look at. The art style is not only beautiful but also funny and over-the-top, cartoony even. The facial expression of the characters and the way the move is reminiscent of a Saturday Morning cartoon. Renowned Explorers doesn't take itself seriously and it's all the better for it. It's ultimate goal is for you to have fun. It isn't looking to tell some kind meaningful story or wow you with graphical fidelity, it's here to have fun provided you're here to have fun.

20845338.review: Awesome game. A lot of inovatie ideas, that are implemented perfectly. I have rarely seen such a good combat system in a game.

20829289.review:
Ce petit jeu, aux graphismes très BD, vous plonge dans une ambiance à la Indiana Jones, ou peut-être Alan Quatermain, avec une bonne dose d'humour. 

Les mécanismes sont du type "jeu de plateau". Le jeu consiste à battre Rivaleux, l'explorateur Français (pourvu d'une magnifique moquette blonde !). Vous avez 5 expéditions pour y arriver. Chacune d'entre elles consiste à faire circuler votre équipe de noeud en noeud sur une carte de la région à explorer. Sur chaque noeud, un événément, une série d'événements, une rencontre peuvent advenir. Leur nature, les bénéfices à en tirer (en cas de réussite), leurs enchainements même dépendent de la constitution de votre équipe et des compétences de ses membres. Le nombre de noeuds à explorer est limité par les approvisionnements emportés par l'équipe, chaque noeud visité avec le ventre creux imposant de lourds malus (cumulatifs) à l'un des explorateurs. 

Ce que RE:IS nomme 'rencontre' est ce qui tient lieu de combat, à la nuance près qu'il existe plusieurs approches pour dénouer ces rencontres : votre équipe peut être amicale, manipulatrice ou agressive, et elle peut modifier son attitude en cours de rencontre. Chacun de ces 3 modes correspond à 1-3 compétences (de "combat") par protagoniste. L'attitude choisie, combinée à celle de l'adversaire, détermine des bonus-malus (attaque/défense, physique/verbal). Les coups portés font évoluer la "santé" de l'adversaire mais aussi son humeur, celle-ci ayant en retour ses propres conséquences en termes de bonus-malus. Les rencontres consistent donc à gérer au plus près tous ces éléments pour éliminer/convaincre l'adversaire le plus vite possible. Les mécanismes, simples à comprendre, sont également assez délicats à maitriser compte tenu du nombre de combinaisons possibles. 

Les 3 personnages de l'équipe acquièrent de l'expérience au fur et à mesure des événements et rencontres. Et il y a d'autres paramètres pour parvenir à la victoire. 

Le jeu offre deux modes : roguelike ou avec sauvegardes, ainsi que plusieurs niveaux de difficulté pour se faire les dents. 

RE:IS est, en ce qui me concerne, la bonne surprise du mois. Ce jeu est stable, les développeurs actifs et à l'écoute, l'interface claire. Une partie (5 expéditions) se joue en 2-3 heures au plus, ce qui en fait un "petit jeu" auquel on peut s'adonner facilement en fonction des disponibilités. 

La rejouabilité me parait excellente : même si le nombre et la taille des cartes sont limités, chaque équipe d'explorateurs génère sur ces cartes un parcours (événements/rencontres) légèrement différent selon sa composition. Avec 20 personnages disponibles (appartenant à 4 grandes classes : scientifique, scout, combattant, orateur), vous avez donc 6840 combinaisons pour vos équipes ! 
Ajoutez à cela 4 niveaux de difficultés et plein d'options en cours de jeu (attitudes dominantes, qui est le capitaine de l'équipe, etc.), les objectifs à atteindre (battre Rivaleurx, dépasser votre dernier record, décrocher tel ou tel badge/"achievement")  et la durée limitée d'une partie : vous avez de quoi vous amuser pendant un bout de temps. 

Bref, un jeu plaisant, drôle et riche, auquel je retourne d'ailleurs sur le champ - j'ai un chateau hanté à explorer dans les Carpathes, moi, messieurs !

20781638.review:
[u]The Good[/u]: Plenty to love here!
[*] [b]Engaging gameplay.[/b] A fun mix of exploration (of course!), stat-based challenges (that roulette wheel mechanic is GREAT alternative to dice rolling), X-COM style tactical combat, balanced with resource management, party-building, and skill tree advancement.
[*] [b]Well-crafted world-building.[/b] Just the right mix of borrowed historical elements, genre tropes, imperial archetypes, and self-aware humor, all presented with genuine love for the setting. 
[*] [b]Impressive pan-global character designs.[/b] The devs take advantage of the gleeful anachronism to present a more diverse cast, with the bad-ass female luchadore and distaff Greek resistance fighter being just as credible and important as the grizzled sea captain and stiff-upper-lipped aristocrat. For a game where the fluff is so closely integrated with the mechanics, that's a big deal.

[u]The Bad[/u]
For a game that doesn't [i]seem[/i] particularly complex, it sure is buggy. I can't run it on my personal laptop, most likely because of chronic problems with MS Visual C++

To be fair, there's a vibrant and responsive support community on the forums here, but I just want a game that runs glitch-free from installation.

(Fortunately, it runs without a hitch on my work computer.)

[u]The Ugly[/u]
All that effort to choose theme-appropriate character designs, names, adventures, maps, and yet [b]none[/b] of the fonts and typefaces match the setting. Especially that awfully bland logo!

20774138.review: This game wonderfully combines tactical battles and roguelike exploration. I can't recommend it highly enough.

20773642.review:
RE:IS is in a genre all it's own. Although it has only minor gameplay similarities, the feeling I get while playing is most similar to FTL. I HIGHLY recommend playing on adventure mode for intense, consequence driven, rogue-lite gaming. 

Combat is turn-based on a hex map. Strategy revolves around changing your team's attitude between friendly, devious, and aggresive to match or beat your opponent's. Emotions are applied on a per charcter basis for additional buffs/debuffs.  

Each expedition plays out similarly to a sector of FTL. Limited supplies and fog-of-war create difficult decisions while exploring. Collect wealth, status, and research to spend later, while also seeking treasures to increase your renown as the world's greates explorer. 

Between expeditions, spend the resources you gathered to specialize your crew with better equipment, an entourage to increase your resource gains, and research papers to focus on your victory condition.

The RNG aspects of the game are clearly laid out (you are told what % chance you have at passing a test, plus the rewards/punishments) which means your risks are calculated and you have nobody to blame but yourself for the outcome.  

Devs like Abbey are why gaming today is so great. Innovative and creative games, constant post-release support, and communication with the community is a winning formula every time.

20688411.review:
There are already many reviews that explain the game mechanics. My review, rather focuses on what is important to me, which is replay value. For the lazy who don't like to read, I have condensed all my points below (Pros, Cons and Warnings). My final verdict is that I love the game. It's a must try if you like turn based strategy, rogue-likes, high score games and high replayability.

-Pros-
+Wonderful Artwork
+Deceptively deep and challenging turn based combat system
+Strong replay value due to treasure collection system, a large amount of characters and good variety of different strategies you can employ to win the game
+Developer is active on the message board, talking to and getting ideas from the fanbase. Free patches and content are constantly released to improve the game.
+Very easy to pick up and play. "One more turn syndrome" is very easy to catch.

-Cons-
+Game is constantly being rebalanced which may alienate people who hate change. Some characters are overpowered and some are underpowered. At a high level of play, players may discover a lack of choice because of the balancing. There is little reason to go on certain expeditions because they don't offer as much score as the "meta" ones.
+Most of the replay value comes from the wealth of different character combinations and strategies. The expeditions, after playing them a few times become predictable despite the fact that they are randomly generated as you'll see the same events often. 

-Warnings-
+Stubborn players may become disillusioned with the difficulty of the game. On the default settings, the turn based combat becomes difficult in the late game unless you learn the deep combat system. This can easily be solved by lowering the difficulty but this will not matter to prideful gamers who refuse to lower it.
+Like any rogue-like, there is a healthy amount of RNG (your success is around 40% luck). If this bothers you, this may not be the genre for you.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This game consists of choosing a three person team of explorers and going on 5 expeditions (you get to choose different locations around the world) in a bid to survive, find treasure and ultimately beat your rival by outscoring him by the end of the game. The amount of treasures and resources you gain during a playthrough are converted into a overall score called Renown.

During an expeditions, there are nodes that you move along that have random events on them. A resource called Supplies is reduced by 1-2 everytime you move with heavy penalties if you run out forcing you to make strategic decisions on how much loot you want to collect before you go to the final node which results in a boss fight and ends the expedition. Combat is surprisingly deep with a rock, paper, scissors system where you can defeat your opponents with aggression, friendliness or deviousness. Massive buffs or debuffs can be applied to the entire battlefield depending on whether you are winning or losing the rock, paper, system system, making combat challenging. Simply rushing in and attacking will not go well in the later expeditions and boss fights.

Outside of expeditions, you can use resources you gained to purchase items to improve the stats of your party, buy items and followers with perks and more.

This game was a giant hidden gem to me. I was randomly browsing Steam for roguelikes and found it deep within the dark depths of Gaben's labyrinth. I purchased it just to try it and next thing you know, I had nearly 25 hours of gameplay in a few days. There are a ton of different carrots to keep you playing for dozens of hours. Unlocking all the captains, beating the game, beating the two secret endings and finding every single one of the treasure hidden in the game.

The game feels very rewarding with many layers to master. "My run is average and I'm not sure I'm going to get enough score to beat my rival. Do I go to a 4 or 5 star difficulty expedition which has great rewards but risk dying? Or do I just do another 3 star expedition which is easy but I may not get enough score to win the game?"

"This boss is weak to aggression so I could physically attack it to do massive damage. But it also has a perk that causes it to transform into a more powerful form if it gets physically attacked which will put my party at risk."

"One of my party members has a greedy personality. Do I risk visiting a ruins where I know there is alot of treasure? It'll drastically increase my score but my party members who has a greedy personality may grab all the treasure and set off a nasty trap risking the run".

If these sorts of scenarios and choices excite you, then I think you'll enjoy the game alot.

20534766.review:
I had to cook it over a while to decide exactly why I love Renowned Explorers so much. It boils down to two things.

1 - Many roguelike experiences are built around the question, "Will you live to cross the finish line?" It can get really depressing to die and fail over and over again. RE:IS (on its standard difficulties anyway) asks, "How cool will your adventuring career be?" I rarely straight up lose a run, but it isn't about winning or losing. It's about the first time you finish with 2500 Renown. Then 3000. Then 3500. You'll get a little better at squeezing more efficiency out of your runs each time you play, and you won't need an unbreakable spirit to want to keep trying.

2 - Another factor hampering many roguelike experiences is that there's only one paradigm for interaction. The whole game is dungeon crawling. No single gameplay system can entertain you forever. RE:IS has three different types of play: Roleplaying as you travel from node to node and decide how to handle incidents, Combat on a turn based grid with a handful of subsystems that don't overwhelm, and Resource Management as you spend your hard earned gains on things that synergize with your strengths and shore up your weaknesses. You'll constantly rotate between these 3 activities, so none of them ever overstay their welcome.

RE:IS is amazing. I eagerly await and will gladly pay for more DLC.

20510683.review:
A truly great game, totally looking forward to the announced expansion.

It might seem innocent and light-hearted if you judge by screenshots, but in fact it is pretty deep and clever and not particularly forgiving (at least for me at the Classic-Adventure difficulty; actually, so far only twice have I survived five expeditions), but even then it delivers incredibly positive message, and 'losing' in fact never feels unfair.

The game basically has three layers, all of them are very well designed and crafted.

The strategic one is your headquarters in roughly XIX century London, were your spend earned resources and prepare to your next expedition. To be honest, I like this part the least, but its fine and pretty complex as well. In fact, on the first few runs, it might appear overwhelming.

Then, there are expeditions themselves, full of random encounters and adventures and witty dialogues. They're amazing, and so far I can't say that I have become bored even from visiting the same areas. The layout of the expedition changes each time you play, and the special locations present there vary from one run to another, and of course, the outcome of events is often different for different teams and runs.

The third layer is tactical battles. Well, you don't get too much of them to become tired, there is always a final encounter at the end of the expedition, and typically two to four aside of it, depending on whether you are looking for fight. At first, the battle mechanics might appear complex and TERRIFYING, but as you grasp the basics (it takes a few encounters) and become more CONFIDENT, it becomes quite EXCITING. I guess any tactical battle system that operates with terms like 'attitude', 'mood' and 'emotions' is definitely worth giving it a try. Oh, and I like the form of field grid too.

Some people might say that the battle mechanics is not really a big deal and devious and friendly abilities can be replaced with say ice and nature magic, the notion that I don't exactly agree with. Even if technically that might be true, the path you choose to resolve encounters is reflected back onto the adventure level, and affects how your quest continues, which I find pretty cool.

As for drawbacks, the only thing I might think about is the number of available expeditions and well, their tight concentration in just few geographical areas. The game is great, but if it just had even more content it would be even greater.

20458557.review:
Renowned Explorers : International Society,
Par où commencer. Un petit ovni comme on n'en croise pas souvent et pourtant il possède énormément de très bonnes qualités.
Une partie dure entre 1h30 et 2h (cela dépend de l'étendue de votre connaissance du contenu) où l'on incarne un groupe d'explorateurs venant de différentes nations. On commence par choisir un capitaine d'équipe qui sera un élément déterminant au niveau des points que vous remporterez puis on l'accompagne de 2 autres équipiers. Chacun possède ses forces, faiblesses, attaques et traits particuliers.

Nous sommes alors entrainés dans une course folle à la renommée contre des rivaux dont les premiers dans le classement seront les principaux ennemis numéros 1 : Les Rivaleux.
Une fois l'équipe construite, le jeu se déroule en 5 manches (hors introduction) dont chacune est composée de 3 parties :
- Une phase de préparation
- Une phase d'exploration
- Une phase de comptage des points

La préparation est déterminante et est très certainement la plus importante des 3 même si pour la plupart des gens elle ne sera pas la plus fun. Le but ici est de préparer son voyage afin de rentabiliser nos découvertes lors de la phase d'exploration. Pour cela il est important de connnaitre les différentes catégories de "découvertes" ou jetons gagnés en exploration :
- La campagne publicitaire (rapporte des points de statut)
- La récolte d'argent (rapporte de l'argent)                                           => découvertes standards
- L'étude (rapporte des points de science)
- L'expérience militaire (rapporte un mix de tout les autres points)
  ----------
- Le trésor (rapporte des points de statut et de l'argent)
- Le secret (rapporte des points de science et de statut)                      => découvertes avancées (plus rares)
- La découverte (rapporte des points de science et de l'argent)

Chacun de ces jetons rapportent aussi des points de renom qui constituent vos points de victoire.

La préparation consiste alors à améliorer les bonus : des personnages, de points rapportés, de jetons gagnés, etc. à travers les points gagnés en exploration (par exemple la science récupérée grace aux jetons étude, découverte, secret et expérience militaire permettent de débloquer une publication en science, l'argent permet d'acheter des équipements pour améliorer ses personnages...)

Une fois ceci terminé vous êtes parés pour une prochaine expédition dont on choisit la destination. Commence alors la phase d'exploration où l'on se déplace comme sur un plateau de jeu sur les différents points de la carte. Sur le terrain, les personnages vivent leurs aventures au travers d'un récit bon enfant et essaient de faire le plus de découvertes possibles. Cela va des jetons jusqu'à des trésors uniques mais à moins qu'ils ne soient donnés gratuitement, il faudra vaincre les obstacles par des combats ou par une roue dont vous pouvez augmenter vos chances de réussites en fonction des traits de votre personnage. Ainsi un Scientifique qui aura le trait Biologiste sera plus à même de découvrir les secrets que cache la nature de la jungle alors qu'il sera moins utile lors du désamorçage d'une bombe.

Arrivés à destination, le jeu comptera vos points récupérés lors de l'exploration et vous êtes parés pour la prochaine manche.

Ceci n'est que le début de la profondeur du jeu car je n'ai pas mentionné comment fonctionne le système de combat qui est loin d'être facile à prendre en main dès le début malgré le fait qu'il soit intelligent et très amusant. Le jeu est totalement randomisé concernant les évènements qui peuvent vous arriver sur vos destinations et 5 manches ne suffisent pas à tout maximiser, il faudra alors vous spécialiser et synergiser vos préparation avec les endroits que vous souhaiter découvrir si vous voulez battre Les Rivaleux.
Tout comme Reus, ce jeu est très intelligent, la pâte graphique est absolument somptueuse, les musiques font de bonnes ambiances, l'univers est génial et le replay value est immense.

Je note tout de même quelques petits défauts :
- L'accessibilité, le jeu pourrait mieux se faire connaitre s'il n'avait pas que l'anglais disponible. Bien que ce ne soit pas une barrière pour moi, un jeu aussi subtil n'est absolument pas facile à prendre en main pour une personne qui "se débrouille" en anglais s'il veut en tirer toutes les ficelles du jeu. On pourrait penser que le jeu est simpliste à la simple vue des graphismes, qu'on se le dise tout de suite : il n'en est rien. C'est un jeu complet et qui demande d'y rejouer pour y prendre du vrai plaisir parce qu'on SAIT comment y jouer.
- Le tutoriel, je n'ai rien contre découvrir un jeu mais il a des traits de jeu de plateau complexe et sans un livret de règle du jeu on ne comprend rien. Je ne dis pas qu'il n'y a pas de tutoriel, je dis qu'il devrait être + complet notamment concernant la phase de préparation.
- Les bonus, on devrait pouvoir accéder aux bonus que l'on possède. Je pense notamment aux bonus de l'arbe de science qui n'est pas disponible lors de l'exploration, j'ai personnellement fait une partie en science et j'avoue qu'après 2 arbres débloqués, à part les grands traits (compétence initiale et finale) je me souvenais plus de ce qu'il y avait dedans.
- Pour finir l'étendue du jeu : les destinations. Pour l'instant je n'ai rien à y redire mais il est vrai qu'après 4 parties j'aurai aimé voir d'autres endroits. Mais la bonne nouvelle est que la team est active et souhaite étendre le jeu.

En somme : très bon jeu.

20416549.review:
This was definitely one of the best games I’ve bought last year. It’s a strategy game with turn-based combat and resource management, great replayability and an active developer to boot, who’s working on a big update at the moment (January 2016).

[h1]The game[/h1]
You assemble a team of three explorers that you send on five expeditions in the quest of becoming the most renowned explorers. To become “renown” you need to find treasures but also resources that enable you to attract an entourage, conduct research, and buy equipment in between the expeditions. And of course, you also need to survive the encounters.
You can play in [u]two modes[/u]; one lets you make saves, the other ends with your death. The latter is the way it is meant to be played and, in my opinion, the only way to play it. If you want to ruin the game for you, use save-scumming. 

[b]Your team: [/b]The first step is to assemble your team. You can choose between [u]20 diverse characters[/u] with very unique skills and perks that belong to one of [u]four classes[/u] (scientist, scout, fighter, speaker). The combination of classes, skills and perks that you have in your team can greatly influence your success in the game. There isn’t one character that is just better than the rest, one character can do great in one team and be a bit useless in the next, and depending on the strategy you want to follow during the main part of the game, you might need a different combination of classes anyway. Trying out new teams is a big part of what makes this game so much fun and adds a lot of replayability.

[b]The expeditions:[/b] You can choose between a few destinations that all have their unique styles, events, treasures to find, and requirements. The [u]destinations are procedurally generated[/u], you move FTL-style from node to node, using supplies as “fuel”, and are confronted with different events or encounters. There is a big variety of events that are also influenced by which classes and perks you have in your team and the choices you’ve made, so it doesn’t get boring fast. I’ve played over 75 hours by now and I still get events I haven’t seen before and I’ve only found half of the unique treasures in the game, so there is a lot to keep you interested. 
Some events require luck, where you have a certain percentage to succeed based on the skills and perks of your characters. There’s also luck involved in the events that you get, some of the rare ones can be great if you find them, although they usually also involve a severe penalty if you fail. 

[b]The encounters:[/b] Turn-based combat that reminded me of X-Com. There’s a lot of depth to the combat system, much more than immediately obvious. Your characters and your enemies have [u]three main classes of attacks[/u], friendly, devious and aggressive. The type of attack you and your enemies use influence the overall [u]mood during the fight[/u], e.g. if you are both devious, the mood is tense, if they are friendly and you are aggressive, the mood is brutal. 
Some of these moods can be beneficial to you, e.g. give you more defence, while others can be negative. So, manipulating the mood by the attack-types you choose is very important. 
Equally important is [u]mood management of your characters[/u]. A friendly attack can leave your character in an impressed mood, which lowers your defence against speech attacks. So you might need to use a friendly attack on your own team member to heal them and change their mood to confident, which adds 25% to their aggressive attack. Obviously, you can use the same principle against your enemies, by using attacks that put them in moods which provide debuffs. 
And finally, sometimes you want to end the fight in a specific mood because you’ll get a bonus if you do. 
All of these effects are explained in [u]excellent tooltips[/u] that you can access during the encounter, there are no hidden effects, very little luck is involved and a lot of strategy. Great! 
You might “win” the game by just doing your thing and ignoring all these details but on higher difficulty and during the more difficult expeditions you will have a very hard time if you don’t use the moods to your advantage. 

[b]In-between expeditions:[/b] During an expedition you earn [u]collect, campaign, and science tokens[/u] that you can exchange for gold, status and research points after the expedition and use to upgrade your equipment, conduct research and hire an entourage. [u]Equipment[/u] can give you more perks and/or add defence or offence stats. [u]Research[/u] lets you get more of the resource that you want to focus on, can give you more supplies, can give you extra bonuses if you end fights in a specific mood, etc. [u]Status[/u] lets you hire an entourage which will let you get more out of your tokens and can also provide you with more perks. 
The success of your overall strategy (which destinations do you want to visit, do you want to focus on a specific resource, ...) will be very much influenced by the choices you make here.

[b]Conclusion[/b]: Fun game that requires a lot of strategy and a bit of luck (although it is very rare that you’re getting completely screwed over by RNG), with more depth to it than you’d think. You can easily finish one game in one evening, although if you’re like me you’ll likely want to start a new one immediately. 
The only drawback is that there could be more destinations, but as the developers are already working on a big update, I'm hopeful that this will be fixed soon. And as I still haven't seen everything there is to see after 75 hours of gameplay, I can't really complain too much, anyway.

[u]I wholeheartedly recommend this game.[/u]

If you like this game, there is a DLC available:
Renowned Explorers: More To Explore

20411515.review:
;If you're looking for a short(ish) game that allows you to play through one set of adventures in a few hours, this is perfect.  There are a lot of parallels to FTL, from the semi randomly generated maps, to the resources collected, to the semi random upgrades, but I feel that RE:IS has a lot more depth than FTL does - both are enjoyable in their own way, and both will take a while to master the tactics, but RE:IS just feels like there's more there.  The different combat powers, the way you can affect your crew and the enemy based on mood and how you 'attack' is very nice.  I like the different options you've got for upgrading between expeditions and how there are plenty of different paths to follow.  The game isn't perfect, but it's got plenty of enjoyment in it, and I'm definitely looking forward to more content.

If you're looking for a nice, gentle difficulty curve, it seems like it might be there, if you pick the right crew and know the right order to take the expeditions in, but it seems to win, you're going to have to hit some of those nasty, RNG difficulty spikes and let fate have a big hand in the final decision.  I like the fact that you can 'finish' the game without winning, but there are also situations where you end up in a fight where you very quickly realize you're over your head, and unlike FTL, there's no way to run away and have the chance to lick your wounds, your game is over (assuming you play adventure mode).  This does seem a little harsh, even in a roguelike with permadeath, being locked in a fight where you know you can't win, which will end the game, but you still have plenty of resources if you could run away and try something else is more than a little frustrating.  I wish there was a 'run away!' option from encounters, but that's pretty minor.

If I have any complaints about RE:IS it's that there's very little map content - there only seem to be a few of each 'difficulty' map, and within those maps, the variability is somewhat limited, so you're going to be playing the same mini adventures over and over again.  FTL has so many different encounters, this seems to be less of an issue there.

Additionally, the only ongoing 'unlocks' that you can obtain in RE:IS are getting crew members to the point they can be captains - though this is similar to FTL's unlocking of new ship layouts and new ships, since you start with all the crew, this somehow, to me anyway, feels less like an accomplishment, but it doesn't take anything away from the enjoyability of the game.

20399167.review:
As of writing this review, I have something like 40 hours (yes, 40) into this game, and still haven't beaten it. Admittedly, I didn't go for any of those wimpy copout lower difficulties and modes - I went straight for Adventure; Classic.

Here's the thing though, time after time, I may have lost, but I've never really felt like it was unfair, and I've always learned something new about how the game works. I've heard the FTL: Faster Than Light comparison - and there's a lot of similarities - you'll never feel like you've got QUITE enough resources to tackle the curveballs the game sends your way. You'll lose far more often than you win. 

Still, where I found FTL to be frustrating, RE:IS is rewarding. Every set of skills is valuable, and will open up paths you never even guessed were going to be there. Most importantly though, this game had me grinning like an idiot even as a crotchety priestess from Scotland whooped my professional hit squad's collective behind. A good purchase.

20396808.review:
RE is a great game which combines procedurally generated expeditions with a node based exploration system and an unexpectedly deep turn-based combat system dominated by mood. Between expeditions you can earn resources by lecturing, gain various entourages, research papers for various improvements and buy gear in shops.

1)	[u]The team[/u] – you pick 3 explorers (scientist, scout, fighter or speaker) each with various perks (engineering, diplomacy, survivalist etc.) that have an effect on your chance for success during expeditions. As you level them up they gain more perks and their stats increase

2)	[u]The expedition[/u] – every place (Mali, Hungary, Egypt etc.) has specific challenges and treasures to be discovered, and certain perks are more beneficial than others depending where you go as are certain styles of combat. There are 5 expeditions per game, so you won’t see them all during one playthrough (2-3 hours).

3)	[u]Combat[/u] – there are 3 moods of attack (friendly, devious and aggressive), and each mood has 3 emotions (friendly – you can impress, encourage or excite an enemy or your own unit). There are many types of attack (cone area dmg, ranged etc.) but most inflict dmg and one of those emotions. Furthermore those attacks have an effect on the general combat mood which can give you major buffs/debuffs. So if you are Devious and your enemy is Aggressive you get a big evasion boost and so on. The more you play the game, the more fun it gets.

This game is immediately fun when you start playing. It has a great atmosphere (think Indy 3), is very ‘cheeky’,  many big encounters have unexpected resolutions and it gives many nods and winks along the way. But the sheer number of possible outcomes, expedition combinations, the fact there are even individual (not class based) choices for many of the 20 characters and the great combat system is what keeps you coming back over and over again.

The developers are very active and new content is still being added. There is more to the game I didn’t put in my review and hopefully modding support is on the way. This game is perfect for mods.

Anyway 60 hours in and I like the game so much I wrote my first review. Hope you like it as well.

I spent a lot of time on this game but it was more for curiosity than satisfaction. I uninstalled and reinstalled it several times. There are a lot of neat concepts but the combination of which doesn't really work. This is due to the huge dependency on dice rolls rather than mini-games and the end product just wasn't satisfying to play. I think the randomness of dice rolls in getting loot, and just plain getting stuff done was too frustrating. Even the starting map is random and there are definitely way better ones to start with than others. 

 The character, captain bonuses, and skills are also very poorly balanced so you can end up with some very crappy teams on maps that don't use any of your relevant skills even though the vague descriptions imply they do. 

The battles are also sometimes very unfair with huge neverending waves of enemies. The battle map, obstacles, and starting positions are also completely random so getting a good or bad start can make or break your battle. 

I feel like there are a lot of good cocepts here but they took away too much player choice with the design. This feels less like a strattegic game and more like dice roll gambling on most everything. I think this game would be a lot more fun if players got more choice in choosing loot, mini-games affecting events, and battle positions. Right now, it's not really fun to just watch bad stuff happen to your team due to bad RNG.

20350910.review:
Writing my very first review in support of this awesome game.

9/10, best game I've played in a long while.

The graphics and art are great. There are so many animations and so much work put into it. For example, every character you come across, down to the sheep have 9-10 different facial expressions depending on their mood.

The music and sound effects are varied and interesting. Some of the songs I've found myself humming to after stopping playing.

The controls are great. I love games that you can play solely with the mouse.

The atmosphere and story is lighthearted and fun. You play a group of explorers searching the globe for rare artifacts. Think Indiana Jones. The characters (there are 20 of them) are each so unique. Rare in a roguelite game, you actually feel like they have character.

The gameplay, which is the core of any gaming experience, is some of the most original I've seen in years. You have 3/4 different things going on. First you have your character selection. You choose from 3 among 20 characters. There are so many combinations and synergies here it's ridiculous. Then you have the preparation for expeditions, which is akin to X-Com. You manage your crew, giving them jobs, hiring supporters and specialists, outfitting your explorers, then sending them on expeditions. Expeditions follow an FTL-like system of branches, but unlike FTL there's more strategy involved in how you make progress. Each path costs a different amount of supplies, and you have a better idea of what your headed into. Planning your trip becomes a major strategy factor in itself. Most places you go will have branching multiple choice paths. Some of these are very in depth with numerous paths. Depending on your explorers' skills, more opportunities are available to you, making each game very different. Finally, there's the combat which is imo the best part. It's a highly original turn based tactics game where you have a rock paper scissors dynamic of friendly persuasion, devious demoralization, and of course, outright beating the crap out of the enemy. Every character has one basic skill in each of these three, with most being best at one. Then two unique moves. Usually these are very complex with multiple ways to use them. Then 1-2 unique passive moves. Oh yeah, then the passive abilities that the equipment gives you. Oh, I almost forgot, and every character, including enemies, will have different moods which influence their stats. All this combines into a tactical combat system with more depth and variety than just about any other. It's fun as hell.

The only con I would give this game is that I wish there were more expeditions to go on (there's about 10 right now). But this is mitigated by the variety within each one, being randomized each playthrough. This fault is being remedied though, in that even in the short time the game's been out they've added a free one, and have more DLC planned. This is why I'm writing this review, please support this game, I want to see it thrive and expand. It's definitely worth the 20 bucks

20337617.review: One of the best indie games I've ever played. It combines rogue-like, rpg, and strategical/tatical elements with crisp, charming artwork and light, funny characters. You pick three members to go on an epic adventure for treasure, fame, and the bragging rights to call yourself the greatest explorer. Each playthrough lasts at least a couple of hours, and while there are no permanent boosts to carry over across playthroughs, you can unlock a huge cast of characters as you go, allowing yourself over a thousand different combinations of teams and subsequently, thorough replayability. Get this game - I promise you will find yourself saying to yourself at the end of adventures, just ... one ... more ... expedition!

20330802.review:
This game has a lot of things to recommend it, most of which pale upon repeated playthroughs.

Upon first glance, it features a wide array of playable characters. However, the characters have a lot of overlap in abilities and the available equipment is constant across runs, leading to very few distinct-feeling characters. And one of the three characters in your party has to either be one of the 5 starting captains or a character that you have already used a lot. Still, there's enough variety to keep things interesting at the start.

The combat works in emotions and diplomacy in addition to violence, which is interesting and innovative at first. Ultimately, though, it's just a rock-paper-scissors elemental system by another name. It's also frustrating that each character has one style of combat that they suck at, meaning that you're essentially playing rock-scissors and just having to grind things out whenever your enemy picks rock. The splash-damage abilities are a little disappointing, too. Since regular attacks often one-shot weak enemies, a splash attack that hits multiple enemies for a third of their health is frequently useless. Once the novelty of winning a battle with kindness or insults wears off, what's left behind is underwhelming.

There are actually very few adventure paths in this game. You get one of three random ones at the start, then three new options open up (same each game), then three new ones (same each game), then two more (same each game), then one more (again, same each game), and that's it. The unique treasures, events, and dialogues are quite cool. That is, of course, until you discover that they aren't unique. You get the same ones each time, on each adventure, on each run-through.

I guess I'm being pretty negative about the game. And there's a good bit to be negative about. But that's only because I've played it too much. The game is great when you first start playing, and will remain great if you have the sense to stop. Buy this on sale, run through each of the adventures once, and never touch it again. You'll have good memories of a novelty game that didn't overstay its welcome.

20311790.review:
This game is a must buy if you like strategy games or roguelikes. 

I seduced a tribesman for a magic mask, I beat sheep to death for science, and I captured King Kong and sold him to the zoo because that's what Renowned Explorers do. It's all fair game on the way to fame and fortune.  

This is the first time I've written a review on Steam.

That should give you some idea of how much of an impression Renowned Explorers has left me with in such a short amount of time. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND it to anybody who is a fan of King of Dragon Pass, Faster Than Light, or roguelike games. It's hard to describe because this game really is a breath of fresh air for any gamer that's played pretty much everything over the years.

It's not really like most other games. 

The combat system is easily the most interesting mechanic I've seen in years. The last time I was this impressed by a new idea like this was probably when I first played Civilization because it was that different and new ideas in games don't seem to come around all that often anymore. It all feels like more of the same, except for this game.

You pick your leader, recruit your crew, and set out on an adventure. You can build a party up of different characters, and there's a lot to choose from. You unlock them as leaders to lead your party later.

The super deep "combat" system. I can't rave about this enough. 

You can resolve encounters through skill checks before they happen sometimes, or by using aggression, devious, or friendly moves during them. Or, you can walk around the areas where you know they'll happen if you want. I mean, there's probably even more ways to handle a single encounter than that, but that's off the top of my head. That doesn't even get into the numerous strategies you can use while you're in combat. You don't have to stick with an aggressive approach for an entire encounter. You can switch halfway through to resolve it in a friendly or devious manner.

It's hard to explain. You just have to play it.

You MUST play it. 

The game really gives you the feeling that you're exploring the world like Indiana Jones, Nathan Drake, or Lara Croft. You have your crew members, and everybody has their own strengths and weaknesses.

The art style is Adorable!

If you ever felt like all the wonder was gone in the world. Or like most games are too damn oppressively moody, then you'll really love the tone of the writing, the refreshing art style, and the humorous events that just seem to happen through the stupid decisions you make.

The cons:

I'm not sure I've found any yet. One bug that resolved when I exited the game. There was an enemy that kept running around my screen like he was on crack after he died. It was more funny than anything.

I solved it by saving and exiting the game.

20295695.review:
Renowned Explorer:International Society (RE pour les intimes) est, pour ma pomme, la découverte de cette fin d'année. En outre, j'ai choisi de vivre dangereusement en l'offrant en cadeau alentours sans même prendre le temps de le tester. Prise de risque couronnée d'au moins un succès puisqu'une de mes victimes s'est trouvée rapidement séduite. Cette distribution dans mon entourage m'a permis d'en profiter aussi sans plus bourse délier via un partage familial Steam. Qu'il me jette la première pierre celui qui n'a jamais offert un cadeau sans penser « Comme ça j'en profiterai moi aussi ! », lieu commun bien connu dit « du train électrique ».

De fait, ce jeu à quelques points communs avec un train électrique. L'alibi de l'apparence graphique un peu enfantine cache en fait quelque chose de tout à fait propre à séduire les grands !

Si l'esprit général est celui du merveilleux scientifique à la Jules Verne, je regrette un peu l'intrusion de quelques tropes tendance culture-pop (momies, pirates vaudous…) qui tâchent parfois ce propos initial. Néanmoins le travail sur les ambiances est admirable et certaines expéditions donnent accès à des aventures très réussies  (Shangri-La...). Un autre regret est la relative brièveté : Cinq expéditions seulement et, même si la victoire débloque un « free game », on en voudrait bien plus. D'autant que triompher de l'antagoniste en chef (l'affreux de service bien nommé « Matthieu Rivaleux ») vous conduira probablement à disposer d'une équipe trop puissante pour que les expéditions suivantes présentent une quelconque difficulté, sinon procéder à un ratissage sans grand enjeu du restant de la carte du monde.
Pour en terminer au chapitre des récriminations, RE est dans un anglais écrit relativement soutenu. Rien d'insurmontable mais ça lui fermera sans doute une part du public potentiel sous nos latitudes. Un effort de traduction serait sans doute le bienvenu pour un jeu qui porte le mot "international" dans son nom...

Du côté des principes et mécanismes de gameplay, la description du jeu est assez juste (ce qui mérite d'être signalé, tant on en trouve sur Steam qui s'apparentent à de la publicité mensongère). RE exploite des principes empruntés aux rogue-like (comme la carte composée de « briques » combinées aléatoirement) pour alimenter son thème d'exploration dans un univers de fantasy victorienne, le tout servi dans une ambiance musicale et graphique très cartoon. Cette ambiance aura tendance à donner une fausse impression de facilité. Comprenez par là que le jeu est très abordable et accrocheur mais que, pour le vaincre, il faudra activer ses neurones ! Le brainstorming requis n'est en rien stérile et, s'il y a une part de hasard (La carte et quelques skillcheck au goût très « Koh Lantesque »), c'est bien un jeu de stratégie et d'aventures à la progression très fluide et non pas un puzzle-game qui vous fera buter des heures sur un obstacle artificiel et abscons.
Le joueur-explorateur compose son équipe de trois membres choisis parmi un panel aussi varié que haut en couleurs, puis commence sa carrière à travers des expéditions variées aux quatre coins du planisphère (Irlande, Himalaya, Mali, Caraïbes...etc.) dans le but d'acquérir gloire, pillage de trésors culturels ou pécuniers, « fardeau de l'homme blanc » et palme du « plus renommé des explorateurs ».
Trois grandes stratégies sont à déployer et éventuellement panacher sur le terrain face aux obstacles et réticences indigènes : L'approche « friendly » (casque en liège et grand sourire jusqu'aux oreilles, « Doctor Livingstone, I presume ? »), l'approche « devious » (façon Nicolas Machiavel accompagne Christophe Colomb) et l'approche guerrière (Moi y en a grosse canonnière ! Casser gueule à toi si pas donner trésor culturel pour exposition coloniale à moi !). Joueurs des pays dits « du sud », munissez vous quand même d'un peu de second degré ^^

Ce jeu apparemment sans grosse prétention mérite d'être connu et procure quelques excellentes heures (à la louche, 10 ou 15 pour un joueur de médiocre compétence dans mon genre).
