18811552.review:
I don't normally write reviews for games, but I feel like this one in particular deserves praise. I'll start you guys off with a quick and dirty comparison and then go into the nitty-gritty later.

tl;dr- This game is FTL meets Fire Emblem and it rocks.

I feel like a lot of strategy games get into the pitfall of bogging the game down with turns that take far too long. This game keeps everything short and sweet- combat encounters are usually resolved in 3-4 turns, while individual maps can be done in 10-20 minutes. Usually a session of the game lasts about an hour if you make it all the way through to the end.

I've been playing through with some of the recommended adventurers, but as I'm getting more of a feel for the weapon triangle I'm more excited to play more groups with different characters (and try for achievements like winning with a group of all scientists and the like.) and trying out some of the more tougher captains (Ivan and Molly have been tough to get runs through.)

The rules and mechanics are simple enough to understand while being diverse enough to keep things interesting and adding variety to the strategies you employ.

That all being said, the game does suffer from a lack of content. The difficulty and randomization do a lot to curb that. Over time I can imagine the game getting better due to more options for players going on a certain build path, but as it is right now I find myself replaying for self-imposed challenges rather than discovering new content.

A+++ would buy again.

18782007.review:
Great aesthetics, fun gameplay. Feels like FTL meets Carmen San Diego.

There are three levels of strategy to this game -
World - deciding what to invest your resources into improving
Expedition - choosing which encounters / events to activate, and which route to take before running out of supplies
Encounter - ordering your three explorers around to defeat enemies.

The encounter turn based strategy game is the weakest part, and unfortunately is also the largest part of the game. Encounters are either trivially easy or punishingly hard. The best "strategy" i've found is trapping enemies with no ranged attack behind a "chokepoint" that they could walk around in 2 turns if the AI wasn't so bad. Otherwise the strategy is to burn down the boss before the minions can kill you too many times.

Overall this game is pretty good and well polished, especially considering the price point. I just wish they would balance the encounters so they're not so hit or miss.

18776787.review:
You lead a team of 3 explorers (picked from 20 different characters in 4 main classes) on 5 explorations around the world (2 new targets of increasing difficulty after each successful exploration). Your goal: gain enough Renown on those 5 adventures to beat your main Rival in the society of explorers.
Lots of exploration (both in the game and in my review) which basically has you make a choice of route across a partially randomized map with partially randomized encounters towards the boss (including traps, choices) which will always be the same. The loot is chosen from among a pool per encounter increasing your Renown, as do some ressources you gather along the route you chose.
Some fighting tests your skill in positioning and in using the right mix of attacks against specific enemy setups. If you don't pay attention you won't beat the game on the adventure mode, which is the regular mode granting access to all achievements. Your group setup can make certain encounters easy, others rather difficult. You'll learn over time what works and which destinations suit some setups better.
This time learning and the resulting success, combined with needing to have every character succeed as a leader to achieve the list of achievements is the mid to long-term appeal of the game. It is fun, worth the money definitely and turns into casual gaming after you have seen every destination repeatedly. That repetition might give you a feeling of "again?" and is the only downside I can list (while I leave out lots of positive things in the small deatils), but my playtime can tell you, it didn't bother me much.
A huge bonus is the support. Listening to customers, asking for input, feedback, shelling out a free DLC and Halloween event just like that. Best-in-class.

Well worth it at full price, if it's on sale, this is a hell of a bargain. The Devs are amazing and are continually updating the game - including completely free DLC with a whole new area to explore.

One word of caution - if you don't want to be too frustrated by a capricious RNG, play on Discovery (saves allowed) mode.

18736880.review:
A good analogy to describe Renowned Explorers is that of an Iceberg. Looking at screenshots or even just one playthrough, you can be guiled into thinking you've seen all the game can offer. The game offers a high level of replayability as there are many possible combinations of explorers and exploration scenarios.

It's hard to describe RE because it doesnt quite fit into a conventional genre such as FPS, RTS, etc. You pick 3 explorers - these explorers are typified into classes (speaker, scientist, scout, fighter) that have their own strengths and weaknesses -and lead them across an exploration scenario collecting tokens. Through combat, diplomacy, or cunning, you resolve challenges across the exploration scenario - the makeup and stats of your explorers will determine your overall success.

Tokens earned can be spent on upgrading a research tech tree, attracting more followers, or purchasing loot. 

Combat in RE is especially well done. During combat, 'moods' can offer a significant bonus/penalty. Manipulating the mood of the combat situation is key to winning battles in harder difficulties. You can resolve a battle by being friendly, aggressive, or devious. 

Overall, RE is easy and fun to play but will take some learning and effort to master. The game offers alot of depth and replayability.

18719598.review:
Renowned Explorers: International Society (RE:IS) is a nice mix of FTL-style exploration and classic hex-field turn-based strategy (such as Heroes of Might and Magic). The game really shines as a complex system of resources and synergies; it's a lot of fun to try out different ways of generating the ultimate ressource in the game - renown. Another element standing out is the combat mood system. Based on your actions and your opponents' actions, the encounters have a different mood, which gives your units certain buffs and debuffs. This really encourages you to use all abilities of your explorers, rather than just using the 'strongest' or 'juicest' (which you can also do and is a challenge of its own). I think in this sense, RE:IS is a great developmental step from REUS, the studio's previous game. REUS had bautiful synergistic mechanics, but the game played more like a simulation. In RE:IS, the devs managed to forge the synergies into a great interdependent game system that is very enjoyable and rewarding - especially if you're into building systems/resource engines.

In general, I think that the game is also a bit too short (many others have mentioned that as well). You're done after a handful of explorations; to compare it with a card game: it feels a bit like playing Race for the Galaxy -- you're taking some turns building a great resource engine, but there's not much time to actually see it run. This being said: The replay value is great, but I think some additional campaigns, or some sort of ongoing exploration with limited lives ("resolve") could be a great addition. (The good news is that the devs are still working on some additional content and modes.) 

As much as I do like the mechanics and the complex resource system, I do think that the representations of different cultures and individuals are reinforcing problematic stereotypes. I do believe that 'exploration' type games do have a tendency to reinforce hegemonic world-views; in the case of RE:IS, I believe that the  "explorer" setting is indeed strongly reinforcing a eurocentric idea of exploration, and in fact, of cultural exploitation (and more than that: it refers to a style of colonialist exploration that actually did happen, and it romanticizes it). 

Many encounters involve helpless or fumbling natives that need the help of the explorers. In my opinion this does have an undertone of cultural inequality, and contains an imlicit message that suggests a cultural inferiority in the cultures we explore in the game. It is also important to note that  all of the places we explore are depicted as technologically, and culturally less advanced.

On one side, the game gives me the choice to resolve encounters agressively or via persuasion. But even if I use persuasion, or 'friendly' tactics, I am still taking something away from the culture (e.g. artifacts). In fact, there is no way to progress in the game without taking artifacts away from their originating culture.  For example, I talk myself into a monastery and convince the nuns to give me one of their relics. Cultural exchange is great - but in RE:IS, a classic colonialist (one-sided, and hegemonic) way of exploration is a constitutional part of the game setting, and game play. 


In conclusion: The irony in RE:IS is that the game mechanics are so bautifully synergistic - but the setting is colonialist. Overall I think that this is a game worth playing, set in a game setting worth problematizing and talking about.

This follows for 5 expeditions. At the last one all the cummulated experience of your crew is needed to survive, and better, explore!

Allong these far expeditions you really get a bond for your crew. The joy of them overcomming their obstacles as a team is truly becomming. Opposed to that is the fear of them failing challenges, or losing spirit in battle...

That brings me to how these obstacles can be overcome. when you enter a 'battle' with some people/cultists/sheep!? the  game switches to a TBS playboard. But since you are exploreres and not just conquistadores there are different approaches. Will you impress them with friendly boasting, pester them with devious remarks or just slice those natives in pieces as the conquistadore you apparently are. The 'life' of characters isnt composed of health but rather spirit, a nice and subtle touch.

18694589.review:
-------------------------------------------
Presentation Review
-------------------------------------------

First of all, I am getting this out of the way. RE:IS is a very compelling , Refined , Well-paced and simply epic way of telling story using every mechanic to support the idea of upbeat adventure. Which might be praised  for a hundreds of time already.

So I am going to focus on presentation this game has to offer instead. First of all, I am pretty much a sucker for anything that has a strong theme. whatever it might sound weird , serious , stupid or unrealistic it is, If the game living in it's own world and take advantage on it's own theme then it's doing presentation right (example : Darkest Dungeon , Hunnie Pop, Don't Starve , Recettear)

For limited budget game like REIS to shine out,  It has to need every aspect of the game to help represent the theme of 
the game and gladly they did almost everything right. the visual is bright and colorful in pop up book style , this might just look too simple on screenshots but when you playing it yourself it feel a hundred times more impressive. This is one of the game that design everything to support the theme itself. Characters design is vivid , a little goofy but they can be mixed together not just for create an efficient party but to change the story telling itself too. Also , to support the idea of combat system that based on "Friendly" , "Devious" and "Aggressive" ways, Every character has their own traits and personality fitting what they are. A small but important details like how they gain buffs or making facial expression on dialogue encounters helping a lot!  So even not in combat this game still keep getting interesting by well made story telling (which you have part of writing it too). It's not hard to find an epic funny story along the way and still this is not the end of how smart they using this system, Because the way they keep changing how encounters and event approach you. Eventually , You will find  most of them but it will hardly goes stale because you will still get different vibe with different party anyway. Even Combat system is created to compliment the theme , battle can be resolved in ways and it's really funny that you can even bully a giant monster until he cry and run away! (and that is A F**KING Brilliant way to make this game appealing).

The weakest point of presentation might be the soundtracks of the game, However it's not actually bad but comparing with all amazing aspect of this game, music in this game got a little off feeling (feel like it should be more upbeat and epic than this), And While it has a good feedback interface that giving most information you need to know. some of them are still lacking (like no tool-tips of unlock buildings in world map and some unclear combat tiles connection). Anyway these are just very tiny dot in this masterpiece.

Bottom line. Just shove money into this game as hard as you can! this game deserve more sale and attention than it is!
(I don't know if pricing in USD maybe a bit higher but in Thailand it's about $10 which is a very good deal)

18692307.review:
I saw this game through Total Biscuit's WTF is... episode (see it here if you are interested: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EXCleyTTShY) and bought it instantly. I regret nothing.

It is a very entertaining rougelite experience, with tactical turn based combat. There are similar games out there, but RE:IS has some features that make it stand out from the crowd.

Firstly theme and aesthetics. Game is set in XIXth century from the pulp novels of the era. It is the world of high adventure, voodoo pirates, mummies rising from their sarcophagi, travels around the world and exploration. Characters are embodiments of the tropes associated with that genre and they are given decent personality through simple things like their visual design and animation, despite almost complete lack of dialogue.

Secondly, combat. It is relatively simple, but uses a "mood" system to create interesting variations with each encounter. Video linked above explains it in more detail, but in short - each move in battle fits one of three moods: Friendly, Devious, Aggresive. Depending in each side's mood, party is affected by buffs or debufss. Add to it the fact, that ending encounter in certain ways may give different rewards and it creates a set of decisions going far past spamming the strongest available attacks.

Thirdly, the charming narrative. It strongly connects with the first point. Each encounter (in verty FTL-esque) manner has a short description (or set of descriptions) which capture the adventureous feeling of the whole thing.

There is one problem with the game, namely number of different adventures available. Within few hours it is possible to see every one of them (but not to see everything they offer - supplies acting as a time limit make it difficult to see everything on any map within one play). This is however prone to change since devs promised to keep content patches coming through the 2015 and in 2016, provided they can afford it.

So here's the selfish part - go buy and play RE:IS. You'll have fun and I'll get chance for more content :P.

Renowned Explorers: International Society ist trotz des ziemlich sperrigen und nicht gerade interessanten Namens alles andere als sperrig und uninterssant.
Es ist ein Roguelite Rundenbasiertes Strategie Spiel was man am ehesten mit FTL: Faster Than Light vergleichen kann.
Man stellt sich Anfangs eine Gruppe aus drei Entdeckern, mit unterschiedlichen Fähigkeiten, zusammen mit denen man dann auf der ganzen Welt nach Schätzen sucht.
Dabei muss man auf seine Ressourcen achten und trifft dann auf den bei jedem Run neu zufallsgenertierten Karten auf unterschiedliche Herrausforderungen und Kämpfe.
Die Erfolgsaussichten bei den Herrausforderrungen werden durch die Persönlichkeit & Fähigkeiten der Abenteurer stark beeinflusst.
Die rundenbasierten Kämpfe funktionieren nach einer Art Schere, Stein, Papier Prinzip und lassen sich je nach Einsatz der Fähigkeiten aggressiv, hinterhältig oder friedlich lösen, was je nach Party & Upgrade Zusammenstellung unterschiedliche Boni bringt und sich auch auf die jeweilige Quest auswirkt.
Nach einer Quest kann man auf der Weltkarte mit den gesammelten Ressourcen Forschung freischalten, den Abenteurern Items kaufen und Spezialisten die Boni bringen einstellen.
Mit jedem erfolgreichen Run kann man neue Anführer freischalten die jeweils andere einzigartige Boni für die Gruppe bringen.
Alles in allem ein leicht von der Hand gehendes Game mit erstaunlich viel Tiefe.

18686442.review:
Interesting tactical gameplay, a wide variety of playstyles, and nice presentation make for a great bout of rogue-lite fun!

Renowned Explorers is, as it says, a tactical rogue-like where you play a team of explorers seeking to become the greatest of all time!  Set in a 19th century vaguely steampunkish setting, the world has a lot of charisma and each expedition stage has its own quirks and charms.  I especially enjoyed the wide variety of crew members and I hope one of the things the developers release is more of them, as they add a real splash of color to the proceedings, especially as you realize that each explorer has hidden traits and abilities as well.

The goal is to become the most renowned explorer in the world, racing against a rival and his own crew of explorers.  You gain renown by, well, exploring and the fun is deciding what path you will take to both explore and to deal with the variety of challenges before you.  There are both choose-your-own-adventure moments, the random outcomes decided by the Adventure Wheel and influenced by the skills and stats of your explorers (sometimes also with those hidden character influences coming up), and tactical encounters.  Though simpler than something like the X-COM games, it still has engaging strategin elements, helped along by the emotion and three-part attitude systems.

Conflicts can be resolved by Agressive (straight up combat), Devious (trickery or intimidation), or by Friendly (diplomacy and enthusiasm) means.  Resolving encounters with different attitudes leads to different rewards, told to you on the battle screen.  Also, the emotions of characters can shift through different states, both positive and negative, each with added buffs and debuffs based on the emotion.  Performing repeated actions of a particular attiude can shift the overall attitude of the battle, which ALSO has a variety of buffs and debuffs.  Even blending some of one attitude during a round can shift the attitude to a different style of the current one.  There's a lot to discover and understand here, especially early on.

While I love the encounter system, it does have its flaws.  My biggest gripe is that there is only one 'health bar', Spirit, meaning that all forms of influence take from that bar.  It's not usually a problem, but it feels just a little off that both insults and gunfire do the same harm and are healed the same way.  When it comes to the Adventure Wheel, it can be a bit rough early on, especially as you are learning the system and the kinds of challenges, and sometimes the rogue-lite elements can bite you on the ass, throwing you into hard-to-handle situations just because of the arrangement of an expedition.

Overall, though, I greatly enjoy the game and look forward to many more playthroughs.  So many more teams to try and Captains to unlock!

Pros:
+ Interesting tactical encounter system
+ Bright and colorful art style
+ Charismatic cast of playable characters and plenty of things to unlock
+ Rogue-lite elements lead to lots of variety in playthroughs
+ Variety of expeditions to undertake, multiplied by the rogue-lite elements

Cons
- One health bar for all kinds of attacks feels funny
- Rogue-lite elements sometimes bite you on the ass
- Might be a bit overwhelming at first to completely grasp the emotion/attitude systems

18674246.review:
While this game does a lot of things right, it fails in a few key aspects. The game is supposed to be about an intrepid band of explorers venturing into the unknown and discovering lost lands, lost peoples, and lost treasures, but ultimately, it fails to deliver on that.

For example, you're supposed to be exploring the unknown, but in reality the path you're taking is fairly predictable. You know exactly how long your supplies will last, exactly what kind of challenge you'll run into, and exactly how best to deal with that challenge. There is certainy random chance involved, which is good, but it's in the wrong place. Instead of throwing you into the unknown and making you figure out how to get out of the mess you're in, you are instead encouraged to look forward, figure out what lies in store for you, and then meticulously plan out where you go and in what order to have the best chance of success. This isn't a bad mechanic per se, and in a different game it could make for some great gameplay, but for a game about exploring the unknown, it just doesn't click.

The combat is another example this. While I like the idea of using a combination of weapons, words, and trickery to defeat your enemies, the way it was done just makes everything feel gamey and contrived. Everything is boiled down to an attack on the enemy's HP, and at best you might get something that inflicts an unreliable status effect or changes the "mood" of the combat. Trying to be diplomatic or sneaky just ends up feeling the same as any other combat, rather than being it's own, interesting way to tackle challenges.

Renowned Explorers is a very good game and well polished.

It's a turn based game with nice graphics & music.

Recruit your adventurers and go play Indiana Jones around the world, from Scotland to Egypt, to The Mali, The Carribeans... etc...

The game plays like a board game where you have a lot of choices to make, fight your way using brute force, cunning art or try to befriend your enemies. Decide where to go on the map chosing the different locations which usually contain challenges you have to overcome to progress. You can't go everywhere on the map, you have to make choice, the problem is the food. Usually, a group of adventurers without food is a dead group !

In the Game, you have to pick your equip of 3 treasure hunters, each with his/her own abilities, in a roster of about 20.
During your adventures you gain experience and invest points to improve your team. With the research you gain during the game you can unlock technologies to help you during your journey.You gain money to buy equipment for your team too.

Well, the game has a good content and the developers are working to further improve the number of locations you can travel to.

A game usually last a few hours and you have a lot of replayability if you want to unlock everything in the game.

I hope this review helps you in your choice.

My advice, no hesitation, you can invest in the game, make a good coffee and send your adventurers in the jungle !

18595798.review:
Renowned Explorers is an innovative title from Abbey Games, an independent developer and publisher. It tells the tale of a group of ambitious explorers, out to gain fame and best their rivals by plundering treasures from across the globe.

Over the course of a game, you'll pick your crew of three explorers and send them on a series of expeditions to exotic locales such as the Egyptian desert or the forests of Transylvania. The encounters in each setting are procedurally generated, making each game a new adventure and offering great replayability. Fans of games like FTL will find much to love here.

The tactical combat system has a surprising level of depth. Each explorer in your party has his or her own set of abilities, and can be further specialised based on your skill selections and item choices. Additionally, combats feature a clever Attitude system, which grants bonuses or penalties based on how well you've optimised your use of Friendly, Devious and Aggressive abilities. In practice, you might end up charming a ghost pirate, insulting a nun, or even punching a cheeky monkey right in the mouth.

The game is remarkably well-polished, with charming graphics and a smooth user interface. It also provides an impressive level of feedback to the player at each decision point, even down to your odds of success on any given action and the factors which generated those odds.

Abbey Games continues to offer excellent support for this title, with regular patches and free content updates.

I bought this game at full price and was very satisfied with my purchase. Highly recommended.

18542367.review:
The first thing you notice about the game is that it's gorgeous.  Everything from environments to characters to animations are lovingly and wonderfully designed.

Gameplaywise, it's also engaging.  Watching the map unfold as you trot from location to location is always a treat.  There's a huge variety of events as well.  I'm still finding new events, and get excite when I find a new treasure.  

If you don't normally like roguelikes, don't worry!  You can play the whole game on "Explorer" mode, and restart any expedition you fail, with no loss.  This is great for finding all of the treasures in the game, some of which are deviously hidden and going after them can completely change the way you perform your expedition.

Enconters/battles are awesome as well,  Not only do you get to admire the characters close-up, but there's a surprising amount of tactical depth, using emotions to buff, debuff, and exploit weaknesses.  in fact, how you battle a boss can affect the boss's behavior and even the outcome of the event.

18481489.review:
This creative band had themselves a smashing debut with Reus, and it's always difficult to top a powerful first record. How did they do? Well, in a word, amgyes.

Upon playing this everyone will notice the cleverness, smoothness and fun-ness of it all. When the loading screen animations still crack you up after 20+ times, you know they pulled something off. 

This game is all replay value, to an extent that will make some gamers feel awkward (I may be referring to the type of players who specifically enjoy cinematic RPG's with many cutscenes and after each and every corner go F5, try this, die, F9, try that, die, F9, etc). Replaying this game is integral to the whole experience, and makes you tweak your tactics bit by bit until you have a formula that works well. Because this game is so appetizing and creative, the whole tactical puzzle becomes something wonderful. Instead of "oh snap I died again, NOOOO", it makes one go "oh yeah? well how about I do it THIS way". In any case, as a gamer you're being challenged to be EXPERIMENTAL, and try numerous combinations of tactics until you're beefed up enough to gain special items and level-ups. 

The most bizarre thing is that after Reus, a godgame in an arena devoid of godgames, they have pulled off their magic trick again of creating a game that is so original and flamboyant that it can only become a niche in itself.

18481381.review:
I have been fortunate enough to be allowed to play RE:IS when it was still being developed and it is amazing to see how much it has changed in the last stages of development. I am lucky enough to know one of the designers for Abbey Games and I was eating with him a few months prior to the release and he said: "We are going to change EVERYTHING!". And I am glad they did! It has gotten so good.

RE:IS is one of those games that you can come back to time and time again and it will be different and exciting and beautifull. The lovely hand drawn animations and backgrounds are candy for the eye, the dialogs and characters full of odd references and bad jokes. Lastly, there are so many mechanics and little systems hidden beneath it surface it will take you a long time to master them all. There is a bit of a learning curve here, and sometimes it can be very overwhelming to see all the little things you can take into consideration. It can easily scare away the more casual gamers from trying to understand this game. 

It has some aspects of FTL in it that work very well with the genre, I feel. The risk/reward choices you make to travel along a certain route in an expedition is the part of the game I enjoy the most. That and hugging it out with your "frienemies" instead of kicking their butt. But you can do that too if you want!

In short, love the game, love the looks, love the characters and I love the free content that keeps being added to make the game even better than it already was. Making it more playable for the casual and hardcore gamer in one simple update, and more content to come. 

9/10 for my part! 

(Also, if you enjoy that kind of thing, here is a video of me playing the intro of this game!)
https://youtu.be/mFcV0YZeKlE

18448255.review:
Overview:  A stellar game with elements of party management, resource management and tactical combat. The game consists of short, challenging play-throughs that build familiarity with the game levels and concepts. As you improve, the game provides re-playability through selection of different combinations of party members and/or attempts to refine your strategy for high score. Not only is the game already fun, but the developers are very active in the steam community to fix bugs and implement suggestions for improvement.

Read on for a description of the game play elements.

Party Selection: The first challenge is picking a captain and two crew members from a selection of 12 characters with a variety of strengths and weaknesses. The characters are divided into 4 classes, each with 2 of 9 traits, a variety of attacks, and semi-hidden personality traits with hints in the character description. The game provides plenty of advice for selecting your team, including description of a character’s strengths and weaknesses, recommended party members, and symbols for a party’s relative strength in each of the three offensive areas – allowing you to quickly select a balanced or specialized party. There is plenty to appeal to min-maxers, challenge runs, or leisure players that just want to select a quick party and go exploring.

Expeditions: After choosing a party you are cast into your 1st of 5 expeditions, in which you explore a location for resources (gold, campaign and research) and renown (victory points). The map shows the location of the final boss and a couple of nearby locations. Each location gives a hint of the challenges and rewards you may find. Some spaces give rewards automatically, some required the roll on a an adventure wheel, where your chance of success is determined by your party’s class, traits and stats. Some challenges provide an opportunity to avoid the roll for a lesser reward, others impose penalties for failure, including a loss of resolve (game over at 0). Your goal is to choose the route that will provide the most reward on the way to the final boss. You can take as long a path as you like, but if you run out of supplies, your team starts suffering stat penalties.

Encounters: Encounters are brief tactical combats that occur during expeditions. During combat, your characters can use aggressive attacks (physical), devious speech (insults) or friendly speech (compliments) to reduce your opponents’ spirit (hit points). Speech abilities also have 4 debuffs and 2 buffs (friendly speech) that can be applied to a target. Friendly abilities can be used on your own party to heal or remove debuffs. The debuffs/buffs only apply when a character has a positive or negative state of mind, which can be manipulated through use of devious or friendly speech. Also, using aggressive, devious, or friendly abilities will affect the mood of which is how the enemy perceives your actions. The enemy also has its own mood showing their preferred method of attack. The game applies bonuses in a RPS format based on your and your opponents’ mood, where aggressive > friendly > devious > aggressive. If your mood matches your opponent, you receive a bonus to abilities in the superior mood. If your mood is superior to your opponent, you receive a defensive bonus. If your mood is inferior, you receive a defensive penalty. If your characters die in combat, you lose one resolve. Characters can also be revived in lieu of attacking your opponents.
 
Preparation: After each successful expedition, you are given the chance to spend your resources to improve your characters. Research can be spent to improve your ability to earn rewards, or to make combat easier. Campaign is used to upgrade your shops or hire an entourage, which can improve the value of future reward tokens or increase the number of reward tokens you receive for certain events. Gold is spent on items. Each character can hold one offensive item, one defensive item and one trinket that provides unique bonuses. Will you buy quality armor for a single character, or spread the wealth for small improvements for all of your characters? Finding treasure during expeditions also earns insight, which can be spent during preparation to earn more research, campaign, or gold tokens – you decide.

Ending the Game: You win the game if you successfully complete 5 expeditions AND finish with more renown than your arch rival. You lose if your party is wiped out during combat, loses all of its resolve during expedition or combat, or if you complete 5 expeditions but don’t earn enough renown to be the top explorer.

If you like strategy and tactics, this game is for you.

18434624.review:
Indie rogue-like games have been quite popular recently and Renowned Explorers is a great addition to the list. The game plays like mix of tabletop game and turn-based combat, with tokens collection and ability checks. Great game! 

Pros:
[list]
[*] Colorful, cartoonish art style fits well with the music.
[*] Cool battle mechanics, like the interactions between personal moods and general attitude.
[*] Great replayability, you could play a completely different new game with the same team just by switching the captain or your play style.
[*] Character customization and improvement through level up, equipped items, researched papers and entourage crew.
[*] Nice flexibility in the difficult levels. In the easiest mode, you don’t have to worry much about the battles if you just want to have fun with map exploration and treasure hunting.
[*] Some captain perks may not look very great at the start, but you can get awesome combos later on if you try to find the right treasures and research specific papers.
[*] The developers support is awesome, there are some confirmed improvements and content coming through the next months.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*] Random events and abilities checks are a major part of the appeal of these games, but RNG can be quite frustrating some times.
[*] There could be a few more Expedition places to choose, the potential is enormous.
[*] As a personal choice, I would prefer if some fantasy aspects were left out of the game, making the Exploration places and characters more like in real life. 
[/list]

I was waiting for a new game from Abbey since [i]Reus[/i] and they do not disappointed, looking forward to the next ones!

18431068.review:
First, this is my favorite game this year (2015).
Why ? Because it got everything for a good [b]roguelike-strategic-rpg-adventure game[/b]. Well, that's quite a long tag but let's speak about the game.

You're a crew of explorers (leaded by a captain). Every member has [b]special abilities and stats[/b]. Also note the levelling aspect and the equipment.

You set-up your crew (researche, buy stuff, get entourage), and then you jump on an adventure campaign !

You get through an [b]random-generated node-network areas[/b]. On these zone, you can complete actions with a success chance that depend on the traits of you crew members (archaeologist, naturalist, athlete, rogue ...).

An sometimes, you get into fights. The game proposes a sort of [b]rock-paper-scissors system[/b] depending on your actions (aggressive, devious or friendly) and get you bonuses or maluses.

Each playthrough is [b]unique[/b] (depending on your crew abilities, the treasures that affect your next runs, the random-generated maps, and the way you make the choices).
It's needed a lot of runs to discover bits by bits the story proposed in each campaign.

I'm currently at 32h and I'm not near the end of the content of the game (without speaking of the next adventures in two weeks)

To conclude, it's an [b]innovative, well-written and nice-looking[/b] roguelike-strategic-rpg-adventure game.

18419901.review:
Update: 600 hours in, I stand by this review. There's been quite a few improvements to RE:IS since I wrote this, I really recommend both this game and its DLC.
-------------------
When I first heard of Renowned Explorers : International Society (henceforce known as RE:IS) my initial reaction was along the lines of "what on earth is this?". I purchased it on a whim, and having now played it for nearly 100 hours and all treasures collected, it has definitely turned out to be one of my wisest purchases (and heck, i'm actually writing a proper review for once, my first one on steam.)

RE:IS is a roguelike in an Indiana Jones style - you and your crew will be having adventures all around the globe, from searching castles in the Scottish highlands to the tombs of  ancient pharoahs in Egypt in the hopes of finding treasures (and with over 100 treasures to find, there is plenty to see.) You'll run into a variety of characters such as bagpipe playing clansmen,  pirates suffering under a voodoo curse and a group of monkeys worshipping a giant fruit.

The game keeps a fairly lighthearted and humourous theme throughout, which is aided by its bright and colourful art style. Don't let this fool you however - there is a surprising amount of depth to be found in the games combat and exploration systems. Battles have three different approaches: you can befriend your enemy, offering them things such as compliments and peace treatires. Or you can take a straight up physical approach - hacking and slashing your way through hordes of your opponents. If you prefer a more devious approach, you can play mind games with your opponents, hurling insults towards them in such number that they run away from the battlefield sobbing.

Overall, RE:IS takes a refreshing approach to the turn-based rogue-like genre. The developers are very active within the community and listen to feedback and suggestions from players. The game is frequently updated with new content, and more has been promised down the line. I highly recommend purchasing this game.

18417426.review:
So in this game you establish a team of 3 explorers, then go off on a series of adventures in order to defeat that dastardly Frenchman Rivaleux and his team of equally dastardly explorers. You have 3 options as to how you handle encounters: You can be Agressive, Friendly or Devious. These work in a rock paper scissors style system. As you complete these expeditions you find different types of currency, which can be spent on upgrading your crew in various ways. The in-game tutorials do an excellent job of explaining this to you, and prevent any confusion you may have at first. 
The encounters themselves are fun and unique, even if you play through the same encounters again and again they always go a little differently, though they can be a a little cheap (and borderline unfair) at times (I'm looking at you, Vladimir). Unfortunately there are very little encounters currently in the game, so you WILL be playing the same ones again and again.
Overall I'd say it's an excellent game and well worth the price, with frequent updates adding more content. If you're at all interested in strategy or turn based combat I'd say this game is a must-have, as it's a nice blend of combat and RNG (generally to determine how many resources you manage to gather) with a lot of replayability and quirky, interesting and  generally adorable characters.
I highly reccomend it and would give it a 9/10.

18404895.review: Giant scorpions!  Pirates!  Sheep?  Welcome to the world of Renowned Explorers!  I'll start by saying I bought this game on a whim.  I was looking for something fun and challenging, but that wouldn't take a vast amount of time to complete. I would have settled for a "Meh" time killer, but I bought this and now I'm hopelessly addicted.  I can honestly say my first thought after an hour of playing was that I'd gladly pay for any future DLC to expand the game.  And that was after I'd lost five times.  It's a unique game that can be a bit difficult to describe, but rather than just shouting, "I love it!", I'll give it a try.   Basically you start by selecting a team of 3 characters from pools of 4 different types of explorers.  Each explorer is unique (some attacks abilities are repeated but the characters all have their own animations and it goes a long way to giving them the feeling of individual personalities) and has Skills, that effect how they play and their success rate on events that can occur while on an adventure.  After selecting your team, you start working your way through Adventures you want to undertake.  While on Adventures,  you explore locations on the Adventure Map searching for resources (used to upgrade your team) and events.  Events fall into three basic categories:  Adventure Wheel challenges (think The Price is Right), combat instances and story challenges (like choose your own adventure books). Lots of  events contain elements of all three.  Combat is tactical and features a unique system in which attacks are divided into Friendly (charm), Devious (psychological) and Aggressive (physical violence).  This ties into the flavor of your team.  Now at this point, we need to jump back to character selection.  Certain characters complement each other better when teamed together.  I've read some comments criticising the combat system as confusing and certain adventures as too hard.  The truth is, what team you put together determines which expeditions you're best suited to undertake and what tactics are best to use in combat.  *The game gives you all this information, you just need to read it.* When you select your crew, it tells you what types of team (Friendly, Devious or Aggressive) the character works best with.  It even gives examples in the character discription of the types of charcters they'd work well with.  It will even show you the type of team (Friendly, Devious, Aggressive) you're putting together at the top of the team selection screen.  The descriptions of Adventures tell you what type of team or what character skills are best suited for those adventures.  I imagine a lot of those people complaining did what I did at first, which is skim this information and go, "These three look cool together, I'll use them!"  Team Super Awesome may be the coolest looking group of explorers around, but it doesn't mean they'll work that well  together or that they have any hope of  making it out of Transylvannia alive.   This is a roguelike.  I recommend sticking fairly close to the recommended teams until you have the chance to get a feel for the Adventures and different characters.  For the combat system, it's one of my personal favorite things about the game.  You can overwhelm pirates with charm, beat the living daylights out of evil cultists, or even make an ancient goddess cry and run away.  The types of attacks you use (your Atttitude) versus the type of attacks your opponent is using (their Attitude) create a Mood (displayed in the top center of the tactical map) that grants various buffs/debuffs.  As a tip, next to the Mood display are little indicators showing how many of the other types of attacks you can use before your Attitude changes, which changes the Mood.  You can mix and match attacks, managing and manipulating the Mood to your advantage is part of the challenge.  Be aware, the AI can do the same.  Pros:  A wide cast of playable characters that feel like individuals (not just reskinned clones).  A fun art style that goes very well with the game's sense of humour.  The combat system is unique and challenging.  Tons of content and an enormous amount of replayability.  While there is some violence, most of it is slapstick or cartoonish, and  I'd say it's one of the safer games out here for younger players.  It's fun, which I know sounds rather simple, but I can honestly say at no point have I been bored or felt gameplay was tedious.  Stability (I haven't had a single bug or crash).  Cons:  A playthrough only consists of 5 Adventures.  You won't understand why that would qualify as a con until you play it and realize how much you wish you could squeeze in just one more  :)

18395774.review:
If you want the review summarized in a few words at the beginning of it, so that you can spare yourself the trouble of reading, there it is: this game is the next THE NEXT FTL (Faster than Light, come on, if you don't know what it is and don't have it, just buy it and play it already), but JUST A TAD OVERPRICED. Easy as that.

Renowned Explorers: International Society (REIS) is a game where you command a crew of 3 explorers on a quest to unravel as many treasures, gain as much renown and eventually rise to the top of the explorer society by beating you top rival... um... Rivaleux. Wowzers, very creative, I know :) So does the game deliver? Let's take a look at the good and the bad.

The Good:

1. Amazing replayability. No 2 groups are the same, they always yield different results in battle, and can be played in a plethora of ways.
2. Good AI. NOTE: I mean good, not great. On classic, it will exploit some of your misakes and forgive you others.
3. Unique locations with great art: the artwork of this game is great, the devs did am awesome job with it.
4. Unique Characters: your Captain and your crew members all have unique capabilities, and you are free to mix and match them to your heart's content, discovering the best combos and finding out what works best for you.
5. An innovative take on combat: combat can be won with friendship, deviousness, aggression and... guile. Why guile? Because you can mix and match all of those 3 combat approaches to achieve a combat status that best fits your next move at any given time, and thus win a battle more easily.
6. A game over that barely feels like a game over. Your crew doesn't really die... they just have "stuff" happen to them. Like spend the remainder of their lives repenting in an all-nun monastery. Well, if that was a 3 man crew... they have their work cut out for them.
7. Easy to roleplay: I am not a good roleplayer AT ALL. Yet I found myself putting lines in my toon's mouths. Say, my girl does an ew and shows some soiled undies to another female and I was like: "Geez girl, when was the last time you changed your knickers?!" - reaction: "Saddened". In another case she shows a snail and points at a guy and I was like "Sheesh, mate, even she knows that you are slow to get it up". And then I LOLED. And then I was happy.  And then I went to bed with a smile of my face. 'Bout that...
8. This game easily puts a smile on your face through dialogues, the encounters (charming wolves and sheep FTW), and the combat. Yeah, even when you're losing...
9. Tons of unlockables: the devs really went balls to the wall with this one. You have 20 unique characters, with every one of them available as a captain after you've played them a few times, over 100 achievements, treasures, and 4 difficulty levels with or without savescumming.
10. Ironman if you want: many rogue-likes (Lites?) have an imposed ironman setting. Here you don't. All that the non-ironman game does is to lock you out are the achievements, and that is a small gripe, especially when it comes to a game as hard as this one. 'Bout that #2...
11. The game is hard. It's brutal. It's so damn difficult to win. I love it. Even getting 2nd or 3rd place is an achievement. Hell, even surviving the whole ordeal is :D
12. 12 procedurally generated maps with tons of stuff to unlock on them.
13. Your experiences matter and the game teaches you as you go. I really like that about a game - it makes my subsequent playthroughs meaningful, and much more fun.
14. Tooltips give you an idea what to expect and even let you turn back and back out of a possible challenge, encounter or opportunity, which is a rare thing in rogue-like (lite?) games. You just need to read, you know...
15. The game gives you recommendations with your starting crew (every toon has 2 "best fits" so to speak), which saves you some trial and error time.
16. Once you get the hang of the entire system, just like in FTL, the game feels great to play.

And now, the bad:

1. Only a limited number of maps. 12 is ultimately too little if you want to play this game over and over.
2. The game is HARD. It will take you a good amount of hours to find a decent crew composition and make it work. And then you need to get used to the bosses... and then you need to get used to the levels... and then you need to learn which toons does what ability... and then you need to pick the proper maps to do it... and finally, you need to make it work. Yeah... that's a lot of info.
3. You can lose missions through no fault of your own. The map can screw you, the RNG can screw you, the enemies can screw you, etc. I had runs where I was consistently losing high % rolls... not a pretty sight.
4. Very high learning curve. Learning how every character, every enemy, every mood combo, every attack and so on and so forth works is a daunting challenge.
5. Overpriced. While the game is good, 20€ is too much. I personally bought it on HumbleBundle for the US equivalent of Euro and even had a % of it donated some to charity, so I feel good about myself. On steam, however, 20€ is a lot.

The conclusion:

This game gets an easy recommendation from me, especially to the gamers of the rogue-like (lite?) genre. The game allows you to do pretty much everything with it - explore safely, savescum, challenge yourself, find tresures, go achievement crazy and so on and so forth. It never makes you feel bad about losing too. Your guys don't perish - they just get to live a different life or flee. This makes it a great game for people who are generally sensitive or don't like to lose their in-game crew. All of this is a grat selling point to this game. Its setbacks comprise of a high learning curve, limited maps and TIME. Yes, you need time, and you really need to take the game in and let it teach you. Not everyone is ready to do that.

Any price reduction of 33% or more makes the game an easy purchase. It needs love in my opinion, because it does so much right, and it is a breath of fresh air to the genre, by letting you do whatever you feel like it with it. I have a ton of fun with it, and I will keep on doing so. 8.7 hours in, just a tad less than my play time in FTL, and this game still isn't getting old, and that is saying something.

18389426.review:
Renowned Explorer (RE) is one of the very best game that I have played for the last 10 years, period :).

I have about 300 games, and haven't felt so excited about a new game for such a long time --- perhaps the last time that I felt so excited was  as long as Civilization 1 in 1991.

I normally play RPGs, but Renowned Explorer is in a Genre all by itself. It's radically different from the typical RPG or strategy games that I am family with.  Because it is so different, it took me a while to grasp and learn the basics of the game. In the end, after learning about the game, I begin to have great fun... and hundreds of hours on the game. 

The nice thing about RE is that the entire game campaign consists of 5 expeditions, and you can play it over and over again with different team setups. Different team captains have different super powers, and so, each game with a different captain usually require different strategy and even different playstyle, making in intriguing and interesting.

Another nice thing about RE is that the development team offered to add additional contents and updates on a regular basis. So far they have already added quite a bit of new content. Such a commitment from a developing team is really commendable. Even with 276 hours played, I will still be playing this game whenever they add anything new. 

I am sure I will get MORE than my money's worth and highly recommend this game.

18226498.review:
Don't want to write a review, too busy playing the game!

No seriously, this game is charming, interesting and while on the surface, doesn't appear to have a lot of replayability due to the number of scenarios, actually hides an amazing amount of secrets in each location. So what does this game bring to the table? What makes it replayable?

It is designed to be played multiple times so each session will only last a few hours at most. You form a three person team from a roster of 20 characters divided into four specializations. The catch being that only four are unlocked at the start to be in the captain roll. Simply playing the game and running with different characters in the other two positions permanently unlocks them for the captain position in future playthroughs. On top of this you can choose how you approach your encounters, be it friendly, devious or aggressively so playing for or against type can throw your opponents for a loop.

Now the biggest drawback is the lack of locations to explore. Currently you have three possible starting locations and then choose from a handful of others. Your goal is to gain enough reknown to beat a rival explorer at a special party, but you only have time for a total of five explorations before the deadline hits and the most reknowned explorer is crowned. While I will freely admit to wanting more locations to explore there is a lot of replay value in what is currently available if you're determined to hunt down all the side quests or you want to nail a significant portion of the 100+ achievements currently available. Each currently available explorable location is stuffed full of interesting things to uncover. You can scour every spot on a playthrough only to discover a different event chain in that location in your next playthrough. The locations were definitely well thought out and had a lot of time and effort put into each one by the developers.

Would I recommend this game?

Yes. If nothing else, it's definitely worth a solid ten to fifteen hours of gameplay just to unlock all the captains and see a good chunk of the quest events. There are plenty more hours to be had if you want to find all the in game trophies and want to grab a good chunk of or even all the achievements. I just finished unlocking all 20 characters for captain use at nearly 13 hours and have only gotten about half of the in game treasure from various side quests and main quest chains and finding all of said side quests.



tl;dr

10/10 Would make sheep feel bad about their life choices again.

18181644.review:
I have to say this is probably one of the most fun games I’ve downloaded since making a Steam account, definitely a pleasant surprise.  It’s a fun little premise based on running a team of three explorers through a handful of expeditions to exotic locations (pirate-infested isles, Count Dracula’s castle, the mysterious Shangri-Lai), exploring and gathering rare treasures.  Your time is split basically between three screens – the planning screen where you use the resources you’ve gathered to buy new equipment, unlock scientific advancements to improve your abilities, and gather an entourage of followers to increase the value of future resources.  It’s a nice little balance that allows you to take different approaches in how you improve your team.  Easy to use but requires some time and thought to really master and make the most of your choices.  

The other two screens are the game itself.  The first is a map of the area where you pick what locale on the map to explore, trying to match your characters’ diverse skills to what the region is likely to yield.  IE, don’t send your party of fighters to spots where expertise in engineering or science is needed.  Finally the third, where you’ll spend a bulk of your time, is in the turn-based combat screen in which you resolve encounters according to your characters’ abilities in a kind of fun paper-rock-scissors dynamic that can see a friendly argument rapidly turn into fisticuffs.  The challenge of course being to balance it so that your own characters stay one step ahead of the fight by leveraging the skills their best at.    

Altogether it’s a diverse little game that allows for a lot of play-throughs with different teams and styles.   It’s also the rare RPG where skills actually mean something more than just an alternative way to kill enemies.  The right mix of skills on your team can have your characters gathering tremendous amounts of renown (the way the game is scored) while a poorly selected and equipped team may end up just scraping by or eventually outmatched in the later stages.  It’s even possible to go through the game without technically ever getting into a physical fight – defeating enemies purely through the persuasive powers of your speech skill, a real rarity in any kind of adventure game.

I’d say it’s definitely worth a try if anything about the premise appeals to you.  The developers did a pretty excellent job of bringing the world to life and offering something a little different, and they’ve continued to tweak an already well-developed game in response to the community’s wants and suggestions.  And if it’s the art that’s maybe giving you pause, I’d advise you don’t let that dissuade you – it’s actually a pretty nice looking game when it’s running and while the cartoony style fits the sometimes humorous tone, this is a serious game that takes a level of skill and dedication to really master.

I have to say I had a bad first impression of the game, art wise. Upon first starting up, the initial loading screen and introduction menu looks badly slapped together. 

Really, white text on black screen loading? Abbey Games you couldn't have done a simple but nice splash screen with a loading bar? And the start game menu! Why are all the text buttons arranged in a small row vertically (so hard to read!), when there is so much space? Why is the start menu screen background a flat boring landscape when you have far better art throughout the game?

Whilst this may come off as nitpicky, first impressions do count!

And this is such a shame (and so easy to fix!), as RE:IS is a gem, and I can wholeheartedly recommend it.

It is a great mash-up of gameplay genres: rogue-like permadeath choices (if you choose to play it this way), choose-your-own-adventure storytelling, reasonably deep and interesting tactical hex-grid-like battles.

It has an interesting and fresh setting, fun and funky characters, mostly well-written and funny storylines.

I had a lot of fun playing this game. Even though I won it twice in classic adventure mode (failed in many other runs), I would go back to retry again using different captains and characters because you want to see how other strategies play out.

I would say this game has surprising depth.

Replay value wise, I agree with other commenters that the number of expeditions are a little on the low side. After a few playthroughs, you have seen many of the events there are to see. If this can be bumped up, it will really make the game shine.

18164020.review:
Не бойтесь графики, игра по хардкору. 

Вкратце: 
Качественная игра которую угораздило выйти в один день с MGSV и Mad Max. 
За 10-15 часов пиратства и 11 официальных пока ни разу не прошёл, одобряю. 
Так же есть "глобальный" уровень сложности гораздо легче - с повторами боёв при поражении, два-три подуровня легче по балансу и даже пропуски боёв, ничего не пробовал ибо это не круто, но для тех кто не хочет "по хардкору" нет преград.
Всё хорошо, только музыку нужно свою включать вместо местной.

Описание что ли:
При старте игры формируется отряд из трёх путешественников (из двадцати на выбор). Персонажи делятся на 4 класса: учёные, разведчики, бойцы и дипломаты. Внутри классов, в каждой пятёрке, различается друг от друга упором на разные навыки и линии развития. Особенности персонажа выбранного на роль капитана определяют общее рекомендуемое направление развития отряда, выгоду от определенных действий и т.д. (при старте только трое могут быть капитанами, остальные разблокируются в процессе, удачными экспедициями с ними в команде).

Передвижение по карте схоже с секторами FTL: территория, точка начала, точка финиша и точки между ними (в тумане), переход с точки на точку расходует провизию, отсутствие преследователей сбалансировано большим дефицитом ресурсов. Исследование территорий без провизии добавляет пенальти (минус к броне, минус к атаке и т.д.) каждый ход. Случайные события (ладно, не тысячи их, но довольно много, некоторые встречаются практически каждое прохождение, некоторые же довольно редко)

Бои пошаговые, но динамичные, без упора на позиционирование и т.д., зато со своей фишкой/изюминкой в виде трёх настроений/типов атак. Вместо здоровья здесь "сила духа" или "уверенность" (или "сила воли", "will" в общем). Физическое насилие, издёвка и дружелюбие работают по принципу "камень, ножницы, бумага": воина размахивающего кулаками легче довести ёдким словцом до истерики, сквернослова побороть открытым и дружелюбным отношением, пацифиста же утрамбовать с ноги. Такие дела. Можно всех любить и распространять мир и любовь. А можно саблей.
Дружелюбные скиллы позволяют так же лечить/"вселять уверенность" в союзников. Внутри этих трёх групп скиллы так же делятся по настроениям, (например те же дружелюбные скиллы могут "ободрять", "восхищать", "очаровывать", разные последствия от каждого вида), по дистанциям и т.д. Использование скиллов одного типа меняет общее настроение в команде и... 
В общем довольно интересная система, которой удобнее пользоваться чем объяснять.

Для тех кто беспокоится о "Curious Expedition": ничего общего в геймплее.
Для тех кто беспокоится о графике: рисунки и анимация очень хорошего качества, да, может показаться слишком красочно с непривычки, но ничего страшного на самом деле. Вот просто  нравится так рисовать чувакам, это странно, да, но вышло у них ловко, внимание к мелочам что надо.

В остальном, игроку неплохо бы любить мультфильмы. И уметь читать по английски. Уметь няшиться и делать ":3"
И сменить музыку, на Prodigy например, внутриигровая слишком торжественна, забивает пафосом, вместо того чтобы оттенять происходящее, а стоило бы.

18137575.review: A charming, innovative and polished game. The encounter system, featuring the turn-based tactical 'combat' of the game, is the weak point, being perhaps too challenging for casual players and too simple for TBS lovers (contrast to FTL, which is somewhat similar, though FTL has more entertaining combat and rather lifeless events). Still, Abbey games has produced a gem here, setting an example that I hope more games follow.

18135578.review:
Update after 50+ hours: Everything's perfect now! 10/10
---------------------------

Renowned Explorers (short: RE)
Genre: adventure, exploration, board game, resource management, survival...
_________________________

I have to start the review with this disclaimer: I started gaming in the 1980s and I was utterly repelled by the graphics of RE. It has this nasty tablet game vibe and feels like it's catering to stupid kids, not even smart kids but plain retarded children. Oh boy, can looks be deceiving! This game is so incredibly mature and deep while still being highly accessible.
--------------
Gameplay:
RE is a rare genre-mix and feels like an Indiana Jones movie. You select a team with 1 leader and 2 sidekicks out of 20 unique characters from four categories (scientist, scout, fighter, speaker).
This gives you the total number of possible combinations: (20!) / ((20-17)! * 3!) = 1140 party combinations!

Then you pick between normal mode and the much better "iron man" mode. It's how every game of this kind should be played, no reloading. Once you're dead, you're dead. One playthrough only lasts a few hours anyways. In iron man mode it's much more tense and fun! Then you pick one out of 4 difficulty modes. Hint: always play iron man, just pick a lower difficulty setting if you want!

Once you have assembled your party, you will have 5 expeditions for your claim to fame. Every expedition takes you to a beautiful place around the globe. This is where the board game aspect kicks in. You move across the map from node to node with limited supplies (each node costs 1 supply). Each node offers different benefits. Sometimes you will get encounters. An encounter plays out on a hex based battle field. This is where the game becomes really complex.

Encounters can be resolved in three ways: peaceful, devious, aggressive.
There is a rock-paper-scissor element to it, but it goes much deeper. Based on your team's skills and the opponent, there are many possible ways to solve an encounter. You can pistol-whip everything, you can charm your opponent or you can backstab them. Really cool stuff and really clever. 
Each expedition ends with a boss fight. Once that is mastered you return to the world map where the resource management unfolds. You can invest in research, items, entourage... again numerous choices, again very complex.

At the end of 5 expeditions (if you're still alive by then!) you get your final score. The devs are planning an online highscore list. The current limitation to 5 expeditions has been critiziced by some people, but let me say two things about that:
1. the devs already announced longer game modes for future patches
2. the idea behind the game is that each playthrough lasts only a few hours and the emphasis is on replay value with different teams (remember: 1140 different combinations!). After all you're unlocking new captains by playing the game. This is exactly what made FTL (Faster Than Light) such a modern classic. Quick playthroughs and a lot of incentive to start over.
-------------

Technical aspect:
Graphics are very good, but annoyingly childish (fake Disney-look). I don't like the over-the-top comical style, but objectively they are executed flawlessly.
Sound is okay, but nothing special. I turned off the music quickly, but I do that in every game.
The real beauty is the programming. So many Indie games suffer from poor to mediocre programming and you can tell immediately. Be it CTDs, clumsy interfaces and plain poor controls... RE truly shines here. This game is a smooth as any 200 million dollar production can be. Wonderful design and implementation. It's just a pleasure to play. 
__________________

Summary:
Very complex, yet easily accessible game. The looks are deceiving. It's a true PC game that looks like tablet garbage.
Highly recommended for everyone... I can't think of a single person who wouldn't enjoy this one.
My biggest gripe (the cartoonish look) isn't even a real con. If you hate that like me, first thing you should do: turn off the action camera.

Rating: [strike]9.5/10[/strike]


---------------------------------------
Update: 23.09.2015
11 hours and 5 campaigns (iron man, normal difficulty) thus far. I won 3 and lost 2 campaigns.
Still extremely high fun factor. The replay value is enormous thanks to the sheer endless possible combinations of characters. I lost my first campaign with an all-out scientist crew. That emphasizes how important a versatile crew is.

One issue is beginning to bother me now. The number of expeditions is too low. It should take more than 11 hours to have seen everything. The devs announced 1 more free expedition and more to come via DLC. Depending on the price that can be good or bad.
I would recommend to deliver 1-2 more free expeditions before moving on to DLC. The lack of content has been a major negative point in many reviews I've read and I have to agree with that.
For a $20+ game you should expect a bit more content.
This leads to a slight devaluation of my rating.

Rating: [strike]9.0/10[/strike]

---------------------------------
Update: 15.10.2015
A brand new free DLC-expedition set in Mali will be released next week. This kind of post-launch support is highly commendable!

Rating: [strike]9.5/10[/strike]

--------------------------------------------
Update: 12.11.2015
Picked up the game after a long time. 
The devs have been extraordinarily active constantly improving the game. You can tell how much they love their product. Some characters used to be weak, they found perfect solutions for that. Every minor gripe I had is solved by now. Hell, I even love the graphics now. The tablet look put my old 1980s gamer genes off for quite a while, but I got used to it and finally see beauty in those loveable characters.

This game is absolutely fabulous now. I doubled my total playing time in this week alone. I'm hopelessly addicted now. For the first time ever I will rate a game with the highest possible score.

Rating: 10/10

18081498.review:
On one hand its a diamond in the rough on the other.. That is one pretty frickin awesome diamond.

The gameplay is absolutely great, exploring is great fun and the combat is a mix of rock, paper, scissors and chess. You fight by either being agressive, devious or friendly. Depending on what attacks you use the mood of the battle will change, awarding buffs or de-buffs, and enemies will be weak/strong versus certain attacks. Balancing damage output with trying to keep the fight in a favorable mood while keeping your team alive can be quite the challenge. 

One of my favourite parts is putting your team toghther from the 20 or so characters. Depending on your set-up the game will change quite drastically, some encounters will be much easier, others down-right impossible. Maps will also become easier or harder depending on who you bring with what kind of skillset. Speaking of the maps, there arn't that many but they do change their layout with every playthrough. The main encounter (boss) of each map will never change but there are several mini-bosses that awards treasure that keeps it feeling fresh as well as different challenges and encounters in general. 

On to the negative. Technical issues. There are quite a few. At least on mac. Some maps are nearly un-playable because of FPS issues, There are some skills that don't seem to work properly. Graphics when you're fighting can get a bit wonky making everything blurry.

But even considering the technical stuff this is an absolutely amazing game that I have had a ton of fun with. Buy it. Buy it now.

Ressalto não é o tipo de jogo que você irá querer jogar horas, e nem possui uma história e enredo por trás. É basicamente, selecionar sua equipe, dentre umas 20 opções, e escolher os mapas da sua aventura, fazer escolhas  e travar algumas batalhas.

Vale a pena? Sim, em um preço bom, e indico para quem quer um jogo mais tranquilo e limitado, pois acaba ficando repetitivo com o tempo.

Refreshingly unique game mechanics and fun context. Like with Reus, it took a bit of effort to learn all the mechanics of their system, which didn't match the casual tone of the art. But it was worth it to wrap my head around all the different elements of the game, because the experience got really fun after a few playthroughs.

This is the first roguelike I'm aware of with a compelling tactics system, where you don't have to go through the world murdering everything in sight. That accomplishment alone was worth the price of admission for me. The character designs were also quite fun. The art in generally was very clever and well executed.

Each session is a bit short, but it took me quite a few tries to win, and I'm sure it will take me quite a few more tries to 100% complete the game (like with Reus). A part of me hopes Abby Games will keep inventing new game systems, but if they make ten sequels to Renowned Explorers, I would probably by them all.

18009133.review:
Pretty fun "rogue-lite" game. Each playthrough will be different from the last one and there's plenty of options in the cast to customize your party. Overall if you're into mid-length games with a degree of randomness (but limited randomness, not completely make-or-break randomness) like Reus this is a pretty good pick up.

Pros:

- Very original gameplay; fusion of Civ-like combat with text-based-adventuring overworlds
- Easy to pick up, but enough depth to actually require some learning
- High level of party customization, re-playability
- Low levels of "game-losing" RNG instances
- Intuitive combat systems
- Visually very appealing IMO

Cons:

- Some bugs, mostly text-only though
- There is some "game-losing" or "game-ruining" RNG instances, which really suck (forced choices with very low success rates)
- No real incentive to play above the easiest mode as you can unlock all the achievements without playing on harder modes
- Developing a strategy to min/max resources outside of exploration is not explained very well
- I do wish you could make your own characters


Overall, somewhere in the range of 7-8/10, a good game in a weird hybrid genre that I've not seen before. .
