17863707.review:
Renowned Explorers: International Society nous propose de faire la part belle à l'aventurier qui sommeille en nous, qui ne rêve pas de se la jouer Lara Croft ou Indiana Jones? Il est ici question de partir dans des contrées inconnues et d'aller braver les dangers dans une équipe de 3 qu'il conviendra de bien choisir en fonction de leurs capacités et de leurs aptitudes sur le terrain. Il existe 4 types d'aventuriers: les combattants, les éclaireurs, les scientifiques et les portes paroles. Il faudra donc bien choisir parmi plusieurs héros dont un leader naturel qui est débloqué dès le début du jeu. Pour permettre d'avoir plus de leaders, il faudra jouer le même personnage dans 3 aventures afin de pouvoir le choisir au début de la partie. Comme tout bon FTL qui se respecte, sachez que lorsque vos aventuriers seront morts, il faudra recommencer une nouvelle partie de 0. Le jeu nous propose malgré tout 2 niveaux de difficultés qui permettront dans le plus permissif d'essayer à nouveau un niveau après avoir passé de vie à trépas.

Le principe du jeu est de se déplacer dans une carte aléatoire afin d'aller y découvrir des trésors et d'affronter des situations diverses et variés qui peuvent aller de rencontres avec les indigènes où il faudra négocier ou faire des choix comme aller dans une mine ou soudoyer les mineurs pour faire le travail à notre place. On dispose de 10 rations de nourriture que l'on utilisera à chaque fois que l'on se déplace sur la carte ration par ration. Heureusement, le jeu nous indique ce qui nous attend sur chaque nodule ce qui nous permettra de faire des choix au moment d'avancer dans la carte. Si l'on a utilisé toutes nos rations, on héritera d'un débuff à chaque fois que l'on se déplacera sur la carte. Il arrivera aussi assez souvent de devoir en découdre avec des adversaires comme des moutons, des indigènes ou alors des autochtones moustachus dont le sens de l'humour n'est pas la principale qualité. Certaines actions demanderont une compétence particulière qui ne sera disponible que chez certains personnages, sachez que le jeu nous montre le pourcentage de réussite de l'opération en fonction de notre personnage et de son évolution. On appréciera tout particulièrement la mise en scène de ces actions qui se déroulent via une roue de la fortune ou de l'infortune. Si on tombe sur le bon segment de la roue, c'est gagné. Sinon c'est une autre histoire et à nous la honte et les quolibets.

Les combats dans Renowned Explorers: International Society se déroulent au tour par tour comme un XCOM par exemple. On se retrouve sur une carte où l'on est entouré d'ennemis qui apparaitront au fur et à mesure du combat à intervalles réguliers. Il faudra donc bien réfléchir à ce que l'on fait en matière de priorité d'ennemis à tuer car une fois que l'on tué le boss de la carte, on a gagné. Il est possible de se déplacer d'un certain nombre de cases et ensuite d'effectuer une action qui peut être offensive, défensive ou neutre. Certaines cases permettent de soigner automatiquement nos personnages pour peu que l'on s'y déplace. Les combats sont un des gros point fort du jeu car il y a de multiples façons de s'y prendre, on peut y aller en mode commando en utilisant les compétences de couleur rouge ou en mode taunt qui consistera à briser le mental de nos adversaire en se moquant de lui et en l'humiliant. On peut également user de diplomatie afin de rendre nos adversaires plus dociles et moins enclin à nous mettre leur poing sur notre figure. Le jeu reprend le principe de Pierre-Papier-Ciseaux au niveau des combats, la force fera plus mal à un adversaire pacifique par exemple. Le pacifisme sera plus fort que la raillerie qui sera elle-même plus forte que la force pure.

Une fois que l'on a atteint la carte avec le boss de l'aventure et que l'on a combattu avec succès, on héritera d'un trésor unique qui nous fera gagner de l'admiration. En fonction de nos actions dans l'aventure, on aura gagné des niveaux pour les 3 personnages, de l'argent ou de la connaissance qui vous permettront de débloquer de l'équipement, du support et des compétences afin de rendre votre prochaine aventure plus facile. A vous donc d'explorer comme il se doit les niveaux afin de trouver ces ressources, sachez également qu'il n'est pas rare de tomber sur de la nourriture ce qui vous permettra de trouver des objectifs secondaires qui apporteront leurs lots de surprises que ce soit au niveau du scénario de l'aventure ou au niveau des récompenses. L'objectif principal du jeu est de rabattre le caquet de notre nemesis Rivaleux, un autre aventurier qui ne manquera pas de nous mettre dans la panade à la moindre occasion et de nous mettre des bâtons dans les roues. Pour ce faire, il suffit d'amasser plus de réputation que lui et le dépasser dans la guilde des aventuriers. Plus facile à dire qu'à faire bien sûr!

Renowned Explorers: International Society est un jeu où il ne faut pas trop s'attacher à ses équipes de personnages car la défaite arrive vite et sans crier gare. C'est aussi tout ce qui fait le charme et l'intérêt du jeu, comptez environ 6-8 heures pour réussir votre première aventure de fond en comble et bien plus encore par la suite si vous souhaitez tout voir et tout débloquer. Plus on a l'habitude de jouer et plus les parties iront vite ce qui nous permettra de débloquer des objets et autres trésors nécessaires à notre progression globale dans le jeu. Il faudra compter 3-4 heures pour terminer vos prochaines aventures. La durée de vie est d'ailleurs remarquable car il y a énormément de choses à voir et à faire avant d'espérer tout débloquer que ce soit au niveau de achievements et des succès ingame. Une fois que l'on a accroché au principe, on ne lâche plus le jeu et on passe beaucoup de temps à peaufiner son équipe et à réfléchir à ce que l'on peut faire pour améliorer notre prochain run.

Renowned Explorers: International Society est très joli à regarder et à écouter. Le jeu ne nécessite pas un foudre de guerre pour tourner et il est compatible PC, Linux et MacOSX. Il est compatible avec le Steam Cloud ce qui est fort appréciable si l'on jour sur plusieurs ordinateurs comme c'est mon cas par exemple. Le jeu n'est pas trop gros en matière de place prise sur le disque dur et il se lance rapidement. La direction artistique est superbe avec des personnages expressifs et marrants à jouer. L'humour est omniprésent au niveau des dialogues et des interactions avec les personnages et autres ennemis. Les cartes Steam mettent pas mal de temps à tomber et elles valent assez cher pour le moment, pensez à jouer assez rapidement si votre but est de les vendre et de rentabiliser au mieux votre achat!

Au final, Renowned Explorers: International Society est un jeu vraiment attachant, il apporte un réel plus au genre et il est fort agréable à regarder et à jouer. Sa durée de vie est exemplaire ce qui rend le prix d'achat intéressant en définitive. C'est un gros progrès si on le compare à Reus que ce soit au niveau du tutoriel, de la réalisation et de la profondeur du contenu. Si vous aimez ce genre de jeu, foncez, vous ne le regretterez pas!

17863385.review:
Abbey Games delivers another refreshing game (and if you don't own Reus, their previous game, you should take a look at it !).
Renowned Explorer is about exploration and fame ! Pick a crew (you have several unique characters to choose from) and prepare yourself to explore different locations and find treasures that needs to be in a museum.

A bit of Exploration, a bit of RPG mecanics, lots of adventures, fun characters, lovely musics and graphics, fun story and events, and tactical combats. Abbey Games delivers again a very unique game (as they did with Reus).

This game features unique tactical combat mecanics with moods and emotions. Each combat skill gives an emotion to your target, playing with emotions and moods can totally change the outcome of a combat  (for better or worse). You can try to befriend your enemies instead of poking them. It's just brilliant... I love it :)

Every character begin with different perks and you'll be able to learn new ones during your expeditions. Those perks will make each expedition unique as most of the event will have to pass a check on those perks.

EDIT :
Abbey Games added difficulty mode and it's a welcome addition to the game.
The game has a rough learning curve and being able to play at a lower difficulty at first will help to grasp the mecanics before trying a harder difficulty.

RE:IS is cute, funny, hard, and addictive. You should totally try it out !

17862621.review:
At the moment I'm writing this, a day after release, there are 22 positive reviews and 0 negative of Renowned Explorers. I won't break the streak. This game is pure, unadulterated awesome. It's fun, interesting, challenging, amusing and very pretty.

... Let's back up a bit. Renowned Explorers is a roguelike, clearly inspired by FTL. It has a similar "decide where to go, solve text-based encounters, fight occassionaly" structure, but it is so much better. If you got discouraged by FTL or couldn't get into it (like me: I bought FTL ages ago, but it just lost my interest each time I tried to play), RE:IS might just be the game for you. 

Why is it better than FTL?
- It is breathtakingly beautiful. The crew members and the opponents they encounter are wonderfully designed, well-animated and also exceedingly funny.
- Your crew (three explorers) have so much personality. IT is coveyed by art (how much personality can there be in a simply attack animation) and by their reactions in an encounter. Say, if you have a very greedy crew member, they may just refuse to leave a treasure, even if it is risky.
- The plot is much more fun, at least for me - I really feel annoyance at our heroes' opponents.
- The encounter/fighting system is really interesting. It occurs on a tactical, hex based map, with varying terrain (e.g., some terrain heals characters standing on it) and interesting mood system. Every ability you use influences the mood of your team, and so does every opponent's action. The interplay between your mood and the opponent's mood can strengthen you or weaken, and furthermore most bosses have interesting reactions to a type of ability. For example, a Big Important Nun gets into her Condemn the Heretics mode if you try to use Aggression on her.
- You can play it in hardcore (here: adventure) mode, without retrying failed ancounters, or you can choose a casual approach, with free saving and retrying failed encounters. 
- Very varied content: every expedition our explorers can go on is different.
- Very funny writing.

17856834.review:
In my very first encounter, I encountered a pack of wolves.  I impressed them with my great intelligence, then insulted them.  They were confused by my mixed signals and ran away.  My most successful run was ended when a ghost pirate and his voodoo cultists were friendly and invited me to sit down for tea, and my crew felt that their vengeance against the Spanish was entirely reasonable and I should stop fighting.  My current game is more direct and is full of dashing gentlemen and fisticuffs.

This is absolutely amazing.  Yes, the overland map is a lot like FTL--random events that are influenced by your party skills.  Combat is your standard hex based tactics game (even though it's not really hex shaped, which is neat).  Physical attacks work like normal, but speech attacks are a major part of the game, and so is control of emotions and mood.  If your enemy is using devious speech attacks but you are being friendly (they all deplete Spirit just like physical attacks), then you get defense bonuses from being the good guys.  If both sides are friendly, then both sides get a bonus if they are the first ones to go to physical attacks, stuff like that.  Takes about an hour or two to really get used to it, but then it feels natural.

This game is pretty polished.  Not perfect, but it hits its mark pretty darn well.  Difficulty seems pretty well tuned, the first couple missions are easy but surviving to the end seems like a real challenge, much like FTL.  You can sit down for a couple hours and play a game or two and have them end in one sitting which is great, honestly...replayability seems high, and unlockables are present but a very minimal part of the experience.  Bugs are very minor and hard to spot.  It's really damn cool to be able to build a party that fights like something out of Monkey Island.

All in all, heavily recommended.

17856381.review:
Renowned Explorers: International Society is one of the most innovative turn based tactical game that I have ever played. 

You create a team of three explorers from an impressive roster of twenty. With that team, you go on semi-randomized expeditions to explore. The rewards you get depends on your team's talents.

Combat in this game is fantastic. At first glance, it deceives you into thinking it's another tactical hex grid turn based combat. As you learn more, you will realize the combat involves multiple layers of strategy. It rewards skills and forward thinking. If you plan your moves ahead, you can put yourself into great positions. However, one fatal mistake can immediately punish you.

After each expedition, using the rewards you recieved from your adventures, you can upgrade your team's equipments, research to gain bonuses, or hire an entourage of people to increase rewards for the future.

All of these intricate mechanics are tied together wonderfully with a storytelling process that fits naturally. Your journey is presented with brilliant artworks, animations, along with clever writings to bring the world and characters to life.

If you are interested in adventures, rogue-lite RPGs, turn based tactics or management simulations, this game should be right in your radar for your next purchase.

17852017.review: A fun and imaginative FTL-clone, with interesting stories, varied characters and tactics which differ between playthroughs.

17851783.review:
Renowned Explorers is, in many ways, reminiscent of FtL: Faster than Light. You lead a crew through a series of locations, some of which are just text-based choices, some of which are fighting encounters, many of which give you the opportunity to gather resources that you can later spend on upgrades and items that improve your crew. The game puts you in the shoes of a Dr. Livingstone-like explorer, going through the ruins of ancient civilizations looking for plunder. It's very good in this way. The art style is incredibly cute and a great asset to the game. Not only are the twenty different characters you can take on an expedition instantly recognisable, the character portraits in-game change when you affect their emotions, which is a lot of fun (making sheep sad is especially rewarding). The music is good as well, never distracting from the game, always adding to it.

A game like this, however, lives and dies with its events. Such games throw a lot of text at you, and it needs to be enjoyable. This, the game succeeds at. There are quite a number of cute little unique responses that make you want to replay the game to see how different characters would interact (for example, a pair of Hungarian lumberjacks gave me some extra goods because they were impressed by my moustache). As such, the game is quite good. It falters a bit in the combat, though. You can use three types of attacks (friendly, devious, and aggressive) to solve encounters, and they affect what you get out of the encounter, but they do tend to play out the same way in an encounter. You can do some nice tricks with it, but it doesn't feel as deep as in FtL. Another negative in the comparison with FtL is that you never really feel pressured. You use up your supplies to move through the map, but there aren't a lot of events that mess with you, so you can usually plan your entire expedition and proceed unrushed. The events do seem to have a lot more variation than in FtL, and the perks that you can unlock for your characters throughout the game make for extra interactions and unique responses to events.

All in all, Renowned Explorers is a very good game. It's enjoyable and its humour makes it very replayable. The humour, graphics, and sheer variety of events makes up for some of its shortcomings and makes it a game that I would be more likely to pick up again than FtL, where I have kind of already seen everything it has to offer. It could do, however, with some more depth in its combat system.

Update: the More to Explore expansion has come out, and it has massively improved on many aspects of the game. A number of balance issues have been solved, the new expeditions showcase some of the best design the Abbey Games team has to offer, and by including new campfire stories, there is a new reason to keep coming back to this game and replaying it. I do wish the player would be able to customise his or her campfire stories at the start of an expedition, but the expansion improves this game on all aspects.

17851761.review:
[b] Target Audience: [/b] [I] Strategy fnas. Also, those wanting to be strategy fans.[/i]

[u] Summary: [/u]
Board game lovers and traditional strategy game lovers will find enjoyment out of Renowned Explorers: International Society in more ways then one. Good balance and variety will allow for gameplay that has surprising depth despite it being very simple on the surface with its Rock, Paper, Scissors mechanics. The presentation works to a certain extent and the ability to customize your party and create different adventures is fun, especially if you get into your own immersion of giving the characters backstories on what has happened. Reasonable writing combined with gameplay you'll want to come back to makes a game that I really wish had a multiplayer element to it, but still works never the less. 

[b] Gameplay Footage and Video Review: http://youtu.be/T2L6mmBnlbw[/b]

[u] Lists: [/u]

[b]+:[/b]
[list]
[*] Addictive Strategy gameplay that's simple on the surface, but very complicated under the surface.
[*] Risk/Reward system is straight forward but makes you interested in those risks enough to go after them, but not overly powerful to give you too much of a boost.
[*] Like the twist on RPS mechanics with the mood system that can flip it on its head. Emotion system adds to the game and strategy and is easy enough for beginners to learn, but takes a while to master. 
[*] Emotions system is awesome. Adds a lot of depth in battle.
[*] RPG mechanics allows for a lot of paths and a lot of replayability. 
[*] Character designs are neat, and constructing a team of an old lady, a luchadora, and a magician was always appreciated. 
[*] Presentation on the surface works in terms of creating a world that you truly feel like an explorer in. 
[*] Straight forward choices with luck mechanics feels fair, balanced, and doesn't frustrate. 
[*] Developers kept on adding content over time. Dedicated. 
[/list]

[b]-:[/b]
[list]
[*] Really wish there was a multiplayer element, because I felt like it would have really taken it to the next level in terms of a purchase.
[*] Trailer characterization of in-game characters doesn't play off in game like that, which is disappointing, as that's what drove me to it. I recognize that may have been hard to really do, but it is still disappointing in the end.
[*] Some more information could be more easily accessible when it comes down to it.
[/list]

Ein Hallo an alle Rundenstrategie und Abenteuer Liebhaber! Das Spielchen hier hat einiges zu bieten, um sich völlig zurechtzufinden und alle Möglichkeiten zu kennen, gehen durchaus 2-3 Stunden ins Land. Und dann geht es erst so richtig los, denn es gibt verschiedene freizuschaltende Charaktere, verschiedene Skills, Techniken, Taktiken, Ressourcen/Loot uuuuund völlig verschiedene Maps. Man hat hier keinen klassischen Start und Zielpunkt, sondern startet zu Spielbeginn eine neue Mission, bekommt dann eine der zig verschiedenen Maps und eine Mission auf der Map angezeigt. Wie und ob man allerdings den Weg an dieses jeweilige Ziel einschlägt, ist die eigene Entscheidung. Auf den vielen unterschiedlichen Stationen bekommt man unterschiedliches Loot oder Errungenschaften, somit bekommen unsere Charaktere auch Erfahrungspunkte. Auch Kampfsequenzen sind vorhanden, welche rundenbasiert sind. Spiel ist ansprechend gestaltet und hat hohen Wiederspielwert. Empfehlenswert!

17847431.review:
Renowned Explorers est un mélange de plusieurs genres (aventure, stratégie, roguelike, RPG) donnant lieu à un excellent titre très passionnant et addictif.

- Graphiquement, le jeu est très sympathique avec une interface épurée et bien adaptée. Les environnements sont variés et la direction artistique est réussie.

- Au niveau du gameplay, vous choisissez 3 personnages parmi les 20 proposés, chacun ayant leurs propres caractéristiques. Une fois ces préparatifs accomplis, vous devez parcourir le monde à la recherche de ressources, trésors et autres merveilles, dans le but de devenir le meilleur aventurier. Durant une expedition, vous allez faire face à divers événements (rencontres avec des personnes amicales, des combats, des trésors, des ruines et autres monuments etc...) Un système de choix est donc mis en place et il est de votre devoir de prendre les bonnes décisions afin de préserver l'intégrité de votre groupe tout en essayant de collecter le maximum de ressources. 

- A la fin de chaque expédition, vous aurez le récapitulatif de toutes les ressources collectées et vous pourrez ensuite les dépenser pour débloquer diverses améliorations qui rendront vos prochaines aventures légèrement moins ardues (en achetant des équipements chez les marchants par exemple). 
Nos aventuriers progressent de niveaux, nous permettant ainsi de débloquer des nouvelles compétences. 

Le jeu est assez court, mais chaque partie est unique ce qui offre une extrême rejouabilité dû à son aspect "roguelike".

A noter que le jeu est disponible qu'en Anglais et qu'il y a pas mal de textes à lire; pas forcément compliqués, mais nécessitant quand même de bonnes bases.

Si vous avez des questions, n'hésitez-pas à m'ajouter ou à les poster dans les commentaires :)

17846264.review:
Renowned Explorers is great game. I have played about 1.5 hour so far and enjoyed it a lot during this time. It is kept in nice lighthearted mood that will keep you smiling through most of a game. I enjoy tactical encounters a lot and the fact that i can resolve in different ways. It is no longer just a case of winning but winning in the way that will benefit our crew the most. 

Game keeps it short and composes of 5 expedition to finish one run. It is similar to FTL in that manner that it can be completed in one afternoon and then you go on pick a new crew and start new procedurally generated adventure. I think game has potential to give hours of fun. 

I also highly appreciate the tutorial in the game it teaches all the basics you need to know to complete first expedition. 

My greatest concern is the price FTL legend that started it all is on sale for $ 9.99 and as much as I appreciate beautiful graphics of Renown explorers and more work put into the build I would prefer it to be slightly cheaper. For me it’s still worth it but it’s up to you to decide. 

I also have a video featuring first procedurally generated expedition in which I show the gameplay, talk about mechanics, and teach you how to play feel free to check it out and let me know what you think. If you have any questions hit me up here or on my channel I’m happy to help.
